IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Dynamic OCE with acoustic micro-tapping for in vivo monitoring of skin graft surgeries Narrative Skin grafting is one of the key procedures in reconstructive and plastic surgeries but, at present, there are no non-contact techniques to quantitatively characterize grafted site healing and, especially, scar formation. The goal of this project is to develop a non-contact, non-invasive clinical tool to characterize, image and monitor graft procedures using volumetric, sub-mm resolved maps of skin elasticity. We propose Optical Coherence Elastography (OCE) to quantitatively monitor skin grafting by volumetric measurements of skin's Young's modulus and anisotropy in donor and recipient sites at a pre-operative stage, and during post-surgery graft healing at all steps (inflammation, proliferation and remodeling); we will use acoustic micro-tapping (recently developed by our group) to efficiently launch sub-mm elastic waves in skin, image propagating mechanical waves with state-of-the-art fast phase-sensitive OCT, and reconstruct skin's elastic properties from acquired data using a biomechanical model considering skin's finite thickness and anisotropic layered structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application has high public health importance because it will: 1) support mentoring of junior investigators in patient-oriented research (POR) with a focus on the association between systemic inflammation and cognitive decline, thus aligning with the NIA’s mission to “Foster the development of research and clinician scientists in aging’; and 2) define role of inflammation and cardiovascular risk factors in risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), in order to inform risk stratification and future interventions on primary prevention of ADRD. The aims of the application perfectly align with the NIA’s goal of defining the impact of inflammatory processes on the development of AD and are directly relevant to the NIH’s mission to foster innovative research strategies and their applications to protect and improve public health.

PHR: Narrative Soft tissue sarcomas are malignant tumors that grow in soft tissues like fat, muscle, cartilage, or deep skin tissues. There are also benign soft tissue tumors affecting a much larger number of patients. The goal of this project is to develop a novel ultra-steerable histotripsy array system for non-invasive treatment of malignant and benign soft tissue tumors in both adults and children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed interdisciplinary research is relevant to public health because Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a significant opportunistic pathogen that can cause severe illness in newborns and immunocompromised individuals. Transmission via human milk (HM) has been recognized to have the largest global impact on population prevalence and, therefore, a research program will be undertaken to study HM CMV transmission dynamics in different timescales, systematically and quantitatively understand the role and interactions of the HM metabolome and microbiome in CMV transmission from women to their infants, validate factors blocking CMV transmission, and evaluate the impact of CMV transmission to the establishment and development of infant gut microbiota. Our findings will deepen our understanding of CMV transmission dynamics, provide a framework for translation assisted by mathematical models and artificial intelligence, and will lay the foundation for rational design of personalized interventions through naturally occurring HM microbiota and metabolites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year lung cancer kills more people in the United States than breast, colorectal and prostate cancer combined. Immunotherapies, including anti-PD-1 monoclonal antibodies, may reduce lung cancer morbidity and mortality, but we can’t yet accurately predict which patients will benefit. The goal of this work is to delineate the molecular mechanisms linking STK11 loss with anti-PD-1 therapy resistance in KRAS-driven lung adenocarcinoma and exploit that knowledge to restore sensitivity to current therapies while working to identify new treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The need to understand the functions of rare somatic mutations calls for multi-OMIC technologies that can scan somatic mutations and map epigenome simultaneously. Here we will optimize a method to generate both whole genome sequencing and 3D genome (Hi-C) data from single cells. Using a novel deep-learning-based pipeline, we can upgrade the sparse Hi-C maps to kilobase resolution, which serves as a robust readout for genome activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to expand the scope of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy against glioblastoma (GBM) by using the tumor-specific targeting capabilities inherent in chlorotoxin (CLTX) to redirect T cells against GBM. CLTX-CAR T cells are expected to broadly target heterogeneous GBM populations and be safe and well tolerated, with negligible activity against normal tissues. The proposed clinical trial aims to improve our understanding of tumor response to therapeutic pressure and key drivers of response and resistance to CAR T cell therapy, with the goal of improving outcomes of patients with GBM.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is affects 1/400-1/1000 and is caused mutations in PKD1 and PKD2, which encode polycystin proteins. This competing renewal application will uncover the functions of the polycystins on cilia and tiny extracellular vesicles. Our studies will provide insight about the biology of normal and pathological processes that require or are modulated by extracellular vesicles including ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Image distortions degrade the accuracy and sensitivity of detecting brain activity with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). This project aims to develop a novel method based on deep learning to correct for fMRI image distortions. This method can restore distortion-free images from measured MRI signal in k-space by incorporating the physical model of distortion effects with deep learning networks. This proposal will resolve a long-standing problem in fMRI, facilitating its applications in neuroscience, patient care, and other areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-infection with HIV is one of the most common risk factors for developing tuberculosis (TB) and so we model HIV and M. tuberculosis (Mtb) co-infection in monkeys, using simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) as an HIV surrogate, to study this. Our exciting preliminary data suggests that vaccinating SIV+ animals with intravenous Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG IV) confers remarkable protection from TB. Here, we will further evaluate BCG IV to better refine this vaccine regimen and to identify the mechanism of this striking protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project offers a brand-new paradigm on Crohn’s disease (CD)-associated intestinal strictures that will on the short term delve into novel cellular and molecular mechanisms of intestinal stricture formation and on the long-term will eventually foster the development of specific new drugs. Thus, this proposal is directly relevant to IBD and the goals of the National Institute of Health by benefitting more than half of Crohn’s disease (CD) patients and having a tangible impact on ways to prevent intestinal obstruction and avoid surgical resections. By investigating a previously unidentified role of the septin cytoskeleton inhibiting pro-fibrotic intestinal myofibroblast activation in vitro and in vivo, we will deviate from the traditional notion of immune cell-driven ECM deposition, and instead focus on the cytoskeleton being responsible for fibrosis and stricture formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the improvements in breast cancer survival, black women experience suboptimal quality of life, which is why it is important to evaluate their experiences to improve quality of life (QOL) and target healthy behaviors that foster a longer life among racial/ethnic minority breast cancer survivors. Physical activity (PA) is a modifiable behavior with the potential to help reduce racial disparities in QOL. This fellowship will help to establish the relationship between PA and QOL among black women, generate new knowledge and insights to enhance QOL among black women, cultivate community partnerships, and empower other researchers to increase the representation of racial/ethnic minorities in studies focusing on behavioral medicine to meet the needs of this community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While the poorly understood age-related factors promoting cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk require urgent investigation as the population ages, recent data establish CVD as the primary cause of the increased mortality in those with clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), which is common in elders (≥1 in 10 among >70 years). The aims of this proposal will: discover the germline genetic predisposition that induces CHIP-related CVD with N~575K to construct CHIP-specific polygenic interaction risk score (PIRS) for CVD, which stratify the risk of CVD in CHIP carriers (K99/Aim 1 and R00/Aim 3), prioritize causal mechanisms for CHIP-related coronary artery disease (CAD), which is the major cause of CVD, with integrating genomic data and multi-omics data (K99/Aim 2), and dissect the molecular mechanisms for CHIP-related CAD analyzing human specimens and combining with population genetics (R00/Aim 4). Successful completion of this study will directly improve the management of CVD risks in CHIP carriers by PIRS and pave the way for developing direct intervention by revealing mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Superoxide dismutase (SOD) enzymes are essential to life and reduce the level of reactive oxygen species in cells. Abnormal SOD activity is found in many pathologies, such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and cardiovascular dysfunction. To provide a detailed understanding of SOD in diseases and for the design of therapeutic interventions, our investigation seeks to define the atom-by-atom workings of the group of enzymes for the first time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growth in the aging population together with improved stroke care has resulted in an increase in survivors and a rise in recurrent ischemic events. Ischemic preconditioning has been shown to effectively protect neurons, while mechanisms of preconditioning in white matter remain to be studied even though axonal injury during stroke underlies the consequent neurological disability in surviving patients. We propose that inhibiting CK2 using an FDA-approved drug, CX-4945 (Silmitasertib), rapidly preconditions WM against ischemia by targeting axonal mitochondria and improving functional recovery in young and old WM both in males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging in the gonad dramatically affects aging in somatic tissues, yet we know little about the mechanisms regulating healthy aging in reproductive organs, nor how this crosstalk is achieved. The goal of the Reproductive Aging Conference will be to showcase research in the growing field of reproductive aging in both male and female systems and stimulate collaborations across disciplines that will help define new paradigms. This unique meeting brings together experts from both academic and clinical science, junior investigators, and trainees to examine mechanisms that regulate aging in reproductive tissues that facilitate overall health span and longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We discovered a robust anabolic response in human cartilage that follows a distal-proximal axis gradient (high in the ankle joint and low in the hip joint); this response was modulated by the same master regulators that regulate limb regeneration in animals capable of limb regeneration. This project investigates the origins of these master regulators in synovial cells, the mechanisms involved, and how aging effects these mechanisms in human joint tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Lecture Course NEUROSCIENCE OF ADDICTION (2024-2027) Narrative  The societal consequences of drug abuse and drug addiction are enormous. Over the past forty years, research on the mechanisms of action of addictive drugs have focused on pharmacology and behavioral pharmacology studies. With the rapid growth in molecular and systems neuroscience in the last two decades and the completion of the human genome more than a decade ago, integration between behavioral or physiological responses and molecular, genetic and cellular responses to addictive drugs is increasingly possible, opening new avenues for the understanding of drug use and drug abuse. Together with the development of increasingly sophisticated preclinical models of the disorder in rodents, amalgamation of these disciplines into contemporary research into the biobehavioral basis of the vulnerability to develop drug addiction requires a profound appreciation for the strengths and weaknesses of each approach. The theme of the proposed lecture course is to provide young and emerging scientists with the most up-to-date and exhaustive information on how tissues, cells and genes respond to drugs of abuse differently between individuals across species. This week-long residential course is targeted to both new and experienced investigators, and combines formal presentations and informal discussions to convey the merits and excitement of behavioral, cellular and molecular approaches to drug addiction research. The course will stress the significance of this approach not only to the most costly neuropsychiatric disorder, addiction, but its applicability to learning, memory, and other disciplines of neuroscience. Research on the psychological, neural, cellular and molecular and cellular changes that occur in response to drugs is critical for clarifying whether adaptive processes are diverse for each stage of addiction and for each drug of abuse. Ultimately, new treatments for these disorders are likely to emerge from a better understanding of the processes that go awry in vulnerable individuals during the transition from controlled to compulsive drug seeking and taking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed project will investigate the transcriptomic contributions of human and non-human primate brain development. While transcriptomic variability is well understood in early prenatal stages, especially for animal models, it is still unclear how gene expression varies across later stages in human brain development. Findings from this work will advance our knowledge of human-related genes that may play a key role in typical development and identify key windows for future clinical and mental health applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Emerging evidence from recent genome-wide studies has revealed that promoters across eukaryotes are commonly paired to drive bidirectional transcription. Work in yeast suggests bidirectional transcription could be the naïve or innate state of transcription initiation with directionality evolving due to the action of diverse pathways. Building on our initial success in developing a highly efficient in vitro reconstitution system of transcription initiation from highly purified yeast factors, we set out to further develop this system to solve the mechanism of divergent transcription through structural and biochemical dissection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) comprise a class of several thousand compounds that present a major public health problem worldwide. The 4th National Conference on Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances – Environmental Justice and Scientific Discovery, will be held in Ann Arbor, MI, a region affected by PFAS drinking water contamination. This meeting will uniquely convene scientists, government officials, environmental justice activists, affected community members, journalists, utility managers, and lawyers to examine the complex set of social, scientific, political, and environmental health issues associated with PFAS exposure and to cultivate cross-sector collaborations to more effectively prevent future exposure and protect human health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The laboratory mouse is the best genetically defined experimental vertebrate model organism for humans and, with widespread use in biomedical research, continues to present a major opportunity for advancement in the understanding of the genetics, biology and interventions of human disease. While many institutions provide ample access to didactic courses, few, if any, have intensive hands-on training in the experimental use of the laboratory mouse. Therefore, we propose to provide a unique opportunity to the next generation of biomedical researchers and health care providers by adapting a highly successful and high-impact workshop that we have thus far offered at The Jackson Laboratory and taking it “on the road” to their home institutions with an explicit focus on reducing barriers to participation by diverse and disadvantaged learner groups.

The 2024 Marine Natural Products Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) and Gordon Research Conference (GRC) will bring together up to 200 students, postdocs, early career and established investigators, providing a platform for discussing innovative research ideas in a highly interactive forum. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Metabolic dysregulation with all of its pathophysiological sequelae, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer, continues to be on the rise. We need to identify new areas that can be targeted for improvements in systemic metabolism. Over the last funding period, we have made significant progress towards defining key processes in the white adipocyte that lead to mitochondrial challenges and consequently, impaired adipose tissue dysfunction. These include challenges to the mitochondrial import machinery, loss of mitochondrial DNA and a dysregulation in iron metabolism. Here, we propose to integrate these challenges to examine how they feed into the mitochondrial Integrated Stress Response, leading to impaired downstream read-outs, such as reduced adiponectin release. This should identify new target areas for anti-diabetic and anti-cardiovascular disease intervention.

PHR: Narrative Sensory and signal transduction processes are essential for bacterial pathogens to produce virulence factors, to resist antimicrobials, to invade host tissues, and to evade the immune system. The 2024 STIM GRC will gather researchers from diverse fields to understand how bacteria sense and respond to their environment at levels that range from molecular mechanisms to interactions with the host on organismal level. The meeting will provide a powerful collaborative platform to address these questions from different perspectives, which will inform new strategies to develop antimicrobials and to combat infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite efforts to prevent suicide, US rates are climbing, and suicide is the second leading cause of death amongst youth. Digital tools, especially personal smartphones, are promising avenues to address these issues and can be used to increase engagement with effective interventions such as suicide safety planning. This Fast-Track SBIR proposal will enhance the effectiveness of the delivery of BRITE, a suicide safety planning smartphone application for youth at risk for suicide, by developing and testing an augmented version of the app that will integrate just-in-time adaptive intervention features to enhance engagement with the plan and thereby increase its effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: MAPS 2024 PROJECT NARATIVE The C. elegans Metabolism, Aging, Pathogenesis, Stress and Small RNAs symposium (MAPS) is a biennial international gathering that brings together researchers using C. elegans to study aging and the related disciplines of stress, metabolism, pathogenesis and small RNAs. C. elegans is a major platform for aging research and many foundational discoveries and mechanistic insights have originated through worm studies. Major goals of the 2024 MAPS meeting are (i) to provide a platform for presentation of predominantly unpublished, cutting-edge discoveries in worm aging from both established and new investigators, (ii) to provide opportunities for postdoc and graduate-student trainees, especially women and under-represented minorities (URMs) to present their research in oral talks and posters, (iii) facilitate mentoring and networking platforms for new faculty and trainees, particularly women and URMs, and (iv) to bring completely new ideas to aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammalian somatosensation is essential to our everyday life and experiences, such as being able to walk in a straight line or learning to play the piano. Since we rely on our sensations of itch, touch, and pain for emotional well-being and a range of behaviors, somatosensory dysfunction results in numerous clinical conditions that impact millions of people worldwide. This Keystone Symposia conference was designed to highlight major areas of somatosensation, progressing from the molecular level to the dynamics of neural circuits, behavior, and disease, to encourage the sharing of cutting-edge, unpublished data, to facilitate dynamic discussion and debate, as well as to promote new collaborations in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoiesis is the process by which the cellular components of the blood cells are formed, and research into these pathways has enhanced our understanding of other areas, including stem cell biology, aging, inflammation and blood cancer. Recent advances have changed the way that hematological malignancies can be targeted in the clinic using small molecule drugs, antibodies and cell-based therapies. This Keystone Symposia conference will provide a platform for basic and clinical investigators from across disciplines and around the globe to establish productive collaborations and stimulate new ideas to accelerate progress in hematology field and bring new medicines to the clinic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chagas disease, caused by the parasitic protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, represents a major public health problem in the Americas. We will develop more reliable tools for the diagnostic and genotyping of T. cruzi from blood samples of congenital and maternal cases. This would be fundamental to better understand T. cruzi molecular and clinical epidemiology, including the links between parasite diversity and congenital infection, leading to a better health care for Chagas disease patients and particularly infected pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The correct topological organization and transcriptional regulation of the B-lymphocyte genome during development and antibody gene diversification processes prevents aberrant chromosomal translocations and promotes appropriate diversification mechanisms. Recent advances in transcriptomics and genomics have identified the role of the noncoding RNA processing complex RNA exosome in the organization of the B cell genome and regulation of the DNA mutator protein Activation Induced Deaminase (AID). In this application, we evaluate the role of the RNA exosome complex, its cofactor proteins, the non-coding RNAs it processes including CTCF-binding element RNAs, and the roles of the 3D genomic architecture of the chromatin in regulating AID activity leading to robust class switch recombination and somatic hypermutation at the immunoglobulin loci genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cancer immunotherapy has been demonstrated to provide remarkable clinical benefit, and a contributor to this benefit is thought to be the high number of cancer mutations, present in some cancers, which can produce surface molecules called mutated peptides that can stimulate tumor-specific immune responses. However, for many cancers like chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the number of cancer mutations that are detected through standard methods is low, but a growing body of evidence suggest that these types of blood cancers have many alternative types of molecular changes that can still generate targets recognizable by the immune system. We propose to build an integrated program using innovative genomic technologies and mass spectrometry to better detect these new classes of patient-specific mutated peptides, to develop predictive tools for their identification, and then to apply these new tools to better understand how immune responses to these mutated peptides shape the clinical history of CLL and its response to immunotherapy exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The neurotransmitter dopamine critically controls physiological functions such as movement, learning, cognition and reward by activating receptors expressed on downstream neurons. Dopamine receptors are found along the cell surface and also within the primary cilium, a specialized cellular compartment whose influence on neuronal function is not well-understood. The current proposal will (a) investigate how dopamine receptors are translocated to primary cilia in cell models, (b) test whether these mechanisms are conserved in neurons, and (c) examine the impact of dopamine receptor signaling from primary cilia on neuronal activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have developed inhibitors of a cancer-promoting protein called spliced X box-binding protein-1 (XBP-1s) and shown that these inhibitors are effective in killing chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). In addition, we have shown that activation of a protein called the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) can also cause CLL cell death. Because both inhibition of XBP-1s and activation of STING can suppress a critical survival mechanism called B cell receptor signaling, we propose to treat CLL through a combination of these approaches and believe that results emanating from this study will inform new treatment strategies to combat CLL.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) is common in hospitalized patients and dramatically increases morbidity and mortality, however, it is frequently overlooked and untreated. Because of the heterogenous nature of AKI, personalized recommendations tailored to individual patients and delivered directly to the patient care team may improve AKI outcomes. This proposal aims to 1) determine whether a rapid response style Kidney Action Team can improve clinical outcomes of patients with AKI, 2) which patients and providers benefit from this intervention and 3) whether an automated system can accurately mimic the recommendations made by human Kidney Action Teams.

PROJECT_TITLE: Personalized Recommendations for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) Care Using a Kidney Action Team: A Randomized Trial

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anemia, defined by low hemoglobin content in the blood, is common in pregnancy, impairing the health of the mother as well as babies. Although the condition can easily be treated with currently available supplements or infusions, anemia is detected too late or not at all. This research focuses on developing a mobile health technology to simply measure blood hemoglobin levels using digital photos of the eyelid, maximizing the currently available resources for anemia diagnosis and management during pregnancy, in particular in the developing world and resource-limited (or at-home) settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spatial neglect is a common symptom after stroke and negatively impacts the ability to achieve independent functional mobility post stroke. This NRSA F31 proposal aims to explore and generate new information regarding the combination of novel motor and spatial training approaches (prism adaptation therapy + electrical stimulation and prism adaptation therapy + gait training) to enhance the rehabilitation of spatial neglect and walking function in individuals post-stroke. This work will generate novel information that will inform future design of new and targeted treatment protocols for evidence-based rehabilitation of spatial neglect and gait dysfunctions post- stroke, to improve gait function and quality of life in stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how the molecular components, inherited lineage, and spatial milieu of single cells dictate function in health and disease remains a key outstanding challenge in genomics. The overarching goal of our Center for Integrated Cellular Analysis is to develop methods to simultaneously assess these multimodal cellular properties, develop tools to harmonize them to allow inferential assessment of cell identity based on partial phenotyping, and share these developments with the broad scientific community while encouraging community engagement through education and outreach. Success in our strategy will facilitate deep, multi-omic phenotyping of single cells for basic research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tendons can withstand large forces due to a highly aligned, dense collagen matrix. Though a minor component of tendon, type III collagen contributes to properties of the extracellular matrix and cellular activity. This study will define the contribution of type III collagen to neonatal tendon development and the enhanced healing capacity of the neonatal tendon, revealing potential targets for improving mature tendon healing and informing clinical approaches to conditions with reduced type III collagen including vascular Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, aging, menopause, and smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE)    Sleep disturbances  predict  increased  risk  of  Alzheimer’s  disease  (AD).  Deficits  in  sleep  impair  memory  consolidation  and  contribute  to  the  accumulation  of  Aβ,  the  neurotoxic  peptide  that  builds  up  in  the  brains of AD  patients, thereby  affecting daily  function and  critically  contributing  to  disease  progression.  Our goal is to determine whether restoring activity in the thalamic reticular nucleus can normalize sleep,  reduce Aβ accumulation, and improve memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In addition to the increasingly well understood repertoire of mutations in coding sequences of oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, genome-wide sequencing of human cancers has revealed abundant mutations in non-coding sequences. Most of these mutations are expected to be neutral, i.e., passengers, with only a small percentage having a functional impact, so identifying bona fide oncogenic mutations within this large background of neutral ones is an important challenge. In this project we seek to address this challenge in a common and difficult to treat human cancer, multiple myeloma, using a mechanism-based genetic-epigenetic mapping strategy, followed by functional assays on the resulting candidate oncogenic non-coding mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma and allergic diseases are among the most common chronic diseases in children and adults, yet therapeutic advances have been incremental. We propose here a highly integrated program to discover and define functions for causal variants and causal genes associated with asthma and allergic diseases, with a focus on variants and genes that impart risk through their effects on lung-resident cells and are promising therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is the most common chronic illness of childhood, and low lung function in childhood is associated with worse lung health throughout adult life. This project will identify the harmful and protective effects of early pregnancy and early childhood exposure to a mixture of metals on children’s sensitivity to allergens, risk of asthma, and lung function. The results from this research will advance our understanding of the role of early life metal exposure in shaping children’s respiratory health through effects on immune function, informing future public health actions to improve respiratory health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After common neurological injuries like stroke, spinal cord injury, and traumatic brain injury, restoring walking ability and functional independence are some of the most important and challenging goals of physical rehabilitation. A drawback of many gait retraining approaches is that patients can quickly accommodate to physical assistance, causing them to lose sensorimotor engagement, which in turn impedes neuroplasticity and progress towards functional goals. The proposed work aims to enhance engagement and motor learning during gait retraining by harnessing positive social pressures; this will make physically assisted rehabilitation more effective, and in the long term, improve quality of life after neurological injury by stabilizing fall risks and reducing comorbid conditions and medical costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative HSV-1 causes eye disease and can lead to blindness. Our data indicate that HSV-1 glycoprotein K (gK) binds to signal peptide peptidase (SPP) and UL20, while UL20 binds to Golgi-specific DHHC zinc finger protein (GODZ). The absence of SPP or GODZ affect HSV-1 infectivity in vitro and in vivo. We will use several approaches to determine if blocking these interactions reduces virus replication in the eye as well as latency- reactivation hence, the occurrence of reactivation and eye disease. Our studies are expected to provide a novel therapeutic strategy to control vision loss from HSV-1 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The gastrointestinal side effects of chemotherapy are estimated to affect as high as 70% of patients receiving treatment. There are currently no available therapies to prevent these debilitating gastrointestinal side effects. The main goal of these studies is to employ translationally relevant mouse models to better understand the pathways that drive intestinal plasticity and healing to resist chemotherapy-related intestinal injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Factors like maternal obesity and exercise during pregnancy can impact the health of offspring at birth and later in life; little is known about which types of maternal exercise is most beneficial to mother and child, when attempting to break the intergenerational cycle of obesity and metabolic disorders. This study will assess outcomes, for mothers and infants, of three different types of exercise interventions (aerobic, resistance, and combined), comparing expectant mothers with overweight/obesity to a control group. By taking key measurements throughout pregnancy and up to 12 months after delivery, this study will provide insight into the most beneficial mode of maternal exercise for the target population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microneedles facilitate drug delivery by forming micropores in the skin. Variability in micropore closure times in diverse skin types may reduce efficacy of this drug delivery approach. In this project we will 1) determine the impact of micropore closure times on delivery of a model drug through the skin, and 2) explore the role of dopamine signaling in microwound closure timeframes in diverse skin types. The overall goal is to identify a possible pharmaceutical target for delaying micropore closure and improving microneedle assisted transdermal drug delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lung cancer is the deadliest malignancy worldwide, and recent patient data confirm the importance of the Nrf2 pathway in this disease, as up to 30% of human lung adenocarcinomas have a mutation that activates this pathway. While Nrf2 activation in tumor cells can promote tumor cell survival, preclinical studies show anti-tumor effects with drugs that activate Nrf2. These studies will identify the immunomodulatory effects of Nrf2 activation in the microenvironment of the lung and help determine whether pharmacological Nrf2 activation could be beneficial for the treatment of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the role of endolysosomal pathways in the formation of neurotoxic axonal misfolded prion protein aggregates is expected to provide a framework on which to develop novel pharmacological strategies for the treatment of prionopathies. Thus, elucidation of the composition, ultrastructure, and mechanism of formation of axonal prion protein aggregates is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that promotes the understanding of basic cell biological principles as a basis for protecting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Brucellosis is one of the world’s most frequent zoonotic diseases with over 500,000 new human infections every year. This proposal defines the pathways of innate immune activation or inhibition by Brucella abortus strain 19 vaccine. Identifying the mechanisms of activation or inhibition of innate immune responses used by strain 19 will determine the issues with the current vaccine and suggest changes to enhance its efficacy and disease control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because timely, effective care for respiratory failure saves lives. Hispanic patients are twice as likely as other patients to die from respiratory failure, yet the existing literature does not identify how to address this critical problem. This proposal meets an urgent need to detect, understand, and eliminate modifiable contributors to inequities in respiratory failure by ethnicity through rigorous patient and clinician cohort research and development of stakeholder-centered interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Sleep is a conserved and essential behavior, whose function remains unclear. Disorders of sleep are common and important causes of human morbidity. This proposal seeks to gain a deeper understanding of the regulation and function of sleep, in order to improve the treatment of dysregulated sleep and address a scientific question of paramount importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in genomics have exposed our inability to functionally characterize genetic variants that associate with sudden cardiac death risk, leaving excessive variants of unknown significance (VUS). We will use Deep Mutational Scanning as a mechanism to uncover all functional genetic variants in a potassium channel and link this data with TOPMed and UK BioBank databases. This is an innovative proactive, data-driven approach, that will establish actionable data usable by clinicians and research teams alike.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Overall Core Project Narrative As the Region 1 RML for the 2021-2026 Cooperative Agreement, the University of Maryland, Baltimore (UMB) proposes an ambitious program that includes social justice, health and digital equity, environmental health, and cultural humility topics in all training, funding and engagement opportunities for NNLM members. Done in tandem with responsive health, data, and digital literacy programming, the reach and impact of the National Library of Medicine (NLM) expands for all populations and audiences and advances the mission of the Network of the National Library of Medicine (NNLM). Thinking nationally and acting regionally, the RML Team integrates the latest evidence-based research and replicable community-driven health outreach programs to improve health and digital equity, integrating principles of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI) in all activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney function is typically estimated using serum creatinine, although this may be less reliable at the extremes of muscle mass; Dr. Potok’s preliminary work demonstrated that the difference in estimated glomerular filtration rate by cystatin C (eGFRCys) vs. creatinine (eGFRCr) holds information on functional status, frailty, and risk of death in older adults. The objective of this proposal is to determine the clinical applications of this difference (eGFRDiff = eGFRCys – eGFRCr), in terms of both prognosis and treatment. Results from this study will provide arguments to change nephrologists’ behavior regarding referral for dialysis preparation, and to change which marker between serum creatinine and cystatin C should be trusted to estimate kidney function when dosing medications.

PHR: NARRATIVE Clinical trials are a critical step in translating discoveries into better treatments for people burdened by cardiac disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Biomedical Relevance Food allergies are a risk factor for asthma, and the natural history of allergic diseases suggests immunological crosstalk between mucosal organs contributes to the co-occurrences of allergic diseases within the same individual, although the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underly this process have not been defined. Building on our novel data demonstrating that dysregulation of lung tissue eosinophils is associated with allergic priming of the airways following allergen ingestion, this proposal will flesh out the mechanisms of the gut-lung crosstalk that dysregulates lung eosinophils and exacerbate allergic susceptibility of remote airways. Completion of this proposal may offer important insights into the mechanisms that drive mucosal organ crosstalk and as such is highly relevant to the development of better diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for patients with allergic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The NA-ACCORD is the most wide-ranging and in-depth collaboration of HIV cohorts that exists within North America. Its large sample size, the comprehensiveness and quality of its data, combined with the expert use of state-of-the-art statistical methods will allow us to provide answers to the most pressing questions of contemporary importance for the care and outcomes of people with HIV in the US and Canada. The questions will inform the End the HIV Epidemic initiative and provide important information on the long-term course of HIV disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Overdiagnosis of thyroid cancer is a significant problem that compromises patients’ quality of life, leading to overtreatment, exposure to unnecessary risk, and high medical costs. The objective of this research is to identify factors that predispose people to being diagnosed with thyroid cancer that would never cause symptoms or death if undetected, so the healthcare system can instead focus resources on thyroid cancers that would result in morbidity if untreated. Results of the model will help to inform clinical practice guidelines and referral practice recommendations to improve the quality of health care while reducing inappropriate testing, to minimize overdiagnosis and overtreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Electrical signaling in myelinated axons requires ion channel clustering at axon initial segments (AIS) and nodes of Ranvier, and a robust axonal cytoskeleton. However, the molecular mechanisms regulating the functional organization of axons remain poorly understood. Here, we will use discovery proteomics and rigorous analysis of strategically designed genetic mouse models to discover these mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While we have identified many disrupted genes that lead to retinal diseases, we often do not know how they cause the disease phenotypes. Understanding how a pathogenic mutation leads to disease is extremely important for prognosis, for developing effective treatments and for assessing likely response to treatment. In this application we focus on understanding the molecules/pathways that are activated or suppressed to lead to photoreceptor degeneration, hyperopia and fundus spotting phenotypes; phenotypes found in many genetic retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project will investigate how obesity, a worldwide epidemic, promotes colonic tumorigenesis by stimulating LD dynamics reinforced through elevated acyltransferases (DGATs). It will demonstrate that targeting DGATs shuts down the regulatory mechanisms driving LDs growth and utilization, thereby attenuating obesity driven colonic tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because insights into the specific molecular mechanisms that control prostate cancer (CaP) progression are ultimately expected to provide the foundation to develop novel treatment options that are tailored to the events that underlie the lethal phenotype of CaP, a malignancy that causes more than 30,000 deaths annually in the US. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of an effective HIV vaccine remains a major challenge. The current proposal seeks to develop HIV envelope broadly neutralizing antibody (bnAb) B cell lineage-based vaccine strategy to induce protective bnAb responses by vaccination. An effective vaccine could be a powerful intervention to prevent new HIV infections, and thus the application is highly relevant to human health and welfare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Residents in our nation’s public housing developments live in conditions of concentrated poverty, unhealthy and unstable housing and community contexts, and weak social and economic opportunities, all key social determinants of poor health. This mixed-methods study exploits a multi-arm natural experiment of public housing redevelopment to evaluate whether improving housing quality, limiting external displacement and creating mixed-income communities improve the physical, mental, and behavioral health of public housing residents. Results will provide key insights into burgeoning economic health disparities, and inform policies and practices targeting our most disadvantaged neighborhoods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this project is to establish and refine the association of genetic polymorphism of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex with a wide variety of health traits and immune markers in a cohort of unprecedented size. Central to immunity and critically important for human health, HLA molecules are encoded by complex genetic systems with extraordinarily high levels of sequence and structural variation and complex expression patterns that has been linked to hundreds of diseases. We will leverage the wealth of existing genetic data collected by the National Marrow Donor Program (NMDP) to examine these associations in fine detail in hundreds of thousands of individuals in order to improve our understanding of the role of HLA in human health and immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: BubR1 is a key regulator of genomic integrity through controlling the spindle assembly checkpoint and also suppresses the process of cellular senescence, thus it is a key factor regulating the interrelationship between cellular stress, cancer, and aging. Protein levels of BubR1 are lost following cell stress such as glucose deprivation and decline naturally during the aging process in a wide variety of tissues, which can be reversed by preventing its ubiquitin-mediated degradation by the deacetylase SIRT2, however the molecular mechanisms promoting ubiquitination of BubR1 during stress and with age remain elusive. In this proposal we will define the role of the E3 ubiquitin ligase SCF-TRCP1 in promoting BubR1 degradation under these conditions, which will provide the impetus to target BubR1 stabilization as a therapeutic strategy against age- related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance  The investigation to be conducted through the present research strategy aims to establish the histopathologic and pathophysiologic correlates of vestibular hypofunction induced by the common ototoxin, gentamicin. The primary objective is to determine the physiologic signatures of the functional decrements providing insight into strategies through which these conditions can be identified in suspected patients. The histopathologic correlates will identify the cellular components of the inner ear vestibular epithelia that are associated with these deficits and, therefore, potential targets of protective and rehabilitative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project focuses on carpometacarpal osteoarthritis (CMC OA), a painful degenerative disease that severely limits thumb function. The structure and function of thumb muscles and how those muscles influence the primary symptoms of CMC OA (pain and joint instability) will be examined. The results will enhance our understanding of the complex relationship between muscles, disease severity, and symptom severity, while also informing clinical interventions to improve the quality of life for individuals with CMC OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Telomeres are closely involved in stem cell differentiation and cancer cell proliferation. The results of this study will lead to new mechanistic principles of telomere length homeostasis and chromosome stability in cells. Therefore, valuable targets for mechanism-driven design of anti-premature aging and cancer therapeutics may be identified through this research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Differentiation is a fundamental process evident in a variety of cell states and transitions. Differentiation is a common feature in tumors, which is most pronounced in colorectal cancer, a vexing health problem. We seek to elucidate how LIN28B, an mRNA binding protein, fosters differentiation in colorectal cancers and concurrently, promote metastasis in this differentiated state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Clostridioides difficile is a toxin-producing bacterium that is a frequent cause of hospital-acquired and antibiotic-associated diarrhea. The United States Centers for Disease Control reports that in 2017, there were 223,900 estimated cases of C. difficile infection (CDI) in hospitalized patients with an estimated 12,800 deaths in the United States. This project will define the mechanism of how the toxin engages receptor proteins on the host cell surface and thus, provide a framework for advancing novel therapeutic and CDI prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction is closely associated with obesity, with no treatment known to decrease cardiovascular mortality. Bariatric surgery is a promising treatment for obesity-associated heart failure with post-operative improvements in heart function. This project will lead to an understanding of how bariatric surgery improves heart function in patients with obesity-related heart failure and lead to the development of new surgical and non-surgical therapies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A subset of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) patients will relapse and succumb to treatment- resistant disease. We found that B-ALL remodels the microenvironment around the leukemia to alter monocyte differentiation, with a subpopulation of nonclassical monocytes that both predicts pediatric and adult B-ALL patient survival and supports B-ALL progression and treatment evasion. The goal of this project is to determine the precise function of leukemia-associated nonclassical monocytes in supporting B-ALL survival and establish new immune-based therapeutic approaches that improve the efficacy of conventional B-ALL therapies, which reflects the public health relevance of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE While conventionally seen as restricted to axon initial segments, recent evidence has implicated Ankyrin-G and Ankyrin-B in the biology of central nervous system glutamatergic synapses. However, little is known about their postsynaptic roles. Here, building on our progress made during the previous funding period, we will investigate the functions of ankyrins and their protein partners at cortical glutamatergic synapses, cortical circuits, and behaviors controlled by the frontal cortex.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unlike mammals, zebrafish possess the ability to regenerate entire appendages following traumatic injury, such as amputation, and these regenerated appendages faithfully recapitulate the size and shape of the original appendage. How size and shape are encoded during appendage regeneration in unclear, in part because there is an incomplete dynamic and quantitative understanding of the cellular events that underlie regeneration. This proposal will quantitatively define the dynamic molecular and cellular events that promote zebrafish appendage regeneration and uncover molecular events that are potential therapeutic targets for enhancing appendage regeneration in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop bone scaffolds that are biomimetically mineralized on the nanoscale and both vascularized and innervated prior to implantation. Several aspects that are of central importance to the success of developing bone scaffolds with close similarities to natural bone will be addressed, including the conditions required to induce osteogenesis in cell-loaded bone-like hydrogels, and the optimal conditions at which bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells differentiate into pericyte-like cells to form mature vascular capillaries and neuronal networks. We contend that the results of this project will enable development of regenerative strategies with improved clinical outcomes for bone augmentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal behavior is impaired under conditions of chronic stress and/or adversity as well as in postpartum mood disorders. This application will examine the impact of postpartum adversity (as modeled through environmental resource depletion) on motivated maternal behaviors and mesolimbic dopamine function in the rat dam by employing an integrated approach (e.g. environmental perturbation, behavior, in vivo electrophysiology, optical recordings of genetically identified cells via the use of transgenic animals and in vivo fiber photometry, circuit- specific manipulations using DREADDs). In this way, I hope to provide insights into mesolimbic DA mechanisms contributing to adversity-induced alterations in mother-infant attachment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE The HIV epidemic in U.S. women disproportionately affects women of color; 61% of HIV-infected women are African-American and 19% are Hispanic/Latina; the population is also rapidly aging, with 70% of U.S. HIV patients predicted to be ≥50 years by 2030. Women and older patients may be at increased risk of adverse events, at least partly due to differences in drug clearance. This study aims to quantify these differences, using MACS/WIHS Combined Cohort Study participants receiving integrase-inhibitor or tenofovir alafenamide-based antiretroviral regimens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative While MRI is the most effective tool for assessing neonatal brain disease and injury, the size and siting constraints of conventional scanners requires the transfer of patients to a centralized radiology suite for imaging. For unstable newborns with brain injury, there are significant risks associated with this transfer that often preclude MRI imaging. Our goal is to address this with a novel, newborn-sized brain MRI scanner designed for operation at the bedside in neonatal ICUs with minimal patient disturbance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A critical barrier to controlling tuberculosis (TB) is the estimated 40% of TB cases who remain undiagnosed, infectious, often without TB symptoms (subclinical) fueling TB transmission. Finding these missing TB cases is challenging and necessary for halting transmission in the fight against TB. We propose to determine whether missing cases could be effectively and efficiently found in areas where TB transmission is concentrated, using innovative spatial and pathogen transmission modeling and use of novel diagnostics to detect infectious forms of TB that include subclinical TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Age-related dementia is a significant and growing burden on our society – the most well known of which is Alzheimer's disease (AD) – and chronic sleep disruption is a pervasive feature of contemporary life that is associated with and exacerbated in AD. This project will examine the idea that sleep quality is more important than sleep quantity, and will investigate the underlying biological mechanisms of this process, as well as explore novel strategies for improving sleep and treating deleterious inflammation in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection affects more than 250 million people worldwide and is a significant health problem because it substantially increases the risk for developing serious liver diseases such as cirrhosis and cancer. New therapeutic approaches for HBV that improve antiviral immunity hold substantial promise for controlling this infection. The goal of the proposed research is to understand the mechanisms of immunological dysfunction that must be successfully overcome to cure chronic HBV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to enhance the potency of adoptive T cell immunotherapies and chimeric antigen receptor T cells (CART) against cancer by removing a key inhibitory factor, CD5, from T-cells. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because CART immunotherapy, despite being now routine clinical practice, still fails in a significant subset of patients. The project is relevant to those parts of the NCI’s mission that pertain to the treatment of cancer, and the advancement of scientific knowledge and help all people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We focus on highly characterized bacterial RNA polymerases, which have a high degree of conservation of structure and function from bacteria to man. The bacterial RNA polymerase is a proven target for antimicrobials, such as rifampicin (or its derivatives), widely used in combination therapy to treat tuberculosis, but bacterial strains resistant to rifampicin arise with appreciable frequency, compromising treatment. Insights into the mechanism of bacterial transcription, as well as into the inhibition mechanism of inhibitors, can lead to new avenues for the development of antimicrobials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is currently a shortage of medical student trainees who are entering into careers in academic medicine as physician-scientists; furthermore, diversity in the pool of physician-scientist pathway trainees fails to reflect the diversity of our communities. This training program entitled “Medical Student Summer Research Program in Infection and Immunity” aims to augment medical research-training opportunities and mentorship for a diverse pool of medical students at the University of Minnesota Medical School by taking advantage of the strength of our immunological sciences. With success in this effort, an increased and more diverse proportion of our medical student population will enter into physician-scientist training pathway residency programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This application is responsive to the 2015 AD Summit recommendation to “elucidate the short- and long-term consequences of disrupted and optimized sleep on brain aging and AD.” Sleep and circadian rhythm disturbances are common in elderly persons with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and dementia, including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). This proposed K23 award will support a research career to examine cross-sectionally and longitudinally the association of poor sleep and disrupted circadian rhythms with cognitive diagnoses, including normal cognition, cognitive impairment without MCI, amnestic MCI single domain, amnestic MCI multiple domain, and ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Untreated cases of early childhood caries (ECC) may expose a child to pain, potentially life- threating infection, failure to thrive, learning difficulties, among several other problems. Building upon the rigor of our prior research, we propose a Stage II research according to the NIH Stage Model that will compare the efficacy of videotaped autonomy-supportive oral health messages framed by the self-determination theory (SDT) to more traditional neutral videotaped messages among mother-child dyads enrolled in Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC) programs located in a rural population with large Hispanic and African American minorities. It is hoped that, in the future, our autonomy-supportive messages can (1) be used in numerous settings (i.e. public health clinics, hospitals, medical/dental offices); (2) be disseminated through the social media (i.e. Facebook) and website (i.e. YouTube); (3) increase access to early dental prevention at low-cost targeted especially for high-caries risk minority groups; (4) break the walls of language barrier by narrating the messages in all desirable languages; and (5) be used later on by other researchers and clinicians as an additional tool to their strategies to prevent ECC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE Testing for antinuclear antibodies (ANA) is a common practice to screen for systemic lupus erythematosus, since the test is almost always positive in lupus even years before the disease onset. However, a large proportion of people without autoimmune disease also have a positive ANA test, and it is not known whether a positive test increases the risk for other adverse outcomes. This project aims (a) to discriminate who is at high risk for lupus from among individuals with a positive ANA test and (b) to define the risk for positive ANA individuals without an autoimmune disease in order to provide better health care advice and improve the care of lupus patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  The overall goal of this research is to develop innovative approaches for overcoming drug resistance in cancer therapy. Developing nanomedicines by subcellular enzyme-instructed self-assembly (sEISA) to selectively kill cancer cells and to overcome the drug resistance, this approach will ultimately lead to a new cancer therapy for millions of people who will need anticancer treatment in the future, and thus improving health of the Nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Narrative This research will increase understanding of factors maintaining AUD and PTSD among veterans, an important public health concern. It will advance knowledge of regulatory processes underlying comorbid AUD and PTSD and associated problems with interpersonal functioning (e.g., violence). Whereas previous research has studied emotional and behavioral dysregulation as person-level correlates of PTSD and AUD, this study shifts the focus to advance knowledge of the temporal dynamics of these processes to identify time-varying precursors of health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Epidermal stem/progenitor cells of the adult skin are highly active and their response to normal and injury-generated signals is essential for organismal survival. Although it is a rapidly developing area of research, the heterogeneity, hierarchical lineage relationship, and the spatial distribution of diverse epidermal stem/progenitor cell populations in the mouse and human skin are poorly understood. Our laboratory has identified heterogeneity of the basal skin cells, containing stem/progenitor cells, and suggested a spatial patterning of distinct stem cell distribution that has the potential to advance our understanding in the area of human skin regeneration and wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: 8. Public Health Relevance.  Interneuronal connection in the nervous system is essential for the proper function of the brain. Cognitive deficits in many psychiatric disorders arise from disruptions in neural connectivity, including disruptions within sensory circuits. The proposed study investigates the role of intercortical neuronal connections in in regulating sensory information processing and perceptual experience. Results from this study will reveal how brain function can deteriorate because of disruptions in the normal connection patterns among neurons. This information is important to provide deep understanding of normal and pathological function of the nervous systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The premise of this proposal is that an optimal early detection strategy to identify clinically relevant prostate cancer will involve a two-tiered algorithm that leverages inherited genetic information to determine who is at risk for prostate cancer followed by MRI imaging to determine which of these high risk patients has clinically relevant disease. We propose to test this premise by implementing a polygenic risk score in men and conducting a prospective trial among 1,500 men with MRI to prove the two-tiered algorithm works.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The primary objective of this new K12 Mentored Research Career Development Program at the Indiana Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute is to provide a diverse group of early career faculty Scholars intensive mentored career development experiences that lead to research independence and prepare them for leadership positions in clinical and translational science. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is an irreversible neurodegenerative disorder that affects over 35 million people worldwide and is the fifth leading cause of death in the elderly. Currently, limited clinical interventions are available, and as such, there is an urgent need to further our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that underlie AD, and in turn, to utilize these findings to develop novel therapeutic approaches. In line with these goals, the work proposed here explores an understudied and potentially critical connection between dysregulation of the circadian timing system and the cognitive deficits that are a defining feature of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative In the current proposal, we will examine whether adults from Black, Indigenous and Persons of Color communities, who have been and are still impacted by health disparities, increase their use of two or more substances (cigarettes, e-cigarettes, marijuana and/or alcohol) when they experience discrimination. Using daily questionnaires via a smartphone application, we will study in real-time the specific factors that influence substance use by these adults to cope with discrimination-related stress. Our results will reveal the burden of daily discrimination on addiction and the aspects of cultural resilience that can reduce this burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The goals of this proposal are to 1) compare immune responses to two of the most promising contemporary HIV vaccination strategies (SOSIP trimer and mRNA) using highly relevant infant and adolescent nonhuman primate models, and 2) define strategies that harness unique aspects of infant immune development to produce protective anti-HIV immune responses, such as broad neutralizing antibodies. This work has strong potential to identify the age group that should be targeted future human clinical vaccine trials in order to provide HIV protection prior to adolescence and provide insight into immune and microbial factors relevant to vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal addresses a significant clinical problem of rhinovirus-mediated exacerbation of asthma. By assembling a multidisciplinary team of scientists, we propose to study a new mechanism of lung defense against rhinoviruses in airways of asthma patients. Our research findings obtained from the state-of-the-art experiments will significantly improve our understanding about host defense mechanisms against rhinovirus infection, and likely provide a new opportunity to treat rhinovirus infection in patients with asthma and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 5.7 million Americans have dementia, but treatments to prevent, cure, or slow dementia progression are lacking. Recent research suggests a link between obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and incident dementia, but this relationship and the potential protective effect of OSA treatment on dementia risk have been insufficiently studied. This study will utilize longitudinal data from a nationally representative, multi-ethnic longitudinal cohort study of older adults, linked with Medicare claims datasets, to examine pathways between OSA, OSA treatment and cognitive decline among women and men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the use of state-of-the-art supportive care and a variety of novel anti-inflammatory agents in critically ill/injured patients, multiple organ failure continues to be a major cause of morbidity/mortality in the surgical intensive care unit. This study is designed to determine if a family of novel checkpoint proteins, expressed on immune and non-immune cells, can be used to block the development of organ injury in the critically ill patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent research demonstrates a novel role for midbrain dopamine neurons in model-based learning. Here, we will reveal the model-based function of two non-canonical dopamine circuits, filling gaps in the knowledge of the particular dopamine circuits that are necessary for this model-based decision making. Given substance use disorders (SUDs) are characterized by ill-informed decisions that lack consideration of future consequences, the very essence of model-based decision making, in the longer term this work could lead to novel targets for treating pathological decision making present in SUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a cell layer at the back of the eye, is essential for retinal function and normal vision and disruptions of the RPE underlie many heritable retinal diseases and age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in aging western populations. The proposed project will identify therapeutic targets by elucidating pathological pathways disrupted in mouse models of the human disease butterfly macular dystrophy, which shares phenotypic characteristics with a broader range of human RPE-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to understand the molecular mechanisms controlling mRNA decapping, the penultimate, irreversible step committing an mRNA to destruction. The expression of thousands of human genes is regulated by the coordinated destruction of messenger RNA which is thought to occur in biological condensates called mRNA processing bodies (P-bodies). The biochemical and structural details provided by this work may pave the way to treat intellectual disability or cancer. More broadly, like mRNA decay, numerous additional biochemical pathways are organized in biological condensates, and the principles of how condensation affects active site geometry are poorly understood. Our proposal will shed light on how the formation of a biological condensate affects enzyme conformation, a critical but poorly understood parameter for the discovery and design of therapies that target enzymes in condensates that are dysregulated during human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - RELEVANCE This project will provide information about the role of early Extrafollicular plasmablast response in the development of protective B and T cell response to Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite that causes Chagas disease. This initial response of B cells, that start outside the B-cell follicle, responsible of first wave of antibodies and able to produce cytokines and to function as antigen-presenting cell could be key in the outcome of the infection. Results will be of great significance for the identification of new targets aimed at enhancing protective immunity in Chagas disease and other chronic infections which course with strong polyclonal B cell activation and early Extrafollicular plasmablast response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is associated with increased colorectal cancer incidence and mortality, in part by activation of the Wnt signaling pathway. However, efforts to therapeutically target Wnt signaling have been unsuccessful in the vast majority of colorectal cancers. We found that specific components of the Wnt signaling pathway are highly upregulated in high fat diet-induced obesity, and therefore hypothesize that disrupting this mechanism of Wnt activation will successful treat obesity-associated colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Mammals hear when the highly-organized organ of Corti vibrates in response to sound pressure waves and stimulates hair cells. Herein, we propose image these vibrations non-invasively and understand how these structures work together to create high auditory sensitivity and sharp frequency tuning. This question remains unsolved and is clinically important because while hearing aids can compensate for the loss of sensitivity, we have no treatments for the loss of frequency tuning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of kidney dysfunction in cirrhosis patients continues to increase; however, the tools we employ to identify a patient’s risk for acute kidney injury are limited. This proposal—through the use of a large longitudinal cohort and novel biomarkers—aims to earlier identify cirrhosis patients at risk for AKI in an effort to implement preventative strategies and reduce kidney-related morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a clear association between the neutralization sensitivity of virus and how effective bNAbs are in suppressing virus replication during clinical trials; however, there are two main obstacles that limit the use of this assay: length of assay time and difficulty in obtaining the correct samples to test. We propose an ultra-sensitive Env binding assay whose results will correlate to neutralization assay results but will take hours, and that can directly measure translationally competent virus directly in cells lysates, increasing the sampling depth. Our multi- disciplinary team has all the expertise necessary to achieve these aims that, when completed, result in an ultra- sensitive binding assay for Env protein to screen clinical trial participants that is time efficient, accurate and qualified.
