IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) is a cancer-causing human retrovirus that infects about 15-20 million individuals worldwide. While virus particle assembly at cell-cell contacts are required for efficient virus transmission (both within and between individuals), many fundamental aspects involved in this critical mode of virus spread are poorly understood, including the nature of virus spread and particle morphology of released particles. Development of experimental workflows to enable new cutting-edge technologies will improve understanding of this distinct mode of virus transmission, which has broad relevance to other viruses capable of spread via cell-cell contacts – including transmission events

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Blood flow in brain of Alzheimer’s disease mice and patients is reduced relative to healthy counterparts. In Alzheimer’s disease mice, increasing brain blood flow leads to rapid improvements in memory performance. This grant examines the changes in brain tissue oxygenation, cellular metabolism, and neural activity that underlie improved performance on short term memory tasks observed after increasing cerebral blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Vibrio cholerae is an important human pathogen whose curved cell shape is important for its pathogenesis, and we previously identified the first two curvature determinants in Vibrio cholerae, CrvA and CrvB. CrvA and CrvB assemble in the cell periplasm into a higher-order structure that promotes curvature; here we propose to determine how CrvA and CrvB assemble with one another, how they interact with the cell wall and other factors to curve V. cholerae, and how curved shapes affect important bacterial behaviors like motility, biofilm interactions, and surface interactions. Together these studies will provide fundamental new insights into how bacterial proteins form copolymers, how periplasmic structures assemble, how curved cell shapes are generated, and the selective benefits that such shapes confer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing aging population increasingly requires major surgery, often resulting in serious complications, functional impairment, cognitive decline, increases in healthcare utilization and death, which are all major public health burdens. Improving perioperative practices to care for this vulnerable, complex population can reduce this burden. The proposed work will utilize a novel approach to surgical care of older adults, applying systems engineering and implementation science principles to develop an implementation package for preoperative geriatric assessments that can be adapted and applied to a wide range of hospitals, serving a diverse population of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal seeks to identify changes in the brain that are lead to the development of pain, urinary urgency, and comorbid anxiety and depression that are very often observed in patients with interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS). IC/BPS is a serious and painful condition that affects 3-6% of women in the United States. Understanding alterations in brain circuits can help us to design new treatments for IC/BPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to expand the benefits of ocular gene therapy for RPE65-associated LCA by using a non-viral gene therapy platform to ensure long-term, physiologically-relevant levels of gene expression. Our platform enables sustained, controlled delivery of the entire therapeutic gene (including regulatory elements). We will validate this platform in RPE65-/- model of LCA, making these studies highly translationally relevant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Aneurysms are an often asymptomatic, pathological, progressive ballooning of a blood vessel and are life-threatening when present in the aorta, the largest artery in the human body. The underlying cause (e.g., connective tissue disorders) and location (i.e., thoracic or abdominal) of aortic aneurysms are diverse, and interventional surgical repairs are complicated and not without adverse events. Therefore, we are developing a universal, non-invasive, systemic, injectable therapy that targets aneurysms with nanoparticles capable of delivering drugs that regress and repair the diseased tissue to obviate surgical intervention and improve the quality of life for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative This project will delineate the cellular mechanisms by which chromosomal rearrangements are formed during the cell cycle by testing the hypothesis that recently discovered modes of DNA replication and repair active in mitosis are responsible for creating many new variant junctions. It will initially focus on fragile loci in the human genome and extend results to the whole genome in cancer relevant mutants. Outcomes will be relevant to public health and NIH's mission by contributing to fundamental knowledge about the mechanisms and stresses that preserve and alter human genetic information, which are the underlying causes of many human genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney transplantation provides the best survival and quality of life for patients with kidney failure, but there is a shortage of kidneys available for transplantation in the United States. This organ shortage necessitates the use of some deceased donor kidneys with less-than-ideal characteristics, and the safe use of these kidneys requires accurate and reliable assessments of organ quality; however, the current presentation of clinical data leads to suboptimal decision making that discourages the use of transplantable marginal kidneys. This project aims to use decision making science to improve the way that this data is presented, starting with deceased donor kidney biopsy results, in order to improve the utilization of kidneys from the expanded donor and organ pool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis, associated fragility fracture, and type 2 diabetes (T2D) are major public health problems that disproportionately influence older Hispanic/Latino (H/L) populations. Using the integrative analysis of genetic and transcriptomic findings, the proposed study will identify causal pathways between T2D and metabolic risk and skeletal health among Mexican Americans, an understudied population. This study will offer better insights into skeletal health disparities in older H/L adults at risk for T2D to develop targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people suffer from loss of muscle protein that causes substantial health risks, including fractures and metabolic disease, but pharmacological therapies are not currently available to effectively mitigate muscle atrophy without rendering substantial side effects. Adipose tissue is an endocrine organ that responds to energetic challenges by secreting signaling proteins, which play critical roles in systemic energy metabolism and can be developed into therapeutic targets for treating metabolic diseases. This proposal aims to establish a novel mechanism of adipose-muscle crosstalk mediated by a hormone that promotes protein synthesis that has potential future therapeutic implications as a treatment for muscle atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease continues to take more human lives than all cancer combined, prompting the need for improved research models and treatment options. We propose to study the patient- specific vascularized model of adult human myocardium, in the context of ischemic injury and acute viral myocarditis. This work is designed to advance our understanding and treatment of two forms of heart disease, which differentially affect males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Teenagers are universally short on sleep, and sleep loss contributes to a host of health issues, including alcohol use disorders. The impact of adolescent circadian disruption on sleep and stress, and resultant changes in alcohol seeking, will be examined in this proposal. Our goal is to determine whether circadian rhythm sleep disorders in adolescence drive immediate or later alcohol seeking by increasing sleep disruption and stress, and whether strategies should be targeted to improving rhythmicity or sleep itself to reduce alcohol use disorder in adolescence and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating intestinal problem that often requires surgical resection of necrotic intestine. In this proposal, we utilize a novel hydrogen sulfide probe in conjunction with iPSC derived mesenchymal stem cells to study the hypothesis that hydrogen sulfide is a critical paracrine factor in stem cell mediated intestinal protection. A novel mouse with a mutation on endothelial nitric oxide synthase will also be used to study the ability of hydrogen sulfide to augment nitric oxide mediated mesenteric vasodilation.

PHR: Project Narrative The work proposed here seeks to elucidate how opportunistic bacteria evolve and adapt to multiple environments, what traits are important for different environments, and how often traits are exapted. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative A decline in mitochondrial function occurs during aging, which is accelerated in age-associated diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease and Parkinson’s Disease. Thus, understanding how cells establish a mitochondrial network during development and adjust that network throughout a cell’s lifetime to meet physiological needs is a necessary step to develop therapies that treat mitochondrial dysfunction and associated diseases. Here, we aim to understand the mechanisms by which the Integrated Stress Response regulates mitochondrial expansion and stress signaling to promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Perioperative neurocognitive disorders (PND) – including postoperative delirium, delayed neurocognitive recovery, and postoperative neurocognitive disorders – are associated with increased morbidity and mortality, high costs of medical care, and Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD). However, blood biomarkers and pathogenesis of PND remain largely to be determined. The proposed research will use a newly developed and innovative nanoneedle technology to establish a system which could identify blood phosphorylated tau (e.g., Tau-PT217 and Tau-PT181) as biomarkers and pathogenesis of PND, consistent with the mission of NIH/NIA to prevent AD/ADRD by delaying the onset and slowing the progression of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer stem cells drive continued tumor growth and are likely less responsive to therapy, retained in tumors to cause relapse, and may be responsible for metastatic spread in a subset of cancers. Here, we will identify heterogeneous cell populations that drive these processes in fusion-negative pediatric rhabdomyosarcoma muscle cancer. Our work will also uncover new mechanisms and therapeutic targets that govern rhabdomyosarcoma cancer stem cell self-renewal, cell state changes, and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular sphingolipid metabolism and their metabolic enzymes are significantly altered in metastatic diseases. The sphingolipid enzyme ceramide kinase (CERK) is prominently associated with cancer. The proposed study will test the hypothesis that nuclear bioactive lipid ceramide-1-phosphate (C1P) and synthesizing enzyme CERK play a critical role in aggressive breast cancers. The knowledge gain ed from this study will be critical for the development of new therapeutics against metastatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Early diagnosis of diabetic eye disease is an important public health initiative as it is the leading cause of preventable vision loss in working aged Americans. It is known that color vision is altered in diabetes, but it is not known if color differences vary across the eye, change with retinopathy development, are correlated with other early diabetes tests, or even exactly which color channels and cells are definitively involved. The study will further develop a novel technique to evaluate color changes at different locations within the eye and will use this technique in patients with and without diabetes and prediabetes to learn more about ocular changes in this disease process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (ACM) is a disease characterized by progressive fibrofatty replacement of the myocardium, arrhythmias, and sudden death. The mechanisms associated to fibrofatty myocardial infiltration need to be investigated to uncover therapeutic targets to improve ACM clinical management. Here we propose to develop a fibrofatty 3D model engineered cardiac tissue (EngCT), which will provide a system to study the pathogenesis of cardiac fibrofatty infiltration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Human genomes harbor significant variation within and between individual tissues, referred to as somatic mosaicism. Investigations into this phenomenon have been mostly limited to higher frequency mosaicism and certain variant types (SNVs, large deletions) due to technical limitations in both molecular assays and computational methodology. This proposal seeks to overcome these limitations by developing and deploying innovative sequencing technologies and computational approaches to identify somatic variation across the frequency spectrum for multiple variant types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deprescribing (i.e., discontinuing or de-intensifying) medications with reduced benefits and increased harms is a priority for older adults (OAs) with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), who face a high medication burden and increased vulnerability to adverse drug reactions. Aspirin for primary or secondary cardiovascular prevention has been proposed as a possible target medication that may be safely discontinued, but there is little evidence about the impact of discontinuing aspirin on health outcomes in OAs with ADRD to support deprescribing decisions. This study will use real-world healthcare data to examine patterns, benefits, and harms of discontinuing aspirin in older nursing home residents with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a common lung disease in premature babies. We discovered that increases in the microRNA let-7b-5p as early as birth strongly predict which infants will later develop BPD. In this project, we will find out if increases in this microRNA in human preterm infants at later time points is also predictive, and we will use mouse models and cell cultures to see if this microRNA is increased by oxygen exposure and causes BPD by decreasing blood vessels in the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Implantable vascular devices such as stents help to save the lives of millions of people with vascular disease every year. These vascular devices often fail over time and the daily medications which are required to prevent blood from clotting, negatively impact patients. This project will develop alloys of biodegradable metals which meet the mechanical and biological requirements of vascular stents to prevent device failure and improve patient lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Hedgehog signaling is widely implicated in development and disease, and its signaling transduction relies in dynamic protein trafficking in and out of the primary cilium, a special cell surface organelle. Many questions remain open regarding the protein transport and signaling relay mechanisms within the cilium. We propose to shed light on these standing questions with a functional proteomic study to discover new signaling transducers during the time course of hedgehog signal activation, and to determine the molecular mechanisms of Hedgehog pathway regulation by these new signaling components in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic musculoskeletal pain, specifically osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee, is common among community-dwelling people living with dementia and associated with cascading negative consequences on physical function limitations, quality of life decline, and caregiver burden; however, few beneficial and appropriate treatment options exist. This study seeks to use evidence, theory, and stakeholder input to design an exercise-based intervention for knee OA pain management that is tailored to the interests, preserved abilities, and biopsychosocial-environmental needs of community-dwelling older adults with mild to moderate dementia. Findings from K23 research will yield a nonpharmacological intervention prototype and delivery parameters that will inform a future efficacy study and have a strong potential for preserving or improving the quality of life of community-dwelling older adults with dementia and OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Cells release chemical signals in a process known as exocytosis, whereby small packages of signaling molecules within cells are expelled into the surrounding fluid where they can act on other cells. Exocytosis has essential roles in virtually all forms of neuronal and endocrine signaling. A deeper understanding of the mechanisms of exocytosis will enable us to learn how the endocrine system orchestrates complex physiological changes in the body, and how the nervous system encodes sensory inputs and processes information. These insights will help us understand how to treat medical conditions involving aberrant hormone release in endocrine disorders, and impaired neuronal communication in mental illness, learning disorders, epilepsy, and other neurological diseases. Studies of exocytosis in human neurons will evaluate synaptic release in Down syndrome, fragile X mental retardation, Parkinson's disease, and tuberous sclerosis complex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Plasminogen activation, MMPs, and extracellular proteolysis are rapidly advancing research areas as they intersect with basic science and clinical research. Critical roles for extracellular proteases are identified in many disorders related to cardiovascular disease, stroke and neurological disorders, aging, cancer, musculoskeletal and metabolic diseases, as well as infectious diseases. It is increasingly evident that research in this area is critical for the development of novel strategies and agents to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiometabolic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, and fatty liver disease, are considered the leading preventable causes of death in most geographies around the world. However, the origin, clinical presentation, and pathogenesis of these cardiometabolic diseases greatly varies worldwide, as do the resources and strategies needed to prevent and treat them. This Keystone Symposia conference will bring together scientists from all over the globe to discuss the latest in precision medicine, develop new scientific collaborations and discuss ways to implement precision medicine approaches to better understand and treat cardiometabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative The annual meeting of the American Aging Association (AGE) is one of the leading annual conferences in aging research in the US, and advances AGE’s mission of promoting biomedical research towards increasing the functional life span of humans, increasing knowledge of biogerontology among the public and among health professionals, and fostering the career development of trainees and scientific members. The goal of the annual AGE meeting is to convene senior and junior scientists to discuss the latest discoveries in aging research, highlight new directions in the field, and promote the emergence of new ideas and collaborative activities among participants. We seek funding for the 52nd annual AGE meeting, where approximately 63% of all invited session speakers will be early career investigators or trainees, more than half will be women, and we will highlight participation from underrepresented minority groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histiocytic disorders, or histiocytoses, are a group of rare hematologic neoplasms and inflammatory disorders affecting both adults and children, characterized by accumulation of macrophage, dendritic cell, or monocyte- derived cells in affected tissues. Despite important advances in the understanding and therapy of these disorders, there are critical knowledge gaps about the natural history of the histiocytoses and their optimal treatment, in part owing to a lack of harmonized investigation across the diseases. This proposed collaborative workshop represents an unprecedented gathering of diverse senior and junior scientists, across the spectrum of histiocytic disorders, to align priorities and approaches to rigorous patient-centered research in these diseases.

This conference will present novel insights into the role of lymphatics in diseases of different organ systems including heart disease, plaque deposition in the arteries, lung inflammation, autoimmune diseases, Crohn’s disease, Alzheimer disease and cancer. PHR: Vascular Biology 2024 Annual Meeting of the North American Vascular Biology Organization  with guest society: Microcirculatory Society  October 20-2419, 2024  Asilomar Conference Grounds, Pacific Grove, California  Principal Investigator: Ying Zheng Project Narrative: At this vascular biology meeting, scientists will present new discoveries in developmental vascular biology, microcirculation, matrix biology, bioengineering, vascular genetics, vascular signaling, and inflammation and will openly discuss the impact of their findings on development, health, and disease. The integrated topics and participation by the Microcirculatory Society will facilitate interactions between established researchers and trainees with overarching common interests, who might otherwise not have opportunities for direct interaction and scientific exchange. PHR: Project Narrative The National Institutes of Health (NIH) Office of Research Infrastructure (ORIP) supports novel research that improves and protects human health by awarding grants to support research resources, such as animal models for human disease and state-of-the-art biomedical instrumentation. This grant will fund three conferences over five years to bring together the Directors of Resource Centers supported by NIH/ORIP, Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives. The conferences’ objectives are to provide a setting for Directors to discuss common issues and problems pertinent to accomplishing the mission of ORIP, obtain feedback and advice from NIH staff and scientists, and share ideas for common solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The PARP Family and ADP-ribosylation Project Narrative ADP-ribosylation is unique among post-translational modifications because it contains both nucleic acid and sugar features. ADP-ribosylation is catalyzed by a family of enzymes (17 in humans) known as PARPs. PARP- mediated ADP-ribosylation has widespread roles in fundamental cellular processes: from DNA repair and transcriptional regulation to the regulation of protein stability and mRNA translational regulation. PARPs are clinically relevant, and small molecule inhibitors are sought-after drug targets. Currently, there are several FDA-approved inhibitors of the founding member PARP1, which have demonstrated tremendous clinical success in the treatment of certain forms of ovarian and breast cancer. In recent years other, lesser-studied PARP family members (e.g. PARP7 and PARP14) as well as enzymes that recognize and reverse ADP- ribosylation, have emerged as exciting new therapeutic targets for cancer and inflammatory diseases. Transformative new tools developed in the last couple of years have revealed new functions for PARPs and ADP-ribosylation, and have expanded the field in exciting new directions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic and phenotypic data from our closest human relatives, Neanderthals and Denisovans (archaic humans), is becoming ever more accessible due to technological advancements, but the relationship of specific genetic changes between human lineages and their downstream phenotypic effects is still unmapped. I propose to use modern, high-throughput functional genomics techniques to dissect how lineage-specific variants in cis-regulatory regions led to the emergence of unique phenotypes in both archaic and modern humans. The proposed study will be the most thorough investigation to-date of how lineage-specific derived variants have played a role in the evolution of recent human groups.

PHR: Narrative Basic science and clinical research into blood coagulation proteins and platelets is critical as bleeding and thrombotic disease remain the leading causes of death worldwide. Moreover, recent advances have identified important roles for clotting proteins and platelets in many pathological processes beyond bleeding and cardiovascular disorders, including cancer, aging, and infectious diseases. The 11th Symposium on Hemostasis provides an ideal setting and opportunity for scientists and clinicians to share their latest advances, as well as to welcome trainees into this exciting field of study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental injustice contributes to disparities in health status across populations of differing ethnicity, race, and socioeconomic status. Infants and children, because of their unique biological vulnerabilities and age‐related patterns of exposure, are especially vulnerable to the health impacts of environmental injustice. This initial conference of a five year series will bring together child exposomics researchers with students and early stage investigators from historically black colleges and universities with community and child health advocates to assess the state of the science and create an environmental justice agenda for children.

PHR: Project Narrative Immunoengineering is a young and vibrant field that seeks to improve human health via cutting-edge analysis, manipulation, and engineering of the immune system, yielding, for example, the cancer immunotherapies that were named the 2013 Breakthrough of the Year by Science Magazine. Following on the tremendous success of the inaugural meeting in 2022, this 2024 Immunoengineering GRC and GRS for will bring together basic scientists, engineers, and translational experts to brainstorm new ideas across disparate fields catalyze new approaches to improve human health that can be realized in the clinic. The meeting will also advance the future of the field by supporting the careers of trainees and young investigators in Immunoengineering, and by actively promoting diversity and inclusion in the program and attendances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The major goal of this conference is to serve as a driving force for cutting-edge discussions and formulation of experiments and collaborations that open new areas of exploration of energy metabolism underlying cognition, energy homeostasis and alterations in aging, Alzheimer’s disease, and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias. This small, focused conference centers on brain energy metabolism and brings together the world's experts, with strong emphasis on participation by women, young investigators, students, and postdoctoral fellows in formal presentations and informal discussions which are a highlight of the meeting. This unique, `investigator initiated' conference series has a long history with strong conceptual, experimental, and collaborative contributions to address controversial areas in the field, and to address development of new approaches to address difficult issues that underlie Alzheimer’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease related dementias and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal evaluates the importance of alveolar macrophage EphA2 β-glucan receptor signaling in host responses to Pneumocystis. Furthermore, we will determine the importance of EphA2 activity in vivo during Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in the CD4 depleted mouse model through analysis of lung inflammation, organism killing, and eventual outcome. Observations from these studies will aid in understanding PCP, and guide development of novel therapeutic approaches targeting this pathway for PCP, for patients who are refractory or fail standard antibiotic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Toxicology is a discipline and profession that is dedicated to identifying the adverse effects of chemical, physical, and biological agents on living organisms and the ecosystem and to preventing and ameliorating such adverse effects. As a mini conference embedded in the Society of Toxicology (SOT) Annual Meeting, the SOT Undergraduate Diversity Program supports a critical need during the undergraduate years: by immersing students from groups underrepresented in the sciences in a disciplinary science meeting, we encourage them to prepare for and apply to graduate school in the biomedical sciences, thus strengthening the pipeline of future toxicologists. Apart from further developing the talent pool, the SOT meeting and this program benefit public and environmental health by advancing research to protect society and the environment from adverse health risks resulting from exposures to hazardous agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The barrier surfaces of multicellular organisms include tissues that are often exposed to infectious agents and factors that contribute to chronic inflammatory diseases such as asthma, allergy, inflammatory bowel diseases and cancer. Yet, there is still much to learn about the complex interplay between these tissue barrier sites, microbial factors, and inflammatory mediators. This conference was designed to bring together experts in innate and adaptive immunity, host-microbiota interactions and neuroscience to foster collaborations between scientists, engage young investigators in the field, and to accelerate research progress in barrier immunity that will lead to the development of new treatments for complex immune disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: IMAT R61 Narrative A major challenge in cancer is how to combat treatment resistant properties of cancer stem cells (CSCs) which drive tumor recurrence and progression. Here we develop a novel high-throughput screening platform that reports changes in CSC electrical properties and cell proliferation in response to ion channel drugs. The changes in electrical properties and proliferation are expected to identify drugs that “reprogram” CSCs to more treatment responsive states which can be used in combination with current or future therapies to improve treatment responses and outcomes for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many novel cancer therapies have been developed to target genomic instability, which is a hallmark and a driving force of cancer. These new therapies are currently moving from the lab to the clinic, and we are poised for a rapid expansion of new DNA repair pathway-targeting drugs that will be used to eliminate different types of cancer. The 2023 SoCal Genome Stability Symposium will focus on research related to genomic instability and its implications in cancers and therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) affects over 20% of all veterans, putting them at risk for serious complications, including vision loss, renal failure, heart attacks, and amputations. T2D is caused by diminished insulin secretion from insulin-producing pancreatic islets and reduced response to insulin. Insoluble protein aggregates, called amyloid, within and around T2D islets may contribute to islet dysfunction. To help identify new approaches to prevent and treat T2D, we are investigating how islet amyloid affects function and health of the various cell types within the human pancreatic islet. We will leverage innovative approaches including genetic manipulation of human islet cells, intra-vital imaging of transplanted human islets, and single nuclear transcriptomic profiling, to study how interactions between the receptor for advanced glycation endproducts (RAGE) and islet amyloid influences islet health in the in vivo context.

PHR: Limb salvage is a major health issue for Veterans with diabetes and peripheral arterial disease. The increasing incidence of diabetes and peripheral arterial disease and the clinical plateau of therapeutic options make this a critical and national issue. This proposal seeks to overcome current barriers and develop a translational platform for regenerative medicine in our Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative We will impact Veteran’s healthcare by improving on-going access to VA multidisciplinary care services to Veterans with HIV by facilitating the implementation of VA Video Connect (VVC). VVC is a VA-supported mobile health video technology that allows Veterans and providers to complete clinical visits from any remote location including the home. We will test whether we can increase Veterans use of VVC in the HIV clinic in the Houston VA, identify the impact of VVC on the Veterans health, and then conduct work to facilitate implementation in HIV clinics in 6 other VA centers throughout the US. VVC is a disruptive technology that can change the way vulnerable Veterans receive primary care, specialty care, social services, and mental health. This project will provide the evidence needed to expand VVC use and the services using VVC, and will provide critical data on how best to do so. It directly addresses priorities to modernize VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Largely due to intersecting forms of stigma and unmet needs for gender affirmation, transgender and nonbinary people have significantly worse mental health outcomes, compared to the general population. Peers have been identified as a critical aspect of gender affirmation, with peer-delivered interventions offering a promising scalable mechanism for addressing mental health disparities. This proposal aims to leverage a community-engaged approach to identify desired elements of peer support interventions, and to develop and test an intervention to improve mental health outcomes among transgender and nonbinary people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT These studies are relevant to public health because despite considerable progress in our understanding of prostate cancer biology, prostate cancer remains a significant cause of suffering and the second leading cause of cancer death among men and there is a pressing need for new and better approaches to treatment. The remarkably adaptive nature and complexity of prostate cancer progression and the uniform development of resistance underscores the importance of developing a broader range of therapeutic agents and approaches that would increase chances of overcoming the resistance to current therapies. This proposal focuses on elucidating how a novel small molecule therapeutic agent may be used to treat prostate cancer by regulating a novel target and an under-exploited cellular process in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The utilization trends of mental health services among transgender (TG) people are poorly understood due to the limited sample sizes, yet there are increased efforts to identify TG people within large electronic health care data using computational phenotypes (CPs). Through this proposed research and training plan, the applicant will investigate the performance of existing CPs to assess the health care utilization trends of TG patients with depressive disorders (DD), anxiety, and attention deficit disorders (ADD) and their risk of self-harm. Ultimately, the results of this work can inform future mental health care policy and public health officials to inform interventions and improve mental health equity among this understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate at a very detailed level the origin of interictal spikes, one of the key electrical outputs of an epileptic brain. We have developed a system for recording and manipulating activity in individual neurons spanning an entire epileptic brain slice. This system will be used to identify the cell types involved in generating interictal spikes and the mechanisms by which they synchronize, both of which will directly inform development of novel antiepileptic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal mosaicism in the blood has not been comprehensively investigated in African American and Latino populations. We will assess this biomarker of cancer risk in these populations through the development of novel methodology that will enhance integrative analysis of mosaic mutations, germline variation, and ancestry. A better understanding of mosaicism in these under-studied populations will allow for more targeted cancer risk assessment and early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In spite of the dramatic increase in our understanding of the structure and properties of hepatitis B virus (HBV), this pathogen remains a major threat to human health. That knowledge also makes HBV an important test case for new antiviral strategies. This project aims to limit the impact of HBV by using computer simulations and synthetic chemistry to develop an improved understanding of the assembly process of HBV as well as new drugs that can eliminate HBV infection in ways that may be generalized to other pathogenic viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Shigella species are the causative agents of bacillary dysentery, a severe form of diarrhea that infects millions of people each year and causes hundreds of thousands of deaths. This bacterium invades and grows within intestinal epithelial cells by disarming the host’s innate immune responses. Here, by investigating how the bacteria evade host responses, we will gain critical knowledge regarding new potential ways to interrupt the infection process.

PHR: The most common cause of multi-drug resistant urinary tract infections (UTIs) are two Escherichia coli strains, that at the same time appears to be able persisting for a long time in the gut and bladder of healthy women, without symptoms of UTI or taking antibiotics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying cellular reservoirs contributing to HIV-1 persistence is essential for development of curative strategies for HIV-1. This application is based on the central hypothesis that brain pericytes are a key, albeit previously unrecognized, cell type for the formation of HIV-1 reservoirs in the CNS. The proposed experiment will define whether brain pericytes harbor latent HIV-1 infections in HIV-suppressed patients (Aim 1), evaluate transcriptional signatures of latently HIV-1-infected human brain pericytes (Aim 2), and determine functional outcomes associated with HIV-1 infection of brain pericytes (Aim 3). Overall, the obtained results will help us to better characterize the pericyte reservoirs in the CNS in order to design future therapies for reservoir clearance and HIV-1 cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The Rieske non-heme iron oxygenases are broadly represented in Nature and showcase reactivity that is essential for degrading environmental pollutants and building medically relevant and commercially valuable natural products. Despite the wealth of annotated Rieske oxygenases, there is a critical lack of information about how these enzymes employ a common set of metallocenters to catalyze a diverse set of site-specific oxygenation reactions. It is therefore critical to obtain information about the structure–function relationships in this class of enzymes to facilitate efforts aimed at repurposing and redesigning Rieske oxygenases for industrial use.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative. Uterine fibroids (UF) are a highly common and costly gynecologic condition that disproportionately affect Black women with regard to incidence, severity, treatment, and outcomes. Recent data suggest that substantial Black/White disparities in UF exist within VA. As one-third of women Veterans using VA health care are Black and this proportion is increasing, understanding the drivers of these disparities within VA is of critical importance. This study will use mixed methods to investigate mechanisms underlying Black/White disparities in UF-related outcomes in VA, including modifiable differences by race in pathways to treatment and interactions with the healthcare system. This work addresses multiple HSR&D priority areas including women’s health, health equity, and healthcare access and will make a substantial impact by informing development of patient-centered interventions to eliminate disparities. Next steps will include partnering with VA women’s health and health equity leaders to design programs and policies that can accelerate progress towards quality and equity in gynecology care in VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) or Lou Gehrig’s disease is characterized by the specific death of the nerve cells that control muscle movement, leading to paralysis and eventual death. ALS is linked to inflammation and defects in energy metabolism. This proposal will investigate if altered expression of a protein that binds fatty acids and regulates inflammation and metabolism plays a role in the progression of the disease in ALS-models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 9-1-1 complexes are an essential component of the DNA damage response pathway by acting as a sensor of damaged sites to promote the direct recruitment of DNA repair proteins and activate ATR signaling. Despite the advancement in understanding the ATR signaling network during meiosis, it remains unclear the role of the 9-1-1 complexes in ATR signaling regulation. Understanding the 9-1-1 mediated ATR signaling will improve our knowledge of the molecular mechanisms regulated by ATR that allow high-fidelity gamete production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to selectively functionalize C–H bonds enables synthetic access to a wide range of valuable chemical feedstocks for the production of pharmaceuticals, natural products, polymers, and commodity chemicals. A promising strategy to carry out selective hydrocarbon functionalization is to design modular catalysts in which the steric and electronic constraints of the active site impart catalyst-encoded selectivity towards a targeted C– H bond. This work aims to harness the oxidative power of electro- and photochemically generated nitrogen- centered radicals catalysts for selective C–H bond functionalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type IV P-type ATPases (P4-ATPases) are lipid regulators known for their ability to influence membrane composition and vesicular transport within the cell and when its function is disrupted, leads to various neurological diseases. This project will be using Saccharomyces cerevisiae to investigate the role of the flippase activity on the formation of retromer-mediated transport vesicles and their ability to recycling known retromer cargo. The results from this project will elucidate a new form of regulation in intracellular trafficking pathways and allow for an understanding of how absence of P4-ATPases may lead to disease including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT TITLE Subcortical targets involved in the action of psilocybin in learned and innate escape behaviors Project Narrative  Psilocybin represents a potentially revolutionary treatment for depression, a leading cause of disability. However, while preliminary clinical trials are encouraging, knowledge of the mechanisms underlying this effect are less understood and focus predominately on the cortex and hippocampus. This proposal will examine the roles of subcortical brain regions in the action of psilocybin during learned and innate escape behaviors, broadening the approach and understanding for the treatment of depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE microRNA-181b is highly expressed in the vasculature, and has overall, been shown to be beneficial in terms of vascular health. Studies examining the role of microRNA-181b in the vasculature has shown that microRNA- 181b decreases with age with a concurrent rise in vascular stiffness and that induced vascular stiffening has been prevented by increasing levels of microRNA-181b. The purpose of this proposal is to determine the exact mechanism(s) of the age-associated decline in microRNA-181b, discover the unknown downstream targets of microRNA-181b, and measure the effect of microRNA-181b overexpression on vascular health with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engaging adolescents living with HIV in HIV care is essential for improving HIV outcomes, and depression has been identified as a significant barrier to initiating and remaining in HIV care for this population. The proposed project adapts and enhances an evidence-based mental health intervention protocol and evaluates its role in improving depression and engagement in HIV care in an individual randomized 3-arm pilot among adolescents living with HIV in Malawi. This proposal will generate critical evidence for designing a fully powered clinical trial to test our adapted and enhanced intervention protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Center for genome imaging (CGI)  A full understanding of the genome will require the highest resolution knowledge of how genes and chromosomes are organized in 3D space in both healthy and diseased cells. Without such knowledge, efforts to advance disease diagnosis and medical intervention will be compromised. As such, the overarching goal of the proposed studies is to develop and implement imaging and analysis strategies that can encompass entire genomes, including the distinction of homologs and the identification of highly repetitive sequences, and, thus, comprehensively elucidate how spatial organiza- tion influences genome function, stability, and inheritance.

PHR: This project will support NNLM in achieving its mission to provide U.S. researchers, health professionals, public health workforce, educators, and the public with equal access to biomedical and health information resources and data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is the second leading cause of death among adolescents and the rates have doubled since 2000. The goal of the present study is to develop personalized risk models of adolescent suicidal ideation based on passive and objective data sources (using wearables and smartphone sensors indexing social engagement, sleep, and physical activity). Our innovative research design has the potential to identify when and how to intervene to reduce suicide risk in individual adolescents.

PHR: NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment is common among individuals with Parkinson’s disease and is associated with reduced quality of life and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bone diseases such as periodontitis and peri-implantitis are very significant health issues that severely affect patients' quality of life and increase the risk of other systemic diseases. It is critical to understand the mechanism underlying bone remodeling in periodontitis and peri-implantitis and to develop effective strategies that prevent inflammatory bone loss and repair bone damaged. This proposal will elucidate a novel mechanism by which F-BOX Protein11 (FBXO11) regulates bone development and inflammation, and render FBXO11 signaling as a new therapeutic target to control and regenerate bone loss in periodontitis and peri-implantitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: In many diseases that are difficult to treat, body tissues and whole organs become inflamed and accumulate excess scar tissue in a process call fibrosis. The mechanisms through which cells and molecules become disturbed in these diseases are complex and incompletely understood, delaying the development of new medicines. In this project, we explore previously understudied aspects of a body molecule called IL-33, which may be targeted with future therapies, and begin developing one of such innovative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cigarette smoking and nicotine dependence have been associated with delayed sleep timing, poor sleep quality and quantity, as well as sleep disordered breathing and insomnia. Our goal is to identify the contributing factors to smoking status, determine circadian characteristics of smoking behavior, and to determine the effects of acute sleep restriction on smoking withdrawal in racially diverse populations. Overall, this study will help to identify targets for smoking cessation strategies as well as lead to novel therapeutic interventions for sleep disruption and smoking abstinence, particularly among ethnic minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an incurable, muscle disease that affects 1 in 3500-6000 boys world- wide. Since the lymphatic system plays active roles in both the resolution and progression of inflammation, our idea is that further increasing the lymphatic vessel density in muscle tissues will augment lymph transport, and consequently, lessen inflammation and improve muscle health in DMD muscle. In this study, we will use mouse and dog models of DMD to understand how new lymphatic capillaries and the improved contractile function of lymphatics will help skeletal muscle fibers to reduce inflammation and improve muscle strength and health in DMD animals, which would potentially provide therapies to improve health in patients with DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: There is an urgent need to gain insight into HIV-1 escape from broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) to aid in more effective combination antibody strategies to be used towards HIV-1 therapy, cure and prevention. The overall objective of this proposal is to measure the ability of genetically diverse strains of HIV antibodies to escape from bNAbs and design an antibody cocktail capable of restricting escape. These findings will inform all clinical trials using bNAbs or bNAb-based molecules, and ultimately, these studies will define a rational pipeline to characterize antibody escape pathways in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop and validate a two-part deep learning method for dose verification in patients with early-stage non-small cell lung cancer receiving definitive stereotactic body radiation therapy. We will evaluate feasibility in a prospective early-stage clinical trial, a necessary intermediate step prior to the implementation of real-time daily adaptive radiation therapy. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current chlamydia prevention and control efforts have been unable to reduce chlamydia infection rates, which provides strong rationale for development of a chlamydia vaccine to prevent chlamydia and its reproductive sequelae. This project will evaluate systemic and mucosal cellular and humoral immune responses induced by promising chlamydia vaccine candidate antigens and will assess association of the immune responses with clinical correlates of protection against chlamydia in women (spontaneous clearance of chlamydia and absence of reinfection after treatment). Findings may advance chlamydia vaccine development efforts and lead to formulation of these candidate antigens into a chlamydia vaccine for a phase I study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Neural circuits are constructed by synapses that connect neurons into vast networks, but how synapse formation builds a neural circuit and how such processes become impaired in neuropsychiatric disorders remains unclear. Latrophilins are postsynaptic signaling molecules that are essential for the formation of specific subsets of synapses in nearly all of the brain’s neural circuits and that may play a key role in neuropsychiatric disorders. The present project will elucidate the fundamental mechanisms by which latrophilins enable synapse formation and specify defined synaptic connections using an interdisciplinary approach in mice and in human neurons.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an urgent, global, public health threat: highly resistant strains have emerged that possess a remarkable evolutionary capacity to adapt and persist in the face of therapy. In this project, our unifying focus is to develop novel combination therapies using novel non-natural nucleotides targeted at hypermutation together with existing antibiotic strategies involving β-lactam antibiotics. Taken together, our results will set the cornerstone for future testing of anti-mutators in clinical trials and provide unprecedented insight into combination therapies for Gram-negative urgent threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose to engineer patient T cells to recognize an antigen called folate receptor-alpha, which is expressed by up to 90% of ovarian cancers, and use them to treat women with recurrent ovarian cancer, a disease which kills more than 14,000 women each year, and for which there are no effective treatment options. Here, we propose to conduct a clinical trial to test the whether these CAR T cells are safe, feasible and effective in women with recurrent ovarian cancer. We will also explore the use of a new macrophage depleting approach as a novel preparative treatment regimen to augment CAR T cell therapy in preclinical models, as a bridge to future trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed project addresses the physiological role of the astrocytic inwardly rectifying potassium channel Kir4.1 and how it modulates interneuron activity in the cerebral cortex. This channel has been implicated in a variety of neurological disorders including seizure susceptibility, epilepsy, and ALS; however, how it affects neuronal function is unknown. If successful this project will provide a better understanding of potassium homeostasis, interneuron activity, and astrocytic potassium buffering and how these contribute to pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical and translational research is vital to the development of new treatments for substance use disorders and for understanding the underlying neurobiological causes of these disorders. The Research Training Fellowship in Substance Abuse Program (RTFSA-P) is a well-established program within the Division of Addictions (DA) at the Yale School of Medicine Department of Psychiatry that is dedicated to training young physicians and PhD-level trainees in translational research that spans from basic science studies to clinical neuroscience research related to the field of addictions. The program trains four fellows per year and at the end of training, fellows should be well suited for independent careers in addiction research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calvarial skeletal stem cells (SSCs) reside in the sutural niche and contribute to calvarial bone homeostasis and healing after injury. This research project aims to determine how calvarial SSCs translocate from the sutural niche to distant regions of the calvarial bones for bone repair. The results of this research project will set the stage for future mechanistic studies to achieve the goal of developing new therapeutic approaches to regenerate and repair injured calvarial bones.

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because new knowledge of mechanisms by which inflammation is regulated will be acquired. This knowledge is directly applicable to understanding the broad array of diseases with dysregulated inflammation, including, including aberrant wound healing, lung and cardiovascular fibrosis, scarring, infection, sepsis, autoimmune disease and asthma. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For people who have lost the ability to move due to movement disorders, including paralysis and ALS, intracor- tical brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) aim to restore movement and communication by directly decoding neural activity from motor regions of the brain. We propose to accelerate and democratize BMI research by building a computational simulator, implemented entirely in software, that enables researchers around the world to design and optimize BMI decoder algorithms. We expect this tool will reduce BMI evaluation time from months to min- utes, and by being widely available and open source to all, considerably increase the intracortical BMI research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Voltage-gated sodium and calcium channels initiate electrical signals and synaptic transmission in neurons, and they are impaired in inherited epilepsy, migraine, chronic pain, and periodic paralysis. We will determine the three-dimensional structures of the key functional elements of sodium and calcium channels at the atomic level. Learning and memory depend on modification of the strength of communication between nerve cells at synapses, a process called synaptic plasticity. We will analyze the molecular and cellular mechanism of short- term synaptic plasticity, which is important for encoding and transmitting information in neurons. Dravet Syndrome (DS) is a devastating childhood neuropsychiatric disorder caused by de novo, heterozygous loss-of- function mutations in brain type-I voltage-gated Na channel Nav1.1, which we are studying in a novel mouse genetic model. Overall, our work will define the fundamental mechanisms of sodium and calcium channel function at the atomic level; provide new understanding of the roles of these ion channels in synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory; and give key insights into the pathophysiology and novel approaches to therapy of DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low back pain will affect the majority of the population at some point in their lifetime, and many of these patients’ pain may be caused by nerve growth, inflammation, and altered mechanical loading. Despite this knowledge, current treatments do not target these features, because their relative contribution to the pain is unknown. Our work seeks to use a novel rodent model of chronic low back pain to investigate the role of nerve presence, inflammation, and mechanical stimulation on pain generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Cleft palate is a common congenital birth defect with a complex etiology of contributions by both genetic and environmental factors. While increasing number of studies suggest a link between cellular metabolic aberrations and cleft palate, it remains largely unknown how cholesterol metabolism affects palate formation. The knowledge gained from this study will lead to a new approach for the diagnosis and prevention of cleft palate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This competitive renewal application requests continued NIMH funding for the long-standing, successful University of California, San Diego (UCSD) Fellowship in Biological Psychiatry and Neuroscience. The Fellowship is designed for provide education, research training, and career opportunities for 7 post-doctoral fellows with a particular emphasis on candidates that are focused on using biological tools to understand pathophysiology and brain processes of psychiatric illness and develop potential treatments for these disorders. The overall goal is to train fellows from diverse backgrounds and research disciplines to acquire and extend skills necessary for the conceptualization, planning, conduct, analysis and publication of research in biological psychiatry and neuroscience with the ultimate goal to become independent and funded researchers, thereby addressing the shortage of clinical researchers who can translate advances in science to treatments for psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Natural killer (NK) cells are vital components of the human innate immune system that seek out and destroy malignant cells as they arise. However, in cancer patients, their tumor cells have escaped NK cell immune surveillance and targeted killing, through various mechanisms including suppressed NK cell development. The studies outlined in this proposal will advance our basic understanding of human innate immunity and will lead to improved strategies to prevent and treat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: As people get older, they lose the ability to grow new blood vessels to help with healing particularly as cholesterol builds up in the blood vessels throughout the body. Our blood cells have the ability to activate the growth of new blood vessels, but the pathways involved and the impact of aging on this ability are not fully understood. This grant seeks to understand the age-acquired changes in certain genes that might influence the signals required for new blood vessel growth. This study will lead to new medicines that can improve blood vessel growth where needed for more rapid healing in older patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human amygdala contains a population of late-maturing neurons that delay their growth until childhood and adolescence when they develop into mature excitatory neurons; however, little is known about their underlying biology. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the developmental trajectories, synaptic connectivity and diversity of late-maturing amygdala neurons from their genesis to functional integration in both humans and mice. This work is fundamental to understanding how abnormal development of these neurons impacts human neurodevelopmental disorders, many of which manifest during adolescence and are characterized by altered trajectories of amygdala development and plasticity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective treatments of disordered fetal growth during complications of pregnancy are lacking. This is due to limitations in our understand of the regulation of fetal growth. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative (public health relevance): BBB breakdown has recently been associated with various neurological disorders including Stroke, Alzheimer's Disease, Parkinson's Disease and Multiple Sclerosis, with neurodegeneration and neuroinflammation as hallmarks of these CNS disorders. Conversely, an intact BBB also poses a major obstacle for drug delivery to the CNS, and has resulted in few therapeutic agents that can transiently cross the BBB to treat neurological disorders, psychiatric illnesses and brain tumors. Therefore, understanding the molecular mechanisms governing BBB formation and function is critical for achieving therapeutic breakthroughs and this proposal will provide new tools to identify key regulators of the BBB, fundamentally advance our understanding of the BBB, and promote discovery of novel therapies to manipulate the BBB for treating neurologic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Cigarette smoking is among the leading causes of preventable death in the United States because smoking increases risk for lung cancer and various diseases. Though U.S. smoking rates have declined, a substantial percentage of adults, particularly those living in poverty who have repeatedly tried and failed to quit, still smoke and therefore could benefit from novel interventions for cessation that operate through different mechanisms than those of traditional treatments. This study will use neuroimaging to uncover the mechanisms of action of a promising strategy for affect regulation and smoking cessation and also build profiles of individuals for whom this strategy does and does not work, thereby providing tangible and practical information that public health professionals and clinicians can use to inform personalized treatments for cigarette smoking cessation.

PHR: The development of a functional nervous system requires precise guidance of axons and dendrites to their target locations and establishment of proper synaptic connections. This proposal is focused on understanding how the tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) regulates the cytoskeleton to control growth and guidance of developing neurons. By developing methods to compare neurons derived from normal and patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, we hope to identify sites for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative:  Treatments for mental health disorders are largely inadequate, in part because the practice of precision psy- chiatry faces extensive diagnostic heterogeneity, substantial between-patient variation in biological and clinical disease manifestation, and mismatch between diagnostic categorization and the underlying pathophysiology. This research proposes novel machine learning and statistical inference methods to address emerging challenges in precision psychiatry by discovering powerful and reliable individualized treatment strategies that address hetero- geneity, factor in a patient's clinical, psychosocial, and biological markers, and integrate evidence from multi-domain data sources and multiple studies to increase generalizability and reproducibility.

This project is directed toward elucidating an autoimmune mechanism of this debilitating disorder and to develop a safe, effective and non-invasive treatment option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  Our studies have established that loss of function mutations in the Wnt inhibitor Secreted Frizzled Receptor Protein 4 (SFRP4) are the cause of Pyle’s disease, a rare skeletal disease presenting with limb deformities characterized by gene valgum, marked cortical thinning and fragility fractures. We hypothesize that Sfrp4 expressed in a discreet pool of periosteal progenitors in the long bone and calvarium influences periosteal stem/progenitor cell activities and contributes to their bone regenerative potential. Insights gained here will be translatable to human diseases associated with bone fragility, and in the development of potential strategies for regeneration of bone defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic progressive differentiated thyroid cancer is an incurable disease. We have identified a new metastasis suppression signaling pathway in thyroid cancer and other solid tumors mediated by loss of RCAN 1.4 and activation of the transcription factor NFE2L3. Our preliminary data suggest that this pathway regulates the development of a tumor-promoting immune environment; the proposed experiments will determine the mechanism by which activation of this pathway occurs and how it promotes cancer progression with an emphasis on future therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major obstacle to rational HIV-1 vaccine design is the lack of an outbred primate animal model where the induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) can be achieved in a consistent and reproducible manner and the molecular events leading to bNAb elicitation deciphered. This application proposes a novel “reverse vaccinology” strategy to overcome this roadblock leading to new immunogen designs and a pivotal proof-of-concept preclinical immunogenicity and protection trial in rhesus macaques. This trial will test the ability of a germline-targeted Q23.17 SOSIP Env prime, followed by lineage-designed Q23.17 SOSIP Env trimer boosts, to elicit bNAbs that protect monkeys from a heterologous tier 2 virus challenge.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal implantation and placental development are a major underlying cause of reproductive failure, including early pregnancy loss and spontaneous abortion. Babies born to these pregnancies or pregnancies with a diseased placenta are at a greater risk for life-long cardiovascular, metabolic and immune health problems. Therefore, developing a better understanding of the genes and proteins that govern normal implantation and placental development is critical and may ultimately lead to new clinical diagnostic tools and therapeutic approaches for the amelioration of infertility and complications of pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A number of human diseases are caused by defects in the enzymes that cleave RNA. All eukaryotes have several of these genes, but what RNAs they cleave and how this causes disease is poorly understood. This study aims to increase understanding of the function of these enzymes, which will eventually provide information that could be used to treat such diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the leading cause of death in the United States, accounting for one in six deaths. Cardiac MRI is a non-invasive non-ionizing technique for comprehensive evaluation of CAD, but its clinical translation is hampered by lengthy exam times. In this work, we will develop and validate techniques for rapid cardiac MRI in a short exam time for comprehensive CAD assessment.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Enacted in 1986, the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) imposed a duty to treat – prior to EMTALA emergency departments could legally turn away patients with emergency conditions based upon ability to pay. Despite its intent to protect vulnerable populations, there is indirect evidence suggesting that EMTALA as currently enforced may exacerbate health disparities, because some hospitals have adapted to EMTALA in ways that might paradoxically reduce access to or quality of emergency care. Understanding whether EMTALA enforcement is associated with measurable changes in access to quality emergency care is needed to inform efforts to enhance and improve the statute.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of EMTALA on Access to and Quality of Emergency Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date, there are no available in vivo methods to distinguish critical sub-types of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) that may be amenable to treatment. We have recently described iron-rich cortical pathology in FTLD, showing distinct laminar distributions associated with underlying proteinopathies. We will develop novel, iron-sensitive MRI protocols to monitor and diagnose FTLD pathologies in vivo, supporting future treatment trials that target individual proteinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because abnormal decision-making is a hallmark of many psychiatric disorders. This proposal is particularly relevant to the aims of NIDA because it will substantially improve our insight into how neural signals in key learning and decision-making circuits develop in normal animals and how they are altered in animals exposed to cocaine. Improving our understanding of the neural, epigenetic, and computational mechanisms underlying the decision-making process will provide a better working knowledge of how we behave normally and how this circuit is affected by chronic drug use, which will aid in the development of more effective treatment solutions and diagnostic strategies for such psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Alphaviruses, such as Sindbis virus, Chikungunya virus, and Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis virus are significant threats to public health. Alphaviral infection in otherwise healthy individuals may result in severe disease- including persistent severe multi-joint arthritis, viral encephalitis, and death. This proposal seeks to characterize the importance of a novel noncapped viral RNA in regards to the establishment of viral infection and pathogenesis, for the purpose of improving the understanding of alphaviral biology to identify innovative therapeutic strategies.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vancomycin is currently the drug of choice and the most important antibiotic for the treatment of CDI. However, C. difficile strains with decreased susceptibility to vancomycin have emerged in the patient population. The goal of this project is to establish the proportion and characterize the genetic elements responsible for vancomycin non-susceptibility in C. difficile isolates in patients from two geographically distinct locations, and assess the impact of vancomycin non- susceptibility on clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lung injury (ALI) and its more severe form, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) carry an unacceptably high level of mortality which results from the fundamental lack of effective pharmacological therapies. A common feature of ALI is the loss of endothelial barrier function in the pulmonary circulation, but a multitude of mechanisms underlie the pathological changes that contribute to pulmonary edema and complicates the investigation. This Project is focused on the novel role of cytoplasmic actions of histone deacetylase, HDAC9, in endothelial barrier regulation with the goal of accelerating the development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This randomized controlled intervention maternal (BIPOC).  trial addresses social and structural inequities to reduce SMM and mortality in the most at-risk patients – those that self-identify as Black, indigenous and people of color Specifically, our intervention will implement and evaluate anintegrated, multi-level maternity care home model (MCHM) aimed at reducing SMM among a group of BIPOC patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative. Characterization of the CNS reservoir and empiric testing of novel cure strategies require physiologically relevant animal models of HIV persistence in the brain. Here, we propose to integrate major advances from our groups in transmitted/founder (TF) SHIV NHP models and AAV-delivered CRISPR/Cas9 editing to delineate key features of the CNS reservoir and assess a promising approach to eradicative cure. In coordinated NHP experiments, we will use barcoded, macrophage-tropic TF SHIV.D to elucidate the mechanisms of CNS persistence and test the efficacy of global and myeloid-specific CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing to cure HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While chimeric antigen receptor T cell (CAR-T) therapies have revolutionized treatment options in a variety of pediatric cancers, CAR-Ts have provided little benefit to metastatic or relapsed solid tumor patients, in part because of inadequate CAR-T expansion. To understand the potential causes of poor CAR-T expansion, this research proposal will evaluate the effect of costimulatory domain and pre-apheresis chemotherapy on solid tumor patient CAR-T expansion and efficacy. Results will identify predictors or drivers of CAR-T efficacy and provide a platform to improve future CAR-T treatment options for children with solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Micro-RNAs (miRNAs) are promising biomarkers for cancer staging, diagnosis, prognosis, and therapeutics, however, their clinical applications are greatly limited by the inconsistent results among studies and lack of high-confidence detection methodologies. We will develop and optimize a single-molecule detection platform for simultaneous detection of endogenous miRNAs in cancer samples and develop a microfluidic chip to enable a speedy analysis of multiple samples in under 1 hour. While the detection platform is generic to miRNA biomarkers of different cancers, we will test our platform with a set of diverse preclinical triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) samples from TNBC-carrying patient-derived xenograft (PDX) mice.
