IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Delivering coordinated, comprehensive care to older adults with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) is challenging. The goal of this proposal is to examine the frequency and consequences of simultaneous enrollment in more than one care management program and to develop and implement a practical primary care based intervention to facilitate collaboration across care management programs for older adults with ADRD. This proposal will support the career development of Dr. Stephanie Nothelle who aims to develop embedded interventions to improve care delivery for older adults with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anesthesiologists play a critical role in the treatment of a wide range of health issues for diverse patient populations in multiple clinical arenas. The breadth of the field affords anesthesiologists the capacity to contribute enormously to basic, translational and clinical research and to push forward discovery, knowledge and care of patients in the operating room, intensive care units, pain medicine clinics, and other perioperative settings. This training grant program will provide the next generation of anesthesiologists and allied scientists with rigorous training in biomedical research so that they can bring more scientific discoveries to patients, and carefully document the safety, efficacy, and importance of the discoveries.
PROJECT_TERMS: Anesthesia procedures;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Comprehensive Anesthesia Research Training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vector-borne viral pathogens pose a global health risk to humans. SFTSV is a highly pathogenic, emerging bunyavirus that causes viral hemorrhagic disease in humans, with spillover potential. This project will leverage results with a 1st generation vaccine vector for development of an effective preventative therapeutic for SFTSV that may also aid in pandemic preparedness against other novel disease threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Blood-brain barrier disruption, brain swelling and edema were recently defined as biomarkers of disease severity in the first clinical studies using MRI in patients suffering from cerebral malaria. In this proposal, we use novel transgenic mice to present evidence that CD8 T cell induced lethal blood-brain barrier disruption is initiated through priming by discrete antigen presenting cell types. In this proposal, we will this “nature verses nurture” hypothesis pertaining to how CD8 T cells induce BBB disruption in vivo using the Plasmodium berghei ANKA (PbA) model of experimental cerebral malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunity to malaria naturally develops in those repeatedly infected by malaria parasites, but is a complex process involving different parts of the immune system and therefore poorly understood. In this proposal, we will broadly profile the immune systems of children and adults living in a malaria endemic area over multiple points in time, building state-of-the-art computational models to learn how infection affects the immune system and how this eventually leads to protection against malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Morrissey Project Narrative: (3 sentences) Cells measure, add, and subtract stimuli to determine when to respond and when to remain quiescent. This project is focused on how macrophages measure ‘Eat me’ and ‘Don’t eat me’ signals to set a threshold for triggering phagocytosis and inflammation. Our goal is to understand the biochemical and biophysical mechanisms underlying this decision, which may serve as the foundation for future studies manipulating macrophage signaling in a disease context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Leveraging expertise in innovative lung imaging and growing experience in COVID-19 clinical care at Columbia University Irving Medical Center (CUIMC) in New York City, we propose to apply state-of-the-art dual energy computed tomography to define the lung vasculature and parenchyma in 200 patients hospitalized for COVID- 19 at CUIMC and 100 matched controls. To strengthen our investigation into microvascular mechanisms of COVID-19 lung injury, we will correlate imaging findings at 3-12 months and 27-36 months post-COVID hospital discharge with biomarkers of inflammation, hypercoagulability, and complement activation. This will provide important insights on the development, progression, and prognosis of post-COVID chronic lung disease that will be suitable to guide post-COVID care and risk stratification, suggest targets for therapeutic interventions, and inform policies for risk mitigation and public health in the COVID-19 era.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Anxiety disorders such as phobias, panic disorder, and generalized anxiety disorder, are often characterized by maladaptive fear responses, but mechanistic insight into underlying neurocircuit function is still incomplete. Here, we study the role of serotonin in the periaqueductal grey to understand how this major modulatory neurotransmitter can change innate fear responses in adulthood and after developmental interference. Experiments are designed to reveal causal relationships between serotonergic activity, postsynaptic neurophysiology and behavior, to improve diagnosis, prevention, and treatment strategies in psychiatry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a rapidly growing health problem that already afflicts over 3 million people in the U.S. alone, causing lifelong debilitating conditions that create enormous social and economic burdens to society. This proposal investigates how T cells normally mediate immune tolerance to commensal bacteria of the gastrointestinal system during health, and how a breakdown in this process may contribute to disease. The knowledge gained from these studies will promote our understanding of IBD pathogenesis and provide novel strategies for future treatments.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will have a positive impact on developing new approaches to lessen the burden of obesity. Specifically, this project will provide new fundamental knowledge of how inflammation, particularly adipose tissue inflammation, influences skeletal muscle molecular responses to exercise. The project is relevant to the mission of NIDDK because it satisfies a critical need for understanding factors that contribute to variability in exercise response, particularly in individuals with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Women involved in the carceral system are at an increased risk of opioid use disorder, overdose and HIV- acquisition. Given the disproportionate number of racial/ethnic minority women, carceral settings provide an opportunity to reduce racial/ethnic disparities in HIV and opioid use disorder treatment engagement by linking these women with innovative biomedical HIV prevention strategies (e.g., pre-exposure prophylaxis; PrEP) and medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) treatment services. Providing linkage to these services using technology that provides women peer and healthcare provider support could be novel, so we propose the development and pilot testing of the PA-Links web-based app to enhance communication in an existing post- release navigation model embedded in a community-based health services organization in Pennsylvania.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Motoric Cognitive Risk syndrome (MCR) is a recently described pre-dementia syndrome, characterized by the presence of subjective cognitive complaints and slow gait that identifies people at high risk of Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia. Previous studies have described the epidemiology and identified modifiable risk factors for MCR. Yet, the pathogenesis of MCR is yet to be established.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In situ vaccination is a type of cancer immunotherapy that consists of administering a treatment directly into a tumor in order to regress that tumor and initiate a systemic immune response against tumor antigens. Our preliminary data suggest that by incorporating a blocking antibody against the IL10 receptor into in situ vaccines we enhance innate immune cells' ability to (i) directly kill tumor cells and (ii) prime tumor-specific T- cells that act systemically. In experiments that will lead to clinical trials aimed at extending the lives of patients with solid cancers, we will investigate the mechanism and the generalizability of this effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Cancer patients die of metastasis, and this advanced stage of disease is especially aggressive in metastatic melanoma. Melanoma metastasizing to distinct organs not only adapts to these organs' environment but also co-opts organ site-specific niches to thrive and evade therapies. Comprehensive study of organ-specific melanoma biology will enable a clearer understanding on the differential prognosis and therapy response associated with distinct metastatic organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a congenital bone and craniofacial disorder that mainly affects bones with varying severity in postnatal bone regeneration and repair, but how normal or defective structural components of collagen in OI regulate bone stem/progenitor cells are essentially unknown. In this project, we seek to define the in vivo characteristics and function of periosteal and bone marrow SSPCs in clinically relevant OI mouse models and we also propose to define key OI matrix factors that regulate periosteal and bone marrow SSPC function and improve bone healing. The success of the proposed studies will lead to new biological and clinical insights into SSPC function under OI pathophysiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Title: Cellular and Metabolic Basis of the Role of CYP1B1 in Liver Fibrosis Project Narrative Activation of hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) is central to the pathogenesis of liver fibrosis. The cytochrome P450 1B1 (CYP1B1) was initially recognized as a xenobiotic enzyme that metabolizes xenobiotics. CYP1B1 is better known for its extrahepatic functions, whereas the role of CYP1B1 in the liver fibrosis has not been reported. The goal of this study is to test our hypothesis that CYP1B1 has a cell-type specific role in liver fibrosis. We hypothesize that CYP1B1 has a cell-type specific role in HSC activation and liver fibrosis. Specifically, we hypothesize that HSC and/or HEP ablation or pharmacological inhibition of Cyp1b1 inhibits HSC activation and liver fibrosis. Mechanistically, inhibition of Cyp1b1 attenuates HSC activation by suppressing the intestinal trehalase, leading to the accumulation of trehalose, a non-reducing disaccharide that inhibits HSC activation and liver fibrosis. Our study will uncover a previously unrecognized endobiotic function of CYP1B1 in liver fibrosis mediated by the liver-intestine organ crosstalk and the trehalose metabolite. Pharmacological inhibition of Cyp1b1 and/or the use of trehalose represent novel strategies for the clinical management of liver fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Cochlear implants (CIs) allow most users to hear and understand speech in quiet environments but, they are less effective in the presence of background noise and also do not provide good appreciation of music. An important contributor to suboptimal performance is the imprecise nature of electrode-based stimulation, leading to activation of broad regions of the target auditory neurons; such broad activation leads to unwanted interactions among neighboring channels that degrade the frequency information transmitted to the brain. Our recent findings show that magnetic stimulation from micro-coils activates narrow regions of the target auditory neurons compared with current (electrode) technology, thereby better approximating the neural signaling patterns that arise naturally; we propose here to more fully evaluate the potential of micro-coils as a next-generation CI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Craniofacial bone loss in children occurs frequently due to trauma or congenital bone loss for which costly and invasive surgeries are the only remedy. Autologous bone grafting is the only approved surgical approach to repair craniofacial bone in children but involves high cost, morbidity, and revision surgeries. There are no bone regenerative strategies for children. We will target the Jagged1 non-canonical signaling pathway to develop a novel regenerative strategy to correct craniofacial bone loss using pre-clinical animal models as the first step towards developing a bone regenerative strategy for pediatric patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative dementias including Alzheimer’s disease afflict many elderly people in our society, and effective treatments to prevent neuronal death are severely lacking. Metabolic stress and endosomal dysfunction are early features of neurodegenerative disease, but how these cause neuron death, and strategies to maintain neuron resilience, remain elusive. This proposal will significantly advance our understanding of how endosome- associated risk genes for Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease contribute to metabolic vulnerability and proteostatic functional decline in human neurons, and will explore genetic and metabolic restorative approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex assembly of hundreds of proteins and a critical regulator of cell, tissue, and organ functions. Yet, the ECM is understudied. Here, we propose to leverage the resources generated by the HuBMAP consortium to build and deploy spatially-resolved maps of the ECM of each tissue of the human body, a first step toward understanding ECM functions in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we will employ complementary molecular, cellular, genetics, and state-of-the-arts next-generation sequencing techniques, as well as various mouse models, to investigate the function of RBMS3/PRRX1 axis in regulating immunosuppressive effect and response to immunotherapy for TNBC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Biliary atresia (BA) is a cholestatic liver disease of infancy that is the leading cause of pediatric liver transplantation. Evidence suggests a role for macrophages in the pathogenesis of BA, however, the specific immune-metabolic networks regulating the macrophage immune response have not been well defined. We aim to define how serum metabolites and the hepatic macrophage transcriptional phenotype at diagnosis may influence patient outcome to ultimately identify novel immune-modulatory treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Intercellular transmission and subsequent amplification of pathological tau contributes significantly to the progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other tauopathies, the underlying mechanisms of which remains largely unknown. Our preliminary data demonstrates for the first time that soluble tau post-translational modifications (PTMs) could dramatically affect the amplification of pathological tau in AD and other tauopathies, which represents a novel mechanism for the modulation of pathological tau spreading. In this proposed study, we will systematically explore how soluble tau PTMs would regulate the amplification of pathological tau in AD and other tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: An important unmet clinical need for MS patients is an effective method for promoting remyelination that can ameliorate clinical symptoms associated with demyelination and restore motor function while limiting immune cell infiltration into the CNS. Using a well-accepted preclinical animal model for MS, key areas of research include identifying signaling pathways governing neuroinflammation, characterizing signaling pathways controlling oligodendroglia maturation and remyelination, and refinement of strategies to improve neural progenitor cell (NPC)-mediated remyelination following surgical engraftment into the CNS and how non-coding RNAs influence disease. In addition, we will employ state- of-the-art single cell and nuclear RNA sequencing to better understand how immune cells interact with resident cells of the CNS during demyelination and remyelination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Neurocysticercosis (NCC), the infection of the central nervous system (CNS) caused by the larvae  of Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm, is identified as the most common cause of  acquired epilepsy worldwide. Larvae encyst in the brain and other tissue and survive by   evading the host´s immune response. A better knowledge of the immunomodulation by the parasite  should allow us to understand its survival mechanisms and to improve and renew therapeutic  approaches. We propose to take advantage of a new in vitro model of development of Taenia  solium embryos developed by our group that allows us to determine stage-specific  differences in antigen expression to identify immunomodulatory molecules used by  the parasite to survive evading the host´s immune response, with a focus in the recently  described TGF-β mimic molecules shown to play a significant role in parasite immunomodulation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Splicing of gene transcripts is an essential process in human cells and frequently dysregulated in disease. Despite progress, the molecular-level mechanisms of splice site identification are incompletely understood. We seek to understand how the splicing machinery identifies gene transcripts for processing into legible RNA messages, thereby providing context for personalized medicines to treat patients with dysfunctional splicing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our program prepares pre- and post-doctoral trainees to acquire advanced mental health services research skills to address challenges faced by the most vulnerable populations in our nation. Specifically, persons living with mental disorders who seek care at the intersection of multiple services sectors (e.g., specialty care, social services, schools) experience high needs for care, and are the least likely to secure needed services or to obtain high quality care. We are the only NIMH-funded T32 program located in a school of social work exclusively focusing on mental health services research. Since 1995, we have trained leaders in mental health services research and social work scholars in mental health. The overall mission of our program is for our trainees to acquire mental health services research knowledge and skills to meet the most pressing needs in the field of social work and to advance the public health significance and impact of NIMH-services research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Health Services Research;Mental Health Services;Schools;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Brown School Training Program in Mental Health Services Research

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the long-term impacts of an unanticipated large-scale natural disaster on the human capital and wellbeing of exposed youth. Data will come from the Study of the Tsunami Aftermath and Recovery (STAR), a 15-year panel study of coastal communities, households, and individuals in Aceh and North Sumatra on the island of Sumatra in Indonesia, who were at risk of exposure to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami, that is designed to leverage the natural experiment of the tsunami to study the causal effects of large-scale adverse events on a large sample of individuals that was representative of the pre- tsunami population. This project will also fully leverage all eight rounds of STAR panel data (one baseline and seven follow-up rounds) to closely trace out the trajectories of child outcomes in the initial and intermediate post-disaster periods, as well as continue to follow those outcomes into the longer-term, which will provide detailed insights into post-disaster resiliency and recovery and into the mechanisms underlying the long-term impacts of the disaster that studies with fewer survey rounds cannot observe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this research is to inform policies to reduce tobacco use and related disparities, as well as to inform policy efforts more broadly, particularly as timely issues, like firearm safety, nutrition policies, and COVID-19 mitigation measures, are increasingly subject to state preemption; this project will analyze whether—and to what extent—enactment or repeal of state preemption on local tobacco control (smoke-free air, advertising, licensure, youth access, and taxation) is associated with tobacco-related disparities. Guided by a socioecological perspective, our central hypothesis is that state preemption laws lead to disproportionately high tobacco use, secondhand smoke exposure, and retail (sales, retail density) in communities with more racial/ethnic minorities, of lower socioeconomic status, and/or in rural settings. This study will have high impact, as it will: 1) contribute novel data to the evidence base regarding state preemption impact on health outcomes/disparities and their potential mechanisms; 2) inform state and local policy efforts to reduce tobacco use and related disparities plaguing certain vulnerable populations; and 3) engage key tobacco control and policy experts to catalyze effective research translation and dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Reliable diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease is currently possible only at late stages of the disease, after hallmark symptoms such as movement dysfunction are evident. Accurate, early diagnosis is critical to pursuing differential prognostic and disease management approaches, and to assessing the efficacy of therapeutic interventions. We aim to develop a specific radioligand, MCL-524, to identify disease-specific changes to D2 expression and function as an early, quantifiable biomarker in prodromal PD; the results from this study will enable the development of MCL-524 towards clinical application in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Microvascular obstruction remains a significant barrier to optimize outcomes after PCI for myocardial infarction (MI), the leading cause of death in US. AdenoPaint has developed a transformative drug loaded guidewire platform (Adenowire) that allows for continuous elution of adenosine, a potent cardioprotective agent, throughout the procedure. The overall goal of this project is to advance the development of Adenowire to clinical trials to improve outcomes in MI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 3 million Americans have a bleeding disorder that could be deadly without treatment, while conversely, around 900,000 Americans each year are affected by a blood clot, resulting in nearly 100,000 – 300,000 deaths. As many patients still suffer from bleeding and clotting disorders of unknown cause, this proposal will probe previously unexplored molecular mechanisms involved in the production and function of different forms of blood proteins that are constantly working together to prevent unnecessary bleeding and clotting throughout all stages of life. Furthering our understanding of these mechanisms and their dysregulation has important implications for improving the treatment of bleeding and clotting disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescents are disproportionately affected by HIV and often access the emergency department (ED) as their only source of care. This multicenter, pragmatic trial seeks to adapt, refine, and test a previously developed tablet-based, broad scale gonorrhea and chlamydia screening intervention process to increase universally offered, opt-out HIV screening in the pediatric ED and use an innovative mHealth HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) navigation platform to identify and link at-risk youth to ongoing PrEP care. Results will contribute to the evidence base that informs the development of effective and sustainable HIV screening and prevention programs that can be successfully integrated into the clinical workflow of the ED.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Successful completion of the proposed studies will significantly advance our knowledge regarding TDP-43 mediated R-loop dynamics that govern transposon elements (TE) expression landscapes in AD and may identify key human TEs that promote AD pathogenesis, which will have a significant impact on identifying more effective therapeutic treatments that are urgently needed in AD. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of adults have gained dental insurance since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), however, despite significant health policy efforts to reduce disparities in oral health, utilization of dental services among vulnerable groups remains low. In addition, we will examine whether the extent of this problem will vary across states as a function of both Medicaid policies and neighborhood characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: This T32 application outlines the plan for an education program entitled “Rochester Musculoskeletal (ROCMSK) Training Program”, which is based in the Center for Musculoskeletal Research at the University of Rochester Medical Center. ROCMSK is designed to provide interdisciplinary didactic and research training in musculoskeletal science with the aim of developing future generations of musculoskeletal scientists and leaders of innovations. This program will nurture the career development of energetic young musculoskeletal investigators with a goal of independent funding success to ensure continued future innovations in musculoskeletal research from basic science through clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Calorie restriction has been shown to be beneficial to healthspan and lifespan in multiple animal models. We have shown that depletion of riboflavin, also known as Vitamin B2, extends lifespan in the nematode worm in a model similar to calorie restriction. This project serves to investigate the mechanisms of how this occurs and whether riboflavin depletion can promote similar benefits in mammals, with the hope of identifying new treatments for aging associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal examines the molecular interactions between cells of the immune system and lung stem/progenitor and mesenchymal cell populations, focusing on their significance in coordinating alveolar epithelial regeneration. Immediate outcomes will be the identification and characterization of leukocyte-induced signals that promote the expansion, differentiation, and function of lung epithelial cells after severe injury. The concepts explored under this proposal will further our understanding of the cellular networks that mediate regeneration of damaged distal lung tissue and have potential broader applications in the development of therapeutics aimed at reversing associated pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over two-thirds of children experience traumatic events such as child maltreatment, violence, or sudden or violent loss, which often results in significant developmental and emotional difficulties. Emotional support from a caregiver is theorized to buffer against the effects of trauma; however, many caregivers lack the self-efficacy and skills to support their child and existing caregiver interventions are lengthy (lasting 8-20 sessions) and result in families placed on long waitlists. The present research addresses this gap in the literature by examining the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of the telehealth delivery of the Project Support Positive Parenting Module, a brief parenting intervention designed to enhance caregiver support, among families on the waitlist for trauma-focused services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) and its components, such as diabetes and obesity, in mid-life are associated with increased risk of cognitive impairment, dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) later in life. In this proposal, we will focus on understanding how mid-life MetS onset disrupts metabolism in oligodendrocyte cells that support neurons to define the mechanism that underlies how MetS leads to neuronal loss in the brain, and ultimately AD, in later life. By understanding the mechanisms that contribute to neuronal loss in MetS- associated AD, we can identify novel, targeted, translatable interventions to reduce MetS-related cognitive decline.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of autism spectrum disorder diagnosis (ASD) has risen to 1 in 54 children in the United States. This project is aimed at identifying potential neurobiological basis of ASD present in the cerebellum, a brain region implicated to be invovled in ASD based on clinical data. Results may provide a description of new sites within the nervous system that are uniquely senstive to perturbations that give rise to ASD and provide opportunities for ASD prediction, prevention, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ketamine, an NMDA receptor blocker, shows promise in overcoming major unmet limitations of currently available antidepressants for treating major depressive disorder, because of its rapid and sustained antidepressant effects. This proposal will determine the influence of GABAergic cellular and synaptic mechanisms in the antidepressant actions of ketamine, and will extend this investigation to additional GABAergic compounds, including ?-GABAA-R modulators. These findings will contribute to a novel hypothesis about how fast-acting antidepressants result in rapid and sustained behavioral changes, guiding efforts to develop a new generation of more specific drugs to treat MDD.

PHR: Project Narrative Variants of the Apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene are associated with risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD). This project will explore the role of APOE variants in the adaptive immune response to pathogenic viruses in AD. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brainstem controls life-sustaining orofacial movements, including suckling, chewing, swallowing, and airway patency, and determining the neuronal circuit mechanisms that regulate these behaviors can provide crucial information to understand more general mechanisms of brain function. Additionally, deficits in orofacial control and the return of primitive oral reflexes in adults, including rooting and suckling, are prominent symptoms of neurodegenerative disease, such as Parkinson’s disease and vascular dementia. Understanding how these behaviors are controlled in the healthy brain can help to identify the cause of these pathologies and how to treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiosyncrasy is a fundamental trait in decision-making that impacts one’s life tremendously, and life-threating, maladaptive choice behavior in neurological/psychiatric disorders might in part stem from malfunctions of the neural circuits controlling idiosyncratic decisions. Recent scientific findings raise a compelling hypothesis that a posterior network in the brain may be central to the control of idiosyncratic choice biases. This project will test this hypothesis and elaborate information processing in the posterior network using advanced computational models and circuit interrogation tools in rodents, the gained knowledge from which will guide future research to identify the neural basis of pathological decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat mental illness depends on our understanding of how the nervous system processes information related to complex behaviors. The research described in this proposal will establish a new system to study how the norepinephrine system alters information processing in the cerebral cortex and how these changes effect decision making. If successful, this work will uncover basic principles of how decision related signals are processed by cortical circuits and how noradrenaline signaling flexibly alters cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glycation is an unexplored non-enzymatic post-translational modification that has only recently emerged as a mechanism of gene regulation. Here, I propose a comprehensive study that will utilize cutting-edge proteomics and gene and metabolic perturbations to understand its biological significance. Importantly, the findings will lead to clinical advancements particularly against age-related and metabolic diseases as well as cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a clear need to train academic physicians and scientists to perform research in gastroenterology in order to sustain the future generations of scientists and to maintain our edge in scientific excellence and innovation worldwide. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) during HIV-1 infection suppresses viral replication and prevents immunodeficiency but does not cure the infection. We have developed a novel genetically encoded humanized mouse model system that enables us to distinguish latent cells from bystander cells and are now characterizing latent cells using single cell genomic profiling of cells, to reveal an unprecedented unperturbed view HIV latency. We propose here to use single cell genomics, live dynamic imaging and spatial transcriptomics to probe how latent cells survive stimuli that can activate the virus and the immune system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I propose a biologically motivated, mathematical modeling approach to understand how neuroimaging and other biomarkers can be used to better understand Alzheimer’s disease biology. I plan to fit mechanistic models to data from 3 cohorts across the age span of Alzheimer’s disease onset: Longitudinal Early Onset Alzheimer’s Disease Study (LEADS) (ages 40-64), Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) cohort (ages 55-90), and The 90+ Study (ages 90+). The long-term objective of this research is to improve our understanding of the age-specific pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s disease, determining the precise relationship between tau and cognition, with the ultimate goal of guiding therapeutic development and trials for Alzheimer’s treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) afflicts approximately one in six Veterans returning from the Iraq and Afghanistan combat arenas. Studies have shown an immune imbalance toward inflammatory reactivity in PTSD patients, and animal models of PTSD have implicated this immune imbalance as a contributor to PTSD following the initial trauma. Currently available treatments for PTSD are only effective in about half of Veterans with PTSD, which underscores the need for alternate treatment approaches. The proposed studies aim to define the immune imbalance in Veterans with PTSD and determine how this can lead to brain inflammation. These studies will also pave the way for novel immunotherapeutic approaches for PTSD as they will explore approaches to restore immune balance, thereby mitigating brain inflammation and its impact on behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We will optimize a unique calcium sensor that can record brain activity in freely-moving mice without any attached optical device to enhance its detection sensitivity for various experimental paradigms. Our optimization pipeline will utilize multiple testing steps, including large-scale testing in vivo, in order to enhance the predictivity of the screening assay. The new sensor will facilitate new types of hypothesis-driven experiments to dissect the distinctive properties of cells that are active in a specific task using either the dynamic recording capabilities of the sensor, optogenetic stimulation, or single-cell sequencing methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The goals of this project are to develop novel dynamic longitudinal functional models and to apply them to the electrocardiographic (ECG) data that are measured repeatedly over time in the Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) study of individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD). We will also develop real-time risk prediction algorithms to identify individuals at high- risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVD). While motivated by the ECG data collected from CRIC study, the proposed methods are general, and can be applied to other electronic health data of different diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggregation of the protein tau is thought to drive several neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's Disease, that lack disease-modifying therapeutics. The goal of this proposal is to gain a comprehensive understanding of how the misfolding and aggregation of tau is controlled by a combination of its sequence and its cellular environment in human neurons. Completion of this proposal has the potential to provide unique insight into fundamental properties of protein misfolding in the brain and identify novel therapeutic targets for treating Alzheimer's Disease and other tau-related neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Increased arterial stiffness has been associated with indicators of damage to the brain including presence of white matter hyperintensity, infarctions, brain atrophy as assessed with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Ultrasound is a first-line imaging modality for evaluation of vascular geometry and flow because of its real-time capabilities, but many scanners do not have the capabilities to measure arterial mechanical properties in an accurate, quantitative manner. Successful completion of this project will characterize the relationship between ultrasound-based measurement of carotid artery mechanical properties and MRI measured indicators of brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This R37 competing renewal application is to use an established experimental model of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) to characterize the mechanisms of long-term brain white matter (WM) pathology. Using multi- pronged innovative approaches, the proposed research will evaluate impairments in WM insulin/IGF signaling that are critical to survival, maturation, and function of oligodendrocytes (OLs); OLs generate and maintain myelin, enabling efficient neuronal conductivity for cognitive-motor functions. The research plan includes analysis of circulating extracellular vesicles that likely reflect FASD brain WM pathology and responses to treatment and have prospects for clinical application via high throughput non-invasive diagnostics and therapeutic monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a serious public health issue without treatment, although scientists are making genetic discoveries that could lead to new therapeutic strategies. In the Y6-10 funding period, GCAD will assemble and harmonize sequencing data from more than 80,000 genomes as a community resource, and coordinate analysis of these data. GCAD will also assemble and harmonize functional genomics data which will be integral to identifying genes as candidate drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will apply innovative machine learning methods to develop clinically-relevant computational models which analyze genetic and morphological signatures of Crohn’s disease to objectively and accurately predict specific outcomes of disease. This work is needed because predicting clinically-relevant outcomes of this debilitating autoimmune inflammatory disease at the time of diagnosis is currently impossible. Successful completion of this work will establish a bench-to-bedside machine learning platform which uses clinical metadata along with deep features of Crohn’s disease from patient-derived biopsies, thus improving clinical management of one of the most chronic, costly, and consequential diseases in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health While there have been many advances in the treatment of liver cancer over the past half century, approximately 85% of patients with this disease will die within five years of diagnosis. Integrated time nanosecond pulse irreversible electroporation (INSPIRE) is a new cancer therapy which uses ultrashort electrical pulses designed for the treatment of inoperable liver cancers. This proposal aims to develop the instrumentation and protocols necessary to implement INSPIRE clinically and demonstrate the safety, efficacy and reproducibility of the treatment in a relevant spontaneous large animal model of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We have identified a gene (stathmin-2) whose expression is suppressed in almost all examples of the fatal paralytic disease ALS and half the cases of the second most frequent dementia (frontotemporal dementia or FTD). We now seek to determine what stathmin-2 does to support neuronal regeneration, how its expression is controled, and how reduction in it affects motor neuron or cognitive disease. Outcomes of these efforts will provide key insights for understanding basic aspects of axonal and synaptic neurobiology and for evaluating whether maintaining or restoring stathmin-2 is an attractive therapeutic option in sporadic ALS and FTD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders, such as autism, intellectual disability, and fetal alcohol syndrome, often have severe impairments that require lifelong care, resulting in a substantial burden to affected individuals, their families, and their communities. The complexity of these conditions demands an integrated strategy that cuts across traditional research boundaries between the behavioral and basic biological sciences, including the boundaries between animal and human studies, as well as the boundaries between the laboratory and real-world applications. In this postdoctoral research training program in neurodevelopmental disorders, we propose an integrated, interdisciplinary training program that will prepare researchers to interface across disciplines and to make transformative advances for the betterment of individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders.

PROJECT_TITLE: Postdoctoral Research in Neurodevelopmental Disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias are common in older age and strongly linked to diabetes. State-of-the art leadless “patch” ECG and continuous glucose monitoring technology provide novel means to evaluate the link between disordered glucose patterns and the occurrence of cardiac arrhythmias in adults with type 2 diabetes. The proposed project will provide evidence-based guidance regarding how low, high, and variable glucose may contribute to the occurrence of cardiac arrhythmias and subsequent health outcomes in the setting of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance To function appropriately and prevent disease states, all cells in the human body must be able to regulate what proteins they express in response to environmental cues or need. RNA processing, including alternative splicing, polyadenylation and mRNA stability, represent pervasive mechanisms for regulating protein expression and cellular function in response to extracellular triggers. The studies in this proposal seek to elucidate the regulatory pathways and molecular mechanisms by which changes in environment regulate RNA processing, and to determine the consequences of such regulation for maintaining proper cellular function and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative We have discovered a previously unknown signal transduction mechanism in which bacteria deliver the C-terminus of a large exoprotein into the cytoplasm of neighboring cells where it binds to an immunity protein and the complex activates a large mobile element that defines a new class of transposon. In this system, a circular, extrachromosomal intermediate is formed that causes a change in gene expression that results in the induction of cooperative behaviors such as biofilm formation. We plan to determine the molecular mechanisms underlying this contact-dependent signaling and DNA transposition phenomenon and to investigate its link with horizontal gene transfer and the evolution of sociomicrobiological behavior. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Double-stranded DNA breaks (DSBs) can cause gross chromosomal rearrangements, which are the hallmark of all forms of cancer. The overall goal of our research is to study the events that lead to DSB formation and the mechanisms that cells use for DSB repair, in the hope that this research will eventually lead to a better understanding of how might be able to prevent or cure cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A substantial proportion of early psychosis EP individuals show minimal symptom reduction despite receiving the full range of evidence-based practices provided by coordinated specialty care (CSC). Currently, clinicians have no way to predict which EP individuals entering CSC will respond and who will not. In this project we will leverage recent progress in the development of pathophysiologically informed MRI based imaging biomarkers along with novel computational image analysis, to develop a precision medicine tool that can identify early psychosis patients entering CSC who are at high risk for non-response and thereby inform clinical decision making to optimize the recovery of young individuals following the onset of psychotic illness.

PHR: This proposal focuses on abnormal RNA decay pathways that may contribute to neuronal dysfunction and death in the neurodegenerative diseases amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD). Work conducted during the previous funding period highlighted critical connections between the RNA binding protein TDP43 and RNA instability in these conditions; here, we will uncover the mechanism underlying TDP43’s effects on RNA decay, while simultaneously evaluating two promising genetic modifiers of neurodegeneration in ALS and FTLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The regulation of specific genes critical to the storage of memories (“memory consolidation”) and changes in neuronal function (“plasticity”) vital for learning are controlled by a number of mechanisms that are not themselves regulated by genetics. We propose to determine the functional roles of such epigenetic processes in memory consolidation and plasticity, and to define the sets of genes that are activated, in individual cells, during memory consolidation. This research promises to provide information that will be critical to the development of novel therapeutics capable of alleviating the cognitive deficits underlying many psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop a hydrogen deuterium exchange-mass spectrometry approach to examine the assembly and disassembly of SNARE proteins reconstituted in lipid nanodiscs in vitro and engineer a fluorescent sensor to study how the SNARE cycle is spatiotemporally linked to vesicle exocytosis in live cells. Achievement of these goals will provide a new means to answer questions related to membrane trafficking and SNARE pathology that are prevented from being addressed due to shortcomings in current technology. This work has the potential to help study the neuronal and metabolic diseases that arise from SNARE mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Rapidly increasing public health harms of methamphetamine use have been observed among people who use opioids underscoring the need for information on mechanisms underlying motivations for use to inform treatment development. The goal of this project is to rigorously evaluate orexin system regulation of opioid and methamphetamine use and co-use using a behavioral economic demand framework. The proposed project will provide key insights into pharmacological and behavioral mechanisms underlying methamphetamine and opioid use and co-use to guide expeditious development of novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Inflammasomes can distinguish between pathogens and non-pathogenic microbes via the detection of ‘patterns-specific activities.’ This proposal uses an evolution-guided framework to translate novel interactions between the human NAIP/NLRC4 and NLRP1 inflammasomes with the human pathogens Shigella flexneri and Dengue virus, respectively, to generate new, rationally-designed models of human infectious disease and immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of the proposed research is to understand the mechanism regulating microtubule-based transport into and out of axonal branches that are critical to synaptic development and function. Following our recent study of branch development and transport regulation at branch junctions, we will use molecular, imaging, and optogenetic approaches to investigate how transport is selectively routed for functional needs of the branch, especially via novel interactions between microtubule-associated proteins and motor proteins. Results from the proposed study will not only establish a general feature of axonal transport, but also shed lights on the mechanisms critical to synaptic function and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Center for Microbial Pathogenesis and Host Inflammatory Responses (CMPHIR: P20-GM103625) was established at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) in 2012. The underlying scientific theme is that addressing existing and emerging problems in infectious disease in a clinically relevant fashion will require an understanding of both the pathogens themselves and the manner in which they impact the host immunological and inflammatory response. This theme is based on the premise that understanding the complex interplay between diverse pathogens and their common human host is a necessary prerequisite to maximizing opportunities to manipulate one or both sides of this equation in favor of the desired prophylactic and/or therapeutic outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative In a mature mammalian retina, more than forty distinct types of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the important components of retinal circuits and functions, have been described on the basis of their morphologies and functions. By learning how RGC subtypes are regulated by T-box transcription factors Tbr1 and Tbr2, we will obtain new information on the fundamental principles guiding retinal ganglion cell development and preventing them from dying under certain disease conditions, such as glaucoma and ischemic optic neuropathy. Obtaining such knowledge is the important first step to develop novel therapeutic strategy for retinal stem cell reprogramming and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid shunt infections are a frequent complication of the treatment of hydrocephalus and can lead to long term neurologic deficits in pediatric patients. In this proposal, we will study the role of complement in neurologic damage associated with cerebrospinal fluid shunt infection. These studies will provide valuable information on how complement creates neurologic damage during shunt infection, potentially leading to new therapies that will decrease the consequences of infection for patients and improve their developmental outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute liver failure is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. The elucidation of the mechanisms of liver cell death is extremely important in developing new approaches to preventing and treating liver injury. The current work focuses on JNK, a pivotal kinase in stress signaling, and the novel targets of JNK, which have been identified to influence glutathione synthesis, mitochondrial function and oxidative stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Bartel, David P. PROJECT NARRATIVE: The experiments of this proposal investigate how cells determine the amount of protein that is produced from each gene, with a focus on regulatory processes that influence the stability and utility of cellular messenger RNAs. Results from these experiments will provide resources and information needed to better understand the regulation of genes, including genes implicated in cancer, birth defects, and other human diseases. They will also provide insights helpful for those harnessing these gene-regulatory processes to study gene function, as well as those beginning to harness these processes to develop new therapies for treating human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fatigue is a condition frequently reported in a large number of patients with breast cancer, which can be attributed to tumor growth and can be exacerbated by chemotherapy and radiotherapy. There are currently no therapies targeting fatigue in this patient population. This application seeks to provide scientific knowledge of the mechanisms that contribute to fatigue in breast cancer patients as well as identify therapeutic options to treat this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The active sites of central synapses are several times smaller than can be resolved using conventional approaches. Thus, much of what we know about the complex and dynamic processes involved in synaptic transmission has been inferred from indirect electrophysiological and/or biochemical assays. Our innovative nanoscale resolution imaging technology can visualize, track, and quantify presynaptic processes with single- vesicle resolution. We propose a research program based on this technology that promises to close the gap in our knowledge of synaptic transmission, including the role such processes play in the pathophysiology of Fragile X syndrome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main goal of this training program is to continue to develop highly competitive junior scientists into future leaders in rehabilitation research. This goal will be met by taking advantage of a rich academic environment that offers numerous resources and a complementary and collaborative team of basic and clinical research mentors committed to training and career development. The program will continue to teach both predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees how to conduct, and the importance of, integrative research that spans from understanding disease at the cellular level to improving clinical rehabilitation practices.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because retinal detachment due to fibrotic  membrane contraction leads to vision loss in millions of people worldwide every year and  understanding the mechanisms responsible for membrane contraction may lead to the development of  therapies to prevent future vision loss. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Non-specific low back pain is a highly prevalent and costly medical condition often characterized by recurrent, fluctuating or persistent pain and limitations in function over time. In this project we will work to understand the role of impairments in spine movement on the course of recovery of pain and functional limitations after a person experiences acute low back. We also will conduct a study treating the impairments during pain-provoking functional activities in people with acute low back pain seeking care in an emergency department setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Comparative genomics and genetic engineering in model organisms are powerful tools that can be used to understand the biology underlying human traits, diversity and disease. We will study how essential proteins can evolve given the constraints imposed by the often multifaceted functions they perform, including for example, the important drug-target Na+,K+-ATPase, which has repeatedly evolved insensitivity to steroid inhibitors across diverse animals. Our work will yield insights into how new proteins associated with neurological and physiological disorders in humans, like Na+,K+-ATPase, can evolve new functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Damage to the kidney filtration barrier resulting in urinary protein loss accounts for approximately 80% of end stage kidney disease where nearly 700,000 patients in the United States require dialysis or kidney transplantation. Understanding the fundamental biology is a necessity as currently, there is a lack of therapeutic options. In this grant proposal, we plan to elucidate the underlying components required to maintain a normally functioning filtration barrier, so that potential novel treatments can be discovered in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The fastest growing segment of the American population is that 85 years of age and older; these are the people most at risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease: the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease in this group, now 35%, is expected to approach 50% by the year 2050. Research in depression as a risk factor for dementia has concentrated on the younger-old (mean age 74) rather than the oldest-old (80 years and greater); and it has rarely been examined in African Americans, for whom depression is more chronic and severe and the risk of dementia higher. This application will address a critical knowledge gap by investigating the association between depression and cognitive decline in the oldest-old African Americans, and by examining inflammation as a potential underlying mechanism.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The obesity epidemic and its associated complications, including cardiovascular disease are leading health concerns in Veterans. Discovery of the fat-derived hormone leptin generated excitement as a weight loss therapy until it became clear that because of obesity-associated leptin resistance, leptin does not reliably lower body weight in humans with obesity. Oxytocin (OT) is an attractive therapeutic agent to treat obesity because it reduces body weight in diet-induced obese (DIO) rodents even in the presence of leptin resistance, and elicits cardioprotective effects in genetically obese rodents. We will determine if activation of hypothalamic OT neurons elicits cardioprotective effects in DIO mice and whether elevations of heart rate (HR) and blood pressure (BP) in DIO rodents are ameliorated by systemic OT alone or as an adjunct with beta-3 receptor agonists. These findings will direct future studies to test if intranasal OT reverses adverse cardiovascular effects associated with obesity in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the ubiquity of cortical feedback connections and their likely role in neurological conditions including schizophrenia, attention disorders and autism, relatively little is known about their functional role. The optogenetic method used in the project enables the study of cortical feedback without contamination from untargeted brain areas, thus providing a cleaner view of the functional role of feedback than what has been previously possible. Thus, the understanding to be gained in the proposed research is likely to provide insight into these disorders, with potential for public health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this multidisciplinary study is to provide a framework for bilingualism’s effect on the trajectory of healthy aging and Alzheimer’s disease, while accounting for the complexity underlying language experiences, executive functioning measures, and dementia types. The findings will improve care for people with diverse language backgrounds and give important insight into whether speaking more than one language can help prevent or slow the symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blunted or flat facial expression is characteristic of schizophrenia spectrum disorders, associated with negative symptoms and social impairment. However, there are no evidence-based treatments for decreased face expression, which is typically assessed through clinical observation and ratings. We will use computational analyses to quantify and operationalize face expression deficits during open-ended interview, including temporal patterns with speech and pauses, and nonverbal synchrony between participants and interviewers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this application is to continue a highly successful 30-year training program in addiction research. Students will be trained to identify basic behavioral, neurobiological, and pharmacological processes involved in addiction and to translate that knowledge into effective clinical interventions and policy. Prior graduates of this program have done quite well at remaining involved in research, publishing articles on addiction, and becoming independent addiction researchers. We aim to continue this record of training success in the next funding period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Ultrasound imaging is safe, cost efficient, and easily accessible, which makes it an attractive imaging modality world-wide, and the potential for advanced ultrasound to dramatically impact patient care is enormous. However, given that benefits to patients cannot be realized before even the most exciting innovations are successfully converted into clinically available products, it is essential to train the next generation of ultrasound engineers for not only interdisciplinary technology development but also commercial translation of the technologies that emerge. The goal of the UNMUTED predoctoral training program is to provide trainees with the collaboration, technical, and commercialization skills necessary for transitioning advanced ultrasound research and development to commercially available products that meaningfully impact patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Narrative The MRI Resource for Physiologic, Metabolic and Anatomic Biomarkers is an interdepartmental and interdisciplinary consortium combining facilities and expertise of multiple departments and schools at the Kennedy Krieger Institute and the Johns Hopkins University. The goal of this National Center is to develop novel noninvasive MRI candidate biomarkers that can ultimately be used for (i) personalized assessment of patients for diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment monitoring (Precision Medicine), and (ii) expediting the development of new medical technologies and drugs. We will provide training in these new advanced technologies, and disseminate them to other research centers and hospitals in the country and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Sepsis strikes ~ 2 million Americans annually; most of these patients will survive the acute stage of sepsis only to end up back in the ICU, weeks later, with hospital-acquired infections. The objective of this proposal is to rigorously study how sepsis leads to the dysfunction and reprogramming of effector and regulatory CD4 T cells. Our planned studies will integrate discovery approaches (e.g., genomics, metabolomics, proteomics) with hypothesis-driven studies to rigorously study CD4 T cell populations from pediatric and adult septic patients and experimental sepsis models in both SPF and ‘dirty’ mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis and osteoarthritis cumulatively affect more than 40 million Americans and result in annual healthcare costs of more than $50 billion, but remain undertreated because of the limited accuracy of existing tools for risk stratification and disease and treatment monitoring. Recently, CT manufacturers began introducing new ultra-high resolution CT (UHR CT) scanners capable of visualizing details approaching the size of the microstructures of human bone. We will investigate whether the UHR CT scanners, combined with novel image analysis techniques, can provide new information on bone health that will improve diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis and osteoarthritis.

PHR: This TRD will develop new MRI techniques to provide researchers and clinicians with the ability to assess the brain’s physiology, such as blood supply, brain’s oxygen consumption, leakage of blood-brain barrier, blood vessel’s responses to carbon dioxide and blood pressure changes. To achieve these goals, we will develop new MRI techniques and integrate other state-of-the-art technologies. These methods will be made available to a variety of NIH-funded projects led by investigators working on different MRI scanners and for them to study several devastating brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project Narrative The primary goal of the International Society of Addiction Medicine (ISAM) is to organize/present annual conferences disseminating the most current research on addiction medicine in countries with relatively few resources, thereby helping local clinical addiction medicine experts in setting up necessary addiction/clinical medicine services and research. ISAM’s Annual Meeting is unique in its focus on international/cultural diversity and in bringing together a cross-sectional, multi-national group of professionals with a common interest in research, clinical practice and training aspects of addiction medicine. The meeting design allows for input/exchange by all participants and provides a forum that facilitates formal and informal analysis/integration of clinical experience and research findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is extraordinarily relevant to public health. Our human data will provide the foundation for identifying DNA methylation profiles in blood that predict the progression and expression of late onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD). Conventional biomarkers for Alzheimer’s disease are costly, invasive, and must be performed in select locations by specialists, thereby reducing their utility for population-wide diagnosis and prognosis. Accordingly, the present proposal expressly addresses NIA’s mission with the discovery and validation of reliable and practical Alzheimer’s disease blood biomarkers. Blood biomarkers configured for use in primary-care settings will detect deviations from healthy cognitive trajectories over the lifespan, identify modifiable Alzheimer’s disease risk factors and interventions, and coordinate research efforts with an epigenetic metric that integrates heritable and acquired variables that influence aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are functionally opposite metabolic pathways that support systemic glucose homeostasis in humans. This project will map kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the two pathways and elucidate regulatory mechanisms that enable seamless transitions and coordination between them. The resulting knowledge will advance therapeutic development for diabetes and cancer.

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: This TRD will develop new methods to measure biomarkers of brain chemistry using an MRI scanner, both by directly detecting signals from small molecules in the brain (with edited magnetic resonance spectroscopy MRS) and indirectly (using the contact between protons in the metabolites and water) with amplification by detection through the water signal). These two methods will also be integrated using machine learning to benefit from their complementary strengths of detection specificity and detection sensitivity, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer remains a deadly and treatment resistant malignancy in large part due to significant stromal desmoplasia and an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME). This proposal seeks to elucidate if targeting a master regulator of the TME, focal adhesion kinase, can alter the stroma and immunosuppressive TME in order to sensitize pancreas cancer to immunotherapy. By employing a neoadjuvant translational research strategy combined with expert mentorship, hands-on training and intensive didactics, these challenges of pancreatic cancer can be addressed with the ultimate goal of reversing the grim clinical outcomes of patients with this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD) result from embryonic exposures to alcohol and affect 2-5% of school- aged children in the US. The diversity of clinical symptoms including facial dysmorphology, cognitive and behavioral deficits, associated with disorders within FASD make both diagnosis and treatment a challenge. This project will investigate how prenatal alcohol exposure may result in aberrant development of circuits in the striatum and relate to early motor deficits common to both animal models of prenatal alcohol exposure, and FASD patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than half of the 80 million stroke survivors worldwide experience persistent walking difficulties that impact their mobility, social interaction, and quality of life. Ankle joint stiffness and viscosity are fundamental mechanical descriptions that impact an individual's walking ability, yet these descriptions are typically not considered during the clinical decision-making process, primarily due to the lack of understanding of how these properties contribute to post-stroke gait function and the difficulty in assessing them in a clinical setting. The proposed grant will investigate how ankle joint stiffness and viscosity influence post-stroke walking function, as well as establish a new tool to measure these properties easily in the clinic, which will advance clinical knowledge and improve the treatment of individuals post-stroke, and ultimately enhance the quality of life of millions of stroke survivors.

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to design pulse sequences and analysis approaches to efficiently quantify MRI parameters that reflect tissue composition and microstructure. These parameters will be used to synthetically generate multiple image contrasts (synthetic MRI), including conventional ones with which the radiologists are familiar for reading and that currently can be acquired only separately. In addition we will develop methods for high resolution mapping of white matter brain tracts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension continues to grow in the US and worldwide, representing one of the greatest burdens in human health as it contributes to the development of cardiovascular disease and premature death. Four decades of scientific research of enhancing the pGC-A/cGMP pathway has demonstrated its favorable blood pressure lowering and protective biological actions, and thus, represents a novel therapeutic target for hypertension. This proposal aims to advance the biology, as well as to optimize a novel pGC-A small molecule stimulator, engineered by the applicants, with the ultimate goal of providing a new class of drugs to treat hypertension, specifically resistant hypertension, for which there are no approved drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Gastric cancer is a global health problem, especially in Northeastern China. This application is for a collaborative approach harmonizing US and China partners. The US group will investigate basic science mechanisms of genes involved in how precancerous lesions (metaplasias) arise, and the Chinese group will provide appropriate clinical samples of patients with gastric cancer. The Chinese group will also help with sequencing and modeling the tumor-forming aspects of specific genes in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Blockade of the T cell inhibitory receptor PD-1 has revolutionized cancer therapy and is now explored for treatment of chronic viral infection, another condition marked by exhausted immunity. In this project we will evaluate whether and how PD-1 blockade enhances immunity to hepatitis B virus (HBV) in an HBV PD-1 blockade trial. The expected results will dramatically increase our understanding of the molecular response to PD-1 blockade and thus will enable further refinement of these groundbreaking new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: RNAi-related pathways have deeply conserved connections to chromatin silencing in all Eukarya and play important roles in suppressing transposons in animal genomes. Currently, RNAi is under clinical development for numerous indications, and the first RNAi drug is now approved. The genetic and biochemical studies proposed here will advance our understanding of how RNA-guided mechanisms regulate gene expression, and should also provide insights into both new applications for RNAi in probing gene function and for enhancing the therapeutic potential of RNAi drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive and currently incurable disease, affecting up to 1 in 20,000 people and leading to death in a median of six years from diagnosis despite treatment. Abnormal hemodynamic forces play a critical role in the development and progression of PAH but have been difficult to study through traditional methods. Identifying hemodynamic-sensitive pathways involved in PAH will lead to new therapeutic targets for this terrible disease.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The involvement of the immune system in hypertension has been recognized for over 50-years. However, the factors responsible for the initiation of renal immune cell infiltration, and the mechanisms by which immune cells amplify the progression of hypertension, have not been fully elucidated. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Hepatic fibrosis and its end stage, cirrhosis, represent an enormous health care burden worldwide. Understanding the mechanisms of myofibroblast activation is critical for the treatment of hepatic fibrosis, and will advance the field by providing new targets for the anti-fibrotic therapy. The goal of this study is to determine the contribution of activated Portal Fibroblasts (aPFs) to the pathogenesis of cholestatic liver fibrosis in humans and mice, characterize the mechanism of their activation, and identify novel strategies for anti-fibrotic therapy with immunotoxin-conjugated anti-human MSLN Ab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Emerging evidence suggests that a high-fat/low-fiber “Western diet” may promote Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) through modulation of microbiome composition and activity, indicating diet modulation as a potential strategy for CDI treatment and prevention. This work will gain mechanistic insight into the relative contributions of high dietary fiber and low dietary fat in preventing antibiotic-induced gut microbiome disturbance and CDI in mice, and test a higher-fiber/lower-fat dietary intervention for prevention of C. difficile recurrence in individuals with cancer. We will also explore a novel synbiotic treatment for CDI prevention in mice, that includes probiotic treatment with bacteria adapted to a disturbed gut coupled with prebiotic treatment with gluconic acid, a substrate that these bacteria use to produce a health promoting metabolite butyrate. We hypothesize that this treatment will facilitate CDI prevention through the reestablishment of protective intestinal anaerobes in the gut microbiome.
