IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: As the majority of pharmaceutical drugs contain heterocycles, often in the form of azacycles, the ability to prepare these materials in the most rapid way possible is of the utmost importance. The broad availability of drugs is directly dependent on the existence of cost-efficient methods that can reliably build complex molecular structures. The main objective of this proposal is the development of powerful new methods and strategies for the synthesis of heterocycles, employing C–H bond functionalization and other techniques that will facilitate rapid access to valuable building blocks for the synthesis of biologically active compounds and pharmaceuticals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis and septic shock are the leading causes of death in the intensive care units globally. The hyper- inflammatory phase of sepsis gives way to a hypo-inflammatory phase. It is currently difficult to distinguish the phases clinically, and we will develop markers/biomarkers to identify phases and phase-specific therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public health narrative: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) remains a major health problem, globally affecting at least 257 million carriers who are at risk of developing serious liver disease, including liver cancer. Although HBV infections can be prevented through vaccination, chronic hepatitis B can rarely be cured. Here, we aim to mechanistically dissect the steps of the HBV life-cycle that are critical for persistence and could yield new targets for novel antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decades of developmental neuroscience research have illuminated multiple factors that convey risk for the development of substance use disorders (SUDs) at the group level, but the field currently lacks methods for using neurocognitive data to make accurate and generalizable predictions about SUD risk for individual youth. The proposed project seeks to address this critical gap in the field by providing an early-career scientist with the tools and training necessary to test whether the combination of two advanced computational approaches, sequential sampling models of cognitive functioning and network neuroscience methods, improve the accuracy of multivariate predictive models of individuals’ SUD risk. Knowledge from this project could lead to the development of novel computational approaches that optimize the identification of predictive features in youths’ neurocognitive data, which may ultimately inform SUD prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: American Indian / Alaska Native students face some of the largest health disparities in the country and together with other groups, such as those from rural backgrounds are underrepresented in the biomedical research workforce. We utilize an approach that links environmental, animal, and human health under the One Health paradigm to engage students from AI/AN and rural background in meaningful research embedded in a supportive holistic mentoring system and integrated coursework to increase their participation in research education and ultimately participation in the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Toddlers with recurrent wheeze, particularly from low-income urban settings, are at higher risk of developing asthma and suffering long-term consequences of their airways disease. This project investigates how different types of asthma develop over time from ages 2 to 6 years with the objective of identifying critical windows along the airway development pathways that lead to lung dysfunction and disease. These time points are potential targets for interventions that could change the course of the disease, which will advance the goal of preventing asthma and improving child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The liver is known for a remarkable regenerative ability through the proliferation of the main functional cell type of the liver, the hepatocyte; however, in end stage liver disease (ESLD), hepatocyte proliferation is exhausted. To overcome the scarcity of donor livers for transplantation to treat ESLD, promotion of the liver’s own biliary epithelial cell (BEC)-mediated regeneration could provide a pool of functional hepatocytes that replenish the liver, thereby recovering liver function. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the NIH mission, as it will establish new therapeutic interventions to promote generation of functional hepatocytes derived from BECs with VEGFA delivered in the liver via clinically safe non-integrative nucleoside-modified mRNAs complexed to lipid nanoparticles.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE – Cornell Center for Reproductive Genomics (Overall) Infertility afflicts 10% of couples in the United States, 50% of which are due to male factors, predominantly resulting from errors in sperm production, leading to abnormal sperm morphology, inviable sperm, or low sperm numbers. Studies in the current P50 program will critically address the genetic, transcriptomic and epigenomic mechanisms of spermatogenesis and how these crucial gene regulatory events determine sperm quality. An important aspect of the translational approach is to use the basic biology to define new benchmarks and criteria by which to judge the fertilization potential of sperm from men with a high rate of sperm morphological abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative A principal goal of modern human genomics is to identify the genetic variants that contribute to disease risk and to learn about the population genetic forces that govern their prevalence and distribution. However, because global patterns of human genetic variation are shaped by the geography of our evolutionary history, existing statistical methods that ignore the geography of genetic variation are inadequate. To address this shortfall, we propose to incorporate geography into new statistical methods for studying population genetic structure, admixture, and selection, which together will yield new insights into human evolutionary history and the etiology of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While risk for severe infection is known to have a heritable component with offspring of parents who died from infection at a young age having a 6-fold increase in their risk of death from infection, the contributing genetic factors remain unknown. Using whole exome sequencing, this project aims to identify genetic sites of immune variation that associate with the development of sepsis-associated thrombotic microangiopathy and hyperinflammation, phenotypes at high-risk of poor sepsis outcome. This effort will identify specific genotypes that convey risk for poor outcome and may identify outcome-associated mechanisms as potential future therapeutic targets in severe pediatric sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome affects many aspects of human health including aging and response to cancer treatments. Though the microbiome is malleable, we lack the knowledge to rationally manipulate it to modify older adults’ treatment response. This project will define the microbiomes of older adults with lung cancer who best respond to immunotherapy treatment, and use dietary interventions and preclinical models to define how to manipulate the microbiome to increase healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nilotinib is an FDA-approved chemotherapeutic agent that has also been recently shown to improve mitochondrial bioenergetics and attenuate hallmark biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) transgenic mouse models. However, nilotinib’s specific effects based on sex are largely unknown. Furthermore, since, a high fat diet (HFD) exacerbates AD pathophysiology, we propose to test nilotinib in 3xTg AD mice on an HFD to investigate sex-based differences on bioenergetic and AD-related neuropathological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Focal cortical dysplasia (FCD) is a common cortical malformation associated with medically refractory epilepsy and most frequently caused by variants in subunits of the GATOR1 complex (a negative regulator of mTOR): DEPDC5, NPRL3, and NPRL2. The least studied of these variants is NPRL2 and in this proposal we aim to define the pathophysiological consequences of Nprl2 KO in vivo and in vitro. Using a mouse model of FCD we will define the morphological and functional changes that occur due to Nprl2 KO-induced mTOR pathway hyperactivation as well as investigate the transcriptomic changes that occur downstream of mTORC1 that may produce MCD and seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative- Public Health Relevance Statement The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the high rates of opioid use disorder among pregnant people in jail and the need to provide evidence-based treatment in order to optimize maternal and infant outcomes. This project is relevant to NIDA's strategic goals to increase access to opioid use disorder treatment for jail populations, who are at high risk of adverse outcomes, and, with NIDA's recently established Racial Equity Initiative, to address racial inequities in substance use treatment. By conducting research and building partnerships with directly impacted individuals and jail policy leaders, we will promote implementation and dissemination of evidence based treatment for pregnant, incarcerated people that will improve outcomes for them and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has become a global epidemic with its progression to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH; hepatic inflammation) and fibrosis resulting in increased cardiovascular disease mortality and the development of hepatocellular carcinoma. A poor understanding of the underlying causes of NASH and fibrosis has severely limited the development of effective therapeutic and preventative strategies. The project will examine the novel relationship between hepatocyte, Kupffer cell and hepatic stellate cell RECK (Reversion Inducing Cysteine Rich Protein with Kazal Motifs) and the regulation of NASH and fibrosis with outcomes that will improve our understanding of the mechanisms responsible for NASH and highlight potential therapeutic targets for the future treatment of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired macrophage efferocytosis drives important diseases including atherosclerosis, whereas enhancing efferocytosis has therapeutic benefits. We have established a genome-wide CRISPR screen for unbiased discovery of novel regulators of macrophage efferocytosis. This study will focus on Wdfy3, a novel regulator discovered by the screen, for in-depth mechanistic studies on its molecular mechanisms and roles in atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE More than 21 million people in the world suffer from schizophrenia, and they experience a wide variety of symptoms that include distorted perception, such as hallucinations, and disrupted social information processing. This proposal uses naturalistic videos along with two complementary neuroimaging methods to examine how perceptual deficits in schizophrenia, specifically in the language domain, might influence social processing deficits. Understanding the neural correlates of language and social processing during naturalistic stimuli will be a step forward towards finding biomarkers of severe mental illness and ultimately improving patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood sexual abuse has been associated with increased risk for psychopathology, revictimization, and health-damaging behavior in adulthood but the neurobiological mechanisms underlying these outcomes remain largely unknown. The overarching goals of this competing renewal are to (1) improve our mechanistic understanding of oxidative stress mechanisms in these processes risk; (2) investigate links between these mechanisms and two key phenotypes of depression; and (3) identify biobehavioral markers predicting disease course and functioning in the context of childhood sexual abuse. A better understanding of neurobiological underpinnings of abuse-related outcomes will contribute to developing more targeted therapeutic interventions, identifying individuals at risk for psychopathology at a younger age, and preventing revictimization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Precise control of adipose tissue function is crucial in modulating energy balance and glucose homeostasis. This research project will test novel concepts that molecularly distinct subsets of VMH SF1 neurons modulate white adipose tissue lipolysis and brown adipose tissue thermogenesis through different sympathetic circuit pathways, and that Ca2+-permeable AMPA receptor (CP-AMPAR) and tumor necrosis factor-a (TNFa) signals in VMH SF1 neurons contribute to the development of high-fat diet (HFD)-induced obesity (DIO). The information to be collected from this project will reveal expression of specific genes in VMH SF1 neurons modulating iWAT or iBAT, and demonstrate that attenuating CP-AMPAR and TNFa signals in VMH SF1 neurons can be an attractive strategy for the treatment of DIO in HFD-fed mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lung injury as a result of the systemic inflammatory response (SIRS) is a common cause of complications in patients following severe injury. Unfortunately, therapeutics that limit SIRS after injury are lacking, with poor translation of therapeutics from animal models into patients in the clinical setting. Here, we will identify the function and mechanism of action of uniquely human genes that are highly expressed in monocytes/macrophages, define their contribution to human SIRS, and understand how these genes effect therapeutics that target anti-inflammatory signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic abdominal pain is the hallmark symptom of chronic pancreatitis (CP), with opioids remaining a mainstay of therapy. Lacosamide, an FDA-approved anticonvulsant, may inhibit the phenomenon known as opioid-induced hyperalgesia, potentially lowering the opioid dose necessary for adequate pain relief. In this proposal, we will evaluate the safety, tolerability and dose-limiting toxicity of combination lacosamide and opioid therapy in CP patients as well as the feasibility of performance of this phase 1 study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to establish a novel therapeutic target for breast-cancer metastasis by dual targeting cancer cells and immune cells. We propose to use Proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) technology to target pro-survival BCL-XL protein, which leads to the apoptosis of metastatic cancer cells and Tregs. Using in vivo models and fresh cancer specimens, we will determine the mechanisms of targeting BCL-XL in metastatic control and immune regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A group of 22 faculty researchers at The City College of New York (CCNY) proposes to leverage a position of research strength in the biomedical sciences, within a large public university in the heart of an underserved community, to address the need for a well-trained biomedical research workforce and the gains to be achieved by improving its diversity. Using a strategic combination of NIH and institutional resources, the G-RISE program at CCNY has the demonstrated capacity to support an average cohort of 13 underrepresented (UR) Ph.D. trainees each year for five years, appointing each trainee for 2-3 years. A coordinated program of stimulating interdisciplinary coursework, rigorous research training, and structured activities to build research identity, ethical values, and career readiness will improve the number and proportion of underrepresented Ph.D.’s who pursue rewarding careers in the biomedical research workforce.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cities;college;New York
PROJECT_TITLE: G-RISE at The City College of New York
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - C[TWD-C]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is associated with deterioration / dysfunction in the endothelial glycocalyx, a major vasoprotective constituent hyaluronan synthesis enzyme (HAS2) and reduction in arterial function. The endothelial glycocalyx and HAS2 may be causal by altering arterial functions, such as the control of vascular tone, large artery stiffening, and inflammation as well as endothelial specific functions such, nitric oxide bioavailability as well as maintenance of barrier function. We will utilize endothelial specific loss and gain of function mouse models to elucidate the role of HAS2, the enzyme responsible for the production of high molecular weight (HMW) HA, a vasoprotective constituent of the glycocalyx, in altering arterial function across the lifespan of mice. We will also interrogate the role of the CD44 receptor as well as the efficacy of dietary supplementation with HMW-HA to improve these aspects of arterial and endothelial function in advanced age.

PHR: NARRATIVE This project will define the role of inflammasome activation in periodontal disease, that is differentially activated between females and males. The long-term goal of this project is to identify the mechanism(s) of inflammasome modulation to control periodontal bone destruction in both females and males. Knowledge on which biological processes prevent periodontal tissues destruction will allow health providers to identify a therapy that matches individual needs rather than a one-size-fits-all approach. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is a predominant secondary complication that affects quality of life and reduces life expectancy in spinal cord injury (SCI) populations. Although sepsis after SCI is an existing clinical condition, this medical issue unfortunately is understudied due to lack of good animal models. Accordingly, the current innovative proposal is designed to develop, for the first time, a novel rat model of sepsis survivors following SCI to study compromised functional recovery as well as damage to various tissue/organ system(s) due to the compounding effects of SCI- sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Copper is an essential trace element utilized by eukaryotic cells as an enzymatic redox cofactor, but at high concentrations the metal is toxic, and complex mechanisms have developed to ensure homeostasis. Prokaryotes have a diminished requirement and increased sensitivity to the metal, and it has been established that macrophages utilize copper toxicity as part of their defense against pathogens while the latter combat the host-defense strategy by upregulating their copper export machinery. Our research seeks a better understanding of how biology leverages the fundamental chemistry of copper to achieve functionality, recognizing that function requires balance between the requirements for selective metalation, the structural determinants of catalysis, and pathogenic virulence induced by robust bacterial export pumps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Thrombectomy is a life-saving procedure that removes clot from the brain during stroke, but it is difficult to predict which patients will recover cognitively and which will have persistent cognitive impairment or decline (VCID: vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia)—and it is particularly difficult to predict these outcomes in rural, underserved patients, who tend to have more complicated medical histories and barriers to care. Using a retention strategy tailored to the needs of rural, underserved participants, the proposed study will test how well certain proteins in blood collected at the time of thrombectomy predict the long-term cognitive outcomes of stroke patients in one of the most rural and medically underserved regions in the U.S. Stroke Belt. Study success would address a major rural-urban health disparity and also benefit stroke patients at large by making available the first long-term cognitive profiles of thrombectomy patients, by improving the assignment to proper care using the earliest possible blood markers for VCID versus cognitive recovery, and by opening the door to development of new therapeutics based on blood protein signaling pathways that affect cognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: New onset postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) is the most common complication after cardiac surgery and substantially affects patient outcomes from the surgery. Our study aims to identify/test the stress-response kinase JNK as a novel POAF biomarker and/or potential anti-POAF therapeutic target. The results from this proposal will form a strong foundation toward achieving our long-term goal of developing novel therapies to treat and prevent AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) is a devastating disease that primarily affects the elderly. Oncogenic NRAS mutations are frequently identified in CMML patients. In the prior funded period, we investigated how the genetic interaction between oncogenic Nras signaling and Asxl1 loss promotes CMML progression and transformation to AML. In this renewal application, we propose to investigate the mechanisms underlying dysregulation of immune microenvironment and evaluate mechanism-based immunotherapeutic approaches in our preclinical animal model. Successful completion of the proposed studies will not only provide fundamental perspectives on disease mechanisms but also test hypotheses that could potentially lead directly to potent and efficacious novel therapies for treating CMML and transformed AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE While current research is underway to identify potential pharmaceutical treatments for preventing excessive alcohol intake associated with dependence, far less attention is given to potential treatments to curb excessive binge drinking, despite numerous negative health consequences associated with this dangerous behavior. Research has established that sensitivity to the aversive effects of alcohol is protective against overconsumption, yet little is known about the neurocircuitry that modulates aversive responses to alcohol. Expected results will provide novel evidence that norepinephrine circuits originating in the brainstem modulate aversive reactions to alcohol and alcohol consumption, offering new insight into treatments that will protect against the transition to alcohol dependence.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to translate innovative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques to image brain oxygen extraction fraction in patients with vascular contributions in dementia, and understand its mechanistic relationship to ischemic injury in white matter hyperintensities. The technology developed and biological knowledge gained from the project will guide new imaging paradigms to measure brain pathophysiology that leads to cognitive impairment, and improve early vascular interventions in many neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will provide important insight on imaging biomarkers for Parkinson's disease by developing new statistical and computational tools for the continuous time random walk model with newly available high spatial resolution MRI data. The goal is to produce reliable and sensitive imaging biomarkers for Parkinson's disease to improve the diagnosis accuracy, which offers prospects for disease diagnosis and treatment. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge in understanding the function of living systems that will help to reduce the burden of human disability and to protect and improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy is one of the most important new approaches to cancer therapy to emerge over the last several decades but is associated with unique side effects that often mimic immune diseases. Recent studies have identified thrombosis (excessive blood clotting) as an important side effect of immunotherapy, however, nothing is known about the underlying causes of blood clots in these patients. The goal of this application is to define these mechanisms using patient samples and a mouse model of blood clots induced by immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Tendons can withstand large forces due to a highly aligned, dense collagen matrix. The overall objective is to delineate mechanisms by which the temporal expression of Col3 modulates the injury response throughout tendon healing, as well as its differential effect throughout aging. We will test the hypothesis that Col3 is crucial for early tendon healing, but that its continued expression during remodeling is detrimental.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue repair requires coordinated protein presentation that is difficult to achieve with current biomaterial delivery vehicles. Using an innovative approach involving directed evolution and rational protein design, we will engineer a library of novel affinity-based biomaterials to investigate the effects of protein delivery and sequestration on tissue regeneration. This work will uncover new insights into the overarching roles of many proteins that govern tissue repair, which will be critical in tailoring biomaterials to treat different types of injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because T2D is a life-threatening disease. Upon conclusion of these studies, we will establish that insulin secretion is regulated by a novel β- to δ-cell dynorphin/Kappa opioid receptor negative feedback loop, and this feedback loop contributes to hyperglycemia in diabetes. These discoveries will stimulate the opening of a new avenue for the design of novel strategies using the dynorphin/Kappa opioid receptor axis as a therapeutic target for the treatment of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation is exquisitely linked to the pathogenesis of immune-mediated conditions. Nanoparticles have risen as a novel strategy to manipulate immune cell responses through multiple biochemical pathways and non-specific and antigen-specific mechanisms. The central vision of my research program is to systematically evaluate the cellular and molecular mechanisms affected by nanoparticles in the context of sepsis (non- specific) and autoimmunity (antigen-specific) to develop fundamental and functional relationships between their physicochemical properties and generated immune responses to ultimately guide the future development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease affects 1 in 9 Americans over 65 years of age, is the 6th leading cause of death, and costs $355 billion annually. Herein, we aim to understand how viruses interact with an aging olfactory system to accelerate Alzheimer's disease. This proposal will identify potential biomarkers and therapies (e.g. vaccines and antiviral agents) that may slow or halt progression to clinical dementia, disability, and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is the most important mosquito-borne disease of humans, but current mosquito control strategies and drug treatments in humans are becoming less effective as insecticide and drug resistance increases. Malaria parasites must acquire essential nutrients, including pantothenate or vitamin B5, from their mosquito and human hosts to successfully complete development. We will suppress mosquito pantothenate stores through a combination of small molecule treatments and genetic manipulations to starve malaria parasites of this essential nutrient to support future, novel mosquito-targeted malaria control strategies.

PHR: Narrative The prevention of HIV in the United States is in a transformational era. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will compile the first comprehensive evolutionary classification of the protein universe by categorizing millions of proteins with accurately predicted 3D structures, enabled by the recent breakthrough in protein modelling facilitated by Artificial Intelligence. Our classification will accelerate discovery and characterization of proteins involved in pathogenicity and human diseases by association of novel and uncharacterized proteins with their well-studied relatives and guide experimental studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Crosslinking and bundling of thin filaments are responsible for the assembly of higher-order F-actin structures that support the unique cell structure, provide the scaffold for intracellular molecules and organelles, and, importantly, generate the force for membrane protrusions underlying cell motility. The proposed study investigates how actin bundling by fascin1 molecules enables the guided development of axonal projections for proper writing of the nervous system, and regulates the specific synaptic connections in the adult hippocampus. The work is directly relevant to public health concerning brain development and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Abnormal activation of inflammasomes can initiate undesirable inflammatory responses associated with the progression of chronic inflammatory diseases. Nanomaterials that are used to target immune cells at the disease site to modulate immune responses have been shown to non-specifically activate inflammasomes potentially exacerbating the disease, however this is poorly understood. The central vision of my program is to perform a comprehensive understanding of nanomaterial properties that drive inflammasome activation and the mechanisms behind their activity for their effective use across a variety of biological applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Despite its position as a leading cause of maternal death and major contributor to maternal and perinatal morbidity, there is no effective drug treatment to prevent preeclampsia (PE). At present, the only effective treatment for PE is early delivery of the baby and placenta. Based on recent studies and on preliminary data presented in this application, we propose that the NLRP3 inflammasome is a novel therapeutic target for the treatment of PE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Receptors for a brain peptide called nociceptin/orphanin FQ (NOP) show promise as targets for new, more effective medications for alcohol use disorder (AUD), which are desperately needed. Using behavioral procedures and brain imaging techniques we will characterize the relationship between NOP receptors and alcohol consumption in monkeys, and will test potential medications in a highly translational model. Taken together, the results of these studies will provide novel, clinically relevant information to support NOP receptors as targets for new medications for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance While isolated aspects of substance misuse are improving, such as tobacco cessation and opioid prescribing practices, enormous service gaps persist that allow the ongoing and enormous negative impacts of risky and problem substance use. Further, these negative impacts place a particular burden on gender and ethnic minorities and other disadvantaged populations and communities. The proposed conference will bring together a multidisciplinary gathering of approximately 300 experts in diverse related fields including substance abuse treatment, epidemiology, prevention research, HIV risk, health services research, health disparities, primary care, psychology, social work, and industrial and systems engineering. Conference organizers aim to increase research capacity by increasing the level of collaboration between established investigators and we will specifically encourage involvement by more junior researchers with particular focus upon recruitment of scientists from underrepresented gender and ethnic minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE E. coli bacteria are known to utilize surface fibers called type 1 pili to bind to the bladder surface during bladder infections. We have discovered that these pili are also important in causing kidney infections, and we have identified a receptor to which the pili bind. In this project, we will study how this binding allows kidney infections to be initiated, develop ‘molecular snapshots’ of the binding interaction, and determine whether this receptor is important for E. coli binding in other body sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal will explore the role of long non-coding RNAs in epigenetic chromatin remodeling mechanisms associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The major goal is to investigate how the long non-RNA Neat1 initiates cell-type specific transcriptional programs in response to AD pathology. These studies will lead to a better understanding of long non-coding RNAs in hippocampal function in AD and can result in novel epigenetic-based therapies to improve cognitive dysfunction in AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Diaphragmatic hernias and cardiovascular malformations are serious birth defects. In this study, we will use bioinformatics and mouse models to identify genes that cause these birth defects and to learn how they work. These experiments will help us to understand how the diaphragm and heart form prior to birth and may ultimately lead to new ways of treating or preventing these birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: TNF (tumor necrosis factor) is a critical innate immune response gene that has a profound impact on a number of autoimmune and infectious diseases outcomes. We have discovered long-range regulatory elements, which control expression of TNF in a cell-type specific manner. Understanding how these elements control TNF gene expression will provide fundamental knowledge about the regulation of TNF and potentially other genes and we expect will lead to novel and specific therapeutic strategies for autoimmune and infectious disease where TNF causes immune pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a common and deadly scarring lung disease for which there is no cure. The development and progression of IPF proceeds when myofibroblasts – scar forming and contractile cells that differentiate from fibroblasts – fail to de-differentiate following lung injury. This proposal seeks to investigate the mechanisms by which myofibroblasts can be de-differentiated and cleared – thereby enabling fibrosis resolution – as well as to support the career development of a promising and committed physician scientist.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address high unmet need for postpartum family planning (PPFP) in Rwanda, we developed and pilot tested our `C4' intervention (informed by Couples/clients, Clinic providers, Champions, and Community health workers), which significantly increased the use of PPFP in government clinics. We now propose to use an implementation science framework to test the hypothesis that C4 is adaptable to large-scale implementation, cost-effective, and sustainable. C4 could dramatically reduce unintended pregnancy and abortion and improve birth spacing and maternal and newborn health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: (No changes from Original Proposal) The treatment of human disease is highly dependent on efficient synthetic access to the nitrogen-containing small molecules that constitute the majority of pharmaceutical agents. The need for greater efficacy, safety, and selectivity in new treatments drives increases in molecular complexity, creating urgent need for new synthetic methods to prepare the required compounds. To meet this need, this proposal aims to develop new methods to construct complex, nitrogen-rich molecules by developing new reactions of highly oxidized nitrogen compounds and supporting technologies to enable their use.

PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because genetic and acquired diseases affecting the airways pose major disease and economic burdens. This proposal takes an innovative approach using novel gene addition and base editing gene therapy strategies to correct cells lining the airways of a large animal model of cystic fibrosis. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal seeks to understand the impact of perinatal organizational factors, those created by the intersection of maternal and neonatal care in birth hospitals, on the care and health of mothers and infants. Focusing on the organizational structure of level of care (the risk-based services available at a hospital for mothers or infants) and the organizational culture of patient-centered care (the extent to which care is respectful of, and responsive to, individual patient preferences, needs and values), I will assess whether and how these factors interact to influence perinatal outcomes. Understanding the implications of perinatal organizational structure and culture is critical to improving the care and outcomes for the more than 3.5 million mothers and their infants who are born in the United States each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed precision perioperative analgesia platform and two case studies in children undergoing major surgery as well as nursing mothers following cesarean delivery in five CTSA hubs have transformative public health relevance. This collaborative CTSA application will overcome barriers in translating precision medicine evidence to perioperative practice settings as well as achieve the best-in-class post-surgical pain and opioid- related outcomes in millions of children undergoing painful surgeries and women undergoing cesarean delivery every year, by proactively identifying patients at risk for opioid-related serious adverse effects, risk of persistent surgical pain and opioid dependence, and personalizing opioid use with precision dosing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Multiple studies hypothesize that environmental factors in utero program patterns of fetal and infant growth that result in increased susceptibility to hypertension (HTN) early in life. We found that transplanted hematopoietic stem cells from embryos exposed to vitamin D deficiency in utero are capable of transferring HTN to vitamin D-sufficient adult mice. In this application we will explore the role of the genetic program induced in macrophages by vitamin D deficiency in utero in the development of HTN, and whether antenatal vitamin D supplementation in humans and rodents reduces HTN in the offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 100.8 PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV testing and service uptake are infrequent among people who inject drugs (PWID) in the United States. In partnership with a community-based syringe service program (SSP), this project will develop the SSP-based “Prevention Ambassadors” (PA) intervention to promote HIV testing and service uptake among PWID via the secondary distribution (i.e., peer delivery) of HIV self-testing (HIVST) kits with local HIV service information and referrals to HIV service navigation in the social networks of SSP clients (i.e., PWID). The PA intervention will then be piloted to assess its preliminary effects, acceptability, and feasibility among PWID in the Ending the HIV Epidemic priority jurisdiction of Riverside County, California.

PHR: Project Narrative The National Academy of Medicine and two recent National Institute on Aging and National Institute of Health sponsored workshops on geriatric palliative care reported extensive national data from multiple settings and disease categories of a high prevalence of physical, psychosocial, and financial suffering associated with serious illness for older adults and their caregivers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-operative care is a time when excessive opioid prescribing occurs which can result in unnecessary harms, particularly to older and frail adults. Without a clear plan for reducing excessive opioid prescribing at hospital discharge after surgery such as with an opioid taper, opioids are often continued, which can result in unnecessary harms. This project will test the effectiveness of an EHR-embedded, provider-facing, patient-specific, discharge opioid taper support (DOTS) intervention to reduce excessive post-operative opioid prescribing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Single-cell genomic tools provide excellent opportunities to survey the gene regulatory programs during mammalian development. This proposal aims to develop both experimental and computational technologies for multi-modal single-cell analysis of epigenome and transcriptome from mammalian germ cells. The proposed project will not only provide novel technologies for analysis of cell-type-specific regulatory programs from complex tissues, but will also uncover the underlying principles controlling mammalian germ cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity produces a variety of adverse medical, economic and psychological consequences. Unfortunately, weight lost in lifestyle change programs is usually regained. This project will contribute to new insights about the reasons why, aiding in the development of new interventions to improve the durability of weight lost in lifestyle change programs for obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Sustained weight loss of 10% reduces the severity of many of the medical problems associated with obesity such as diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure and fatty liver. However, weight loss causes changes in energy metabolism and hunger that cause many people to regain lost weight. This study is designed to identify the physiological and molecular bases for these changes in persons with overweight/obesity by detailed prospective analyses of metabolism and food intake in a one year period following 10% weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative With a prevalence of 6.2 million people and 1 million new cases diagnosed each year, heart failure continues to be one of the most frequent principal diagnoses for hospitalization, and a leading cause of death in the United States. Many of these hospitalizations are the result of inadequate self-care manifested in patients with heart failure as nonadherence to treatment recommendations and healthy lifestyle behaviors (e.g., medication taking, low-sodium diet, symptoms monitoring, physical activity). This study addresses a critical gap in our understanding of the potential use of consumer mobile health technologies and individually tailored text messages to improve self-care adherence and reduce mortality and morbidity in patients with heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer (CC) remains a significant problem worldwide and women living with HIV (WWH) have higher rates than the general population. Women living with perinatally transmitted HIV (WWPHIV) seem to be especially vulnerable even if they have received the HPV vaccine. This study will examine HPV vaccine effectiveness and will examine several tests to see which ones are best to screen HPV vaccinated and unvaccinated WWH including WWH so that no woman with cancer will be missed and at the same time, to make sure there are few false positives tests (that is they have a positive test but no disease).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Understanding the neural mechanisms underlying decision-making is important because patients with many psychiatric disorders make mal-adaptive decisions, impacting many cognitive executive functions, including emotion and mood regulation. This grant studies how neural representations in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex mediate two types of decisions that commonly occur in everyday life but have rarely been examined in the laboratory: decisions in novel situations that rely on generalizing from past experience to the new one, and decisions that rely on being able to flexibly generate new responses to familiar stimuli. The mechanistic insight from these studies promises to be critical for understanding pathophysiological processes in a broad range of psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Chronic kidney injury represents a major public health burden worldwide. This grant investigates the role of dysregulated mitochondrial electron transport-dependent tricarboxylic acid cycle metabolism in the pathogenesis of chronic kidney injury. Studies proposed under this grant will provide novel and fundamental insights into the metabolic functions of mitochondrial electron transport in kidney physiology and pathogenesis, and ultimately aim at identifying metabolic targets that can be exploited therapeutically for the prevention and therapy of kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The developing visual system undergoes a postnatal period of synaptic refinement when neural circuits are structurally and functionally established. Our work will reveal how key divergent neural circuits within the primate retina reach functional and synaptic maturation in the postnatal period. Our findings will provide novel insights into the developmental trajectory of postnatal maturation for primate retinal pathways, thereby contributing to our understanding of visual dysfunction that arise from developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Horizontal gene transfer is the movement of genetic material between organisms that differs from vertical transfer, the usual way of transmission from parents to offspring. While it is prevalent in bacteria, it occurs only rarely in multicellular animals. We are investigating the ways in which it can re-shape the evolution and biological properties of metazoans capable of capturing genes from representatives of other kingdoms and domains of life, and the means by which genetic information can be transferred through the well-protected metazoan germ line.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Excess fat can accumulate ectopically in the liver and muscle, has negative metabolic consequences, and differentially impacts specific racial/ethnic subgroups of older adults. This project seeks to measure plasma lipidomics (>1000 lipids) and use existing computed tomography scans of the abdo- men to provide a better understanding of the biology of muscle and liver adiposity among Black Caribbeans, Black Americans, and White Americans. This study will provide evidence of lipid pathways associated with muscle and liver adiposity and differences in these pathways among individuals of varying degrees of African admixture to help elucidate important racial disparities in health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To accurately assess the risk of Airborne transmission of viral respiratory diseases, we need to not only identify the route of transmission (droplet or aerosol) for respiratory viruses but also whether the viruses are infectious (“viable, live”). This proposal presents a novel instrument for assessment of the different transmission modalities by separating airborne virus-containing particles by size and collecting them into liquid medium to conserve their viability, with the goal of determining the preferential particle sizes containing infectious viruses. Successful development of the proposed sampler will result in a powerful tool that allows better understanding of how viral respiratory diseases are spread through the air.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This study seeks to discover the reason patients with long COVID suffer from persistent chest pain symptoms. Using advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), this study will determine: (a) whether MRI accurately and precisely detects blockage in small blood vessels supplying oxygen to the heart in long COVID patients; (b) whether the said blockage is the cause of persistent chest pain symptoms in long COVID patients; (c) whether the said blockage resolves better if patients undergo therapy. Our findings will inform future clinical trials aimed at preventing and/or reversing persistent chest pain caused by long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in executive functioning (EF) disproportionately impact children living in poverty and increase risk for psychopathology, particularly disruptive behavior disorders. This randomized clinical trial seeks to determine whether childhood EF, assessed across neural and behavioral units of analysis, is an experimental therapeutic target that can be directly modified through caregiver participation in the Chicago Parent Program (CPP), if increases in EF predict reduced disruptive behavior trajectories in low-income children over a short-term follow-up period, and identify which CPP-driven parenting skill improvements are the most influential in modifying EF. This work will contribute new knowledge as to whether a cost-efficient parenting intervention, developed for and with low-income families raising young children in poverty, can modify EF, a neural- behavioral mechanism implicated in risk for childhood disruptive behavior problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will determine whether deletion of a Parkinson disease (PD)-associated, regulatory sequence from an intron of the PD gene, alpha synuclein, influences disease onset or severity, in a novel, engineered mouse model. We will characterize the histological, non-motor and motor phenotypes of the model, in the absence and presence of established genetic and cellular insults known to elicit clinical symptoms and progressive dopamine neuronal loss in mice. Our work will reveal the pathological relevance of this sequence and inform the mechanistic role of PD-associated regulatory variants in modulating PD risk, severity and progression, and highlight new avenues for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) is responsible for the majority of craniotomy-associated infections, where it forms a biofilm on the bone flap that is recalcitrant to antibiotics and evades immune clearance. Combined infection and injury from the surgical procedure leads to a mixture of pathogen- and damage-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs and DAMPs) in the local tissue environment, which are both sensed by triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-2 (TREM2). This proposed research will investigate the molecular and metabolic mechanisms by which TREM2 mediates an anti-inflammatory immune cell response and S. aureus immune evasion to promote biofilm growth.

PHR: Project Narrative Regulation of blood pH within a narrow window is necessary to sustain life. We recently uncovered a novel and consequential role for a kidney receptor (Gpr116) to modulate how the kidney regulates blood pH. In these studies, we aim to better understand the role of Gpr116 in the kidney by uncovering the mechanism by which Gpr116-mediated regulation of pH occurs, and, by discovering how the activity of Gpr116 is regulated and controlled.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex interactions between physiological systems, as seen in the gastrointestinal, immune, and skeletal systems’ response to prebiotics, require systems approaches to integrate the many interconnected processes. This project combines experimental and computational systems approaches to explore how a dietary prebiotic can be used to regulate the gut-bone axis in estrogen deficiency. Project results will provide new insights into the immune system’s response to prebiotics and will produce a predictive mathematical model for mechanistic effects of the immune system in the gut-bone axis that will enable future optimization of prevention and treatment strategies targeting the gut for osteoporosis and other conditions associated with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJEC NARRATIVE  The root cause for the majority of cases of congenital heart defects (CHD) cannot be explained by current research. There is an established risk for alcohol use during pregnancy resulting in CHD without mechanistic understanding of how alcohol disrupts heart development. This fellowship will allow for investigation into a large, modifiable CHD risk factor, paving the way for therapeutic and preventative interventions to reduce the leading cause of newborn death and driving cost for pediatric hospitalizations.

PHR: Project Narrative The program for the Environment Section at the 2023, 2024, and 2025 American Public Health Association Annual Meeting and Expos will benefit students. In particular, we aim to support underrepresented students defined as those coming from underserved populations, underrepresented institutions, or communities underrepresented in the field of environmental health in terms of economic, racial/ethnic, or other demographic characteristics. This funding would allow scholarship recipients the opportunity to discover the latest science, policy and practice in the field of environmental health; learn about efforts to address the health impacts of environmental exposures; network with leaders and peers in the field; and present their own work in environmental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Rooted in colonialism, historical trauma, and structural racism, American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) populations experience major disparities in substance use and related adverse outcomes—particularly AI/AN Veterans—but these disparities remain vastly understudied. Our team of Indigenous and non-Indigenous researchers and our rich foundation of substantial upfront investment from NIDA via a parent R01 create a unique opportunity to add an unprecedented and community-engaged line of inquiry into substance use and its treatment among AI/AN Veterans to support culturally-appropriate intervention development. We will conduct community-partnered clinical epidemiologic and qualitative research to inform development of a culturally appropriate and strengths-based intervention that addresses substance use among AI/AN Veterans in clinical settings and can be tested using a Hybrid Type I design to inform effectiveness and implementation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nemaline myopathy (NM) causes skeletal muscle weakness primarily presenting at birth or early childhood. NM diagnosis, clinical treatment and basic science research typically focuses on the muscle breakdown component of the disease without considering the inputs needed for muscle function. This proposal aims to understand the molecular changes in communication leading to muscle contraction prior to the muscle breakdown seen in NM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most mental health disorders arise during adolescence, with depression being one of the most consequential given its long-term effects well into adulthood. The proposed study aims to determine if a child’s genetics and their family socioeconomic status interact to shape longitudinal changes in emotional brain and behavior development that could ultimately increase their risk of depression using a large, diverse nationwide sample of U.S. youth between the ages of 9 to 12 years. Ultimately understanding how these two concepts interact will help policy makers, clinicians, and scientists better detect, alleviate, and treat the burden of depression for individuals and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative It is thought that homologous recombination (HR) and fork protection (FP) deficiencies produce points of vulnerability in cancer cells that sensitize them to DNA damaging agents such as to cisplatin and Poly (ADP- ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors (PARPi), but our recent findings indicate that single stranded DNA (ssDNA) gaps are the killing lesion such that gap suppression (GS) deficiencies could sensitize cancer cells to therapies. BRCA2 is required for GS thus by studying therapy response in the model system of BRCA-deficient cancer, in which distinct mechanisms via separation-of-function models have been linked to resistance, we will have the opportunity to determine if instead resistance is also or solely mediated by GS, a question that has yet to be addressed. This goal of this study is to systematically disrupt and retain each function (HR, FP, GS) within BRCA2 to define what function is critical for therapy resistance, elucidate a unified mechanism of resistance, and provide insight into inhibiting pathways of resistance to inform therapeutic choices.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Healthcare-associated infections (HAI) and antibiotic-resistance (AR) increase patient morbidity and mortality. The proposed work will lead to new strategies for preventing HAI, AR and other adverse events in all types of healthcare facilities in the United States.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-004: Prevention Epicenters Program: Protecting Patients from Infections, Antibiotic Resistance andOther Adverse Events

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is important for public health because it will allow us to prevent spread of infections by improving the equipment healthcare providers wear, and by reducing environmental contamination. This proposal will also enable us to: 1) expand surveillance by harnessing a novel cell phone technology to identify infections acquired in hospitals that become symptomatic after patients are discharged and 2) identify both patients at high risk of becoming septic while hospitalized and factors we could modify to prevent this serious complication. Moreover, the proposal will enable us to decrease the risk of antibiotic resistance and the incidence of antibiotic side effects by improving antibiotic prescribing overall, in urgent care clinics, and at the time of hospital discharge.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK20-004: Infection Prevention and Antimicrobial Stewardship: Minding the Gaps: The Iowa Prevention Epicenter

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ultimate aim of this project is to develop a novel pharmaceutical treatment that will produce efficient and safe on-demand voiding in people with bowel and bladder retention disorders due to spinal cord injury and diseases such as multiple sclerosis, diabetes, and complications of aging. Many people with these disorders rely on daily digital bowel programs and multiple daily bladder catheterizations as surrogates for voluntary defecation and urination. This grant will fund the completion of FDA-mandated nonclinical studies that will enable submission of an Investigational New Drug Application for future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress is a common pathological thread in many neuroinflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). To date, there are no treatments for the prevention of neurodegeneration caused by innate immune-mediated oxidative injury in MS. The goal of this project is to determine the epigenomic mechanisms underlying oxidative stress gene activity and function in toxic innate immune cells in MS models, which may provide therapeutic candidates for intervention of MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fundamental abilities, such as keeping track of where we are, or forming episodic memories during social experiences, critically depend on the continuous processing and encoding of spatial information about the self, others, and the environment. Impairments in these abilities are among the hallmark symptoms of Alzheimer’s and other neurological diseases. The proposed research therefore aims to enhance our understanding of the neural mechanisms that underlie the encoding of spatial information and awareness of others, which will ultimately help elucidate the neurophysiological origins of malfunctions in these systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is among the leading cause of pediatric death secondary to pneumonia worldwide and requires rapid and sensitivity diagnostics. We propose a novel, rapid, sensitive method for RSV diagnostics by digital nanobubble detection in a gold nanoparticle-based diagnostic assay. Success of this project will address a significant problem that affects infants and children in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A properly functioning cellular immune response is essential to the eradication of infectious diseases and cancer, whereas inappropriate cellular immune regulation results in debilitating autoimmune conditions. Given that cellular immunity plays such a critical role in the disease process, a better understanding of the innate regulatory mechanisms governing cellular immunity would allow for the formulation of novel vaccine and pharmaceutical interventions that would enormously benefit human health and well-being. Completion of the work outlined herein will permit the immunoregulatory role of a critical basic factor, the novel gene product AIMp1, to become fully elucidated thereby enabling a) simpler production of more effective and less-expensive vaccines and b) the characterization of new druggable target interactions that will form the basis of the next generation of pharmaceuticals for the treatment of cancer, infectious disease, and autoimmune conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Bacteriophages, the viruses of bacteria, are now emerging as important alternatives to antibiotics, as the era of multi-drug resistant bacterial infection is beginning. This proposal seeks to deepen our understanding of how phages accomplish the destruction of the bacterial cell. In addition, by studying the ways in which phages can attack the bacterial cell wall, fundamental new clues to the design of new antibiotics are likely to emerge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The foreign body reaction (FBR) to material implants was first described in the 1970s yet continues to induce implant rejection. With the proportion of people over 60 years old doubling from 12% to 22% by 2050 there is a critical need to better understand how chronic inflammation alters the FBR which will enable biomedical engineers to improve implant design. The overarching goals of this proposed work is to identify key biologic factors to target to develop immunomodulatory synthetic materials for use in the aging population for tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise is one of few treatments shown to benefit adults with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Yet, exercise is one of the most challenging treatments for adults with HFpEF to start and continue over time. This study tests two behavioral interventions, Heart Failure Exercise and Resistance Training (HEART) Camp (in-person) and HEART Camp Connect (virtual), designed to promote adherence to exercise and improve physical function, inflammation, symptoms, and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Transgender women of color experience systemic racism and transphobia, which contributes economic vulnerability and HIV inequities. The proposed R34 application seeks to adapt and evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a microeconomic intervention designed with and for transgender women of color to improve HIV prevention and care continua outcomes. The proposed approach will provide the necessary groundwork for an efficacy trial in a future, large-scale randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Preterm birth occurs at unacceptably high rates in the United States, with Black women disproportionately affected. A long-recognized risk factor for preterm birth in this population is the relentless exposure to intersectional stress related to racial and sexual discrimination, poverty, and neighborhood disadvantage that Black women often experience from an early age. In this interdisciplinary study, we bring together experts in preterm birth, music therapy, and metabolomics to address this health disparity by testing the efficacy of a live, culturally based music intervention to reduce the production of metabolites and metabolic pathways associated with chronic stress and thereby improve birth outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uncontrolled asthma in school-aged children is a significant public health problem. Low-SES Latino children are at increased risk for uncontrolled asthma compared to non-Latino white children, and psychosocial stress is an unaddressed factor in this disparity. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Volumetric muscle loss (VML) is caused by the loss of a large portion of skeletal muscle due to traumatic injury, leading to permanent muscle damage. The incidence of VML is becoming more frequent in Veterans as a result of combat. The goal of this proposal is to bioengineer muscle that mimics normal muscle and blood vessel structure as a new strategy to treat VML. The engineered muscle utilizes nano-patterned scaffolds to organize the muscle precursor cells and endothelial cells along their normal arrangement to mimic native muscle structure. The engineered muscle will be tested in mice with VML to test its therapeutic benefit. The proposed studies are highly significant because they seek to improve the health of Veterans suffering from VML using bioengineered muscle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will characterize PD-1 immune checkpoint signaling dynamics in T cells by using quantitative mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomics, single-molecule fluorescence microscopy, bioinformatics, and mechanistic mathematical modeling. A better basic understanding of PD-1 signaling, which plays an important role in avoidance of autoimmunity and escape of cancer cells and pathogens from immune surveillance, has the potential to motivate evaluation of new therapeutic strategies for diverse diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one of the most common casualties in military personnel. Mild TBI accounts for over 80% of all TBI incidents in the active military service members and experiences unrelenting progression of neurocognitive, behavioral and psychiatric deficits. The long-lasting traumatic axonal injury, loss of myelin sheath, and inhibition of oligodendrocyte maturation contribute to motor, cognitive, behavioral, and psychiatric deficits. This proposal will investigate the roles of microglia-oligodendrocyte interactions in white matter injury and tissue repair in experimental TBI models and explore glia-oriented therapeutic strategies for treating TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While approximately 450,000 patients in the United States are treated with life-sustaining maintenance hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease, their mortality rate is unacceptably high, reaching approximately 50% by three years from the time of hemodialysis initiation. Rates of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, including sudden cardiac death, are higher on the days of dialysis and have been associated with higher serum and dialysate bicarbonate concentrations. Our proposal will explore the effect of altering the dialysate bicarbonate on intradialytic hypotension and electrocardiographic changes associated with sudden cardiac death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Polyketides are used more in human medicine than any other class of secondary metabolites, and comprise roughly 20% of top-selling small-molecule drugs. This project advances catalytic methods for the de novo chemical synthesis of polyketides based on hydrogen auto-transfer processes that enable direct stereo- and site-selective conversion of lower alcohols to higher alcohols. Polyketide natural products that possess anti-cancer and anti- bacterial properties are targeted.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral palsy is characterized by a progressive decline in mobility due to gait dysfunction caused by deficits in strength and coordination. This proposal investigates a novel wearable adaptive resistance therapy for improving neuromuscular control and walking outcomes in this patient population. Completion of this work will contribute to a better understanding of the factors necessary for successful rehabilitation of children with neuromuscular impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Local application of antibiotics directly to the traumatic wound is a promising treatment for the prevention of infection after open tibia fractures, which are a significant source of disease burden globally, particularly in low- income countries. This pilot study aims to assess feasibility of a randomized controlled trial to measure the effect of locally applied gentamicin on risk of infection for open tibial fractures in Tanzania. If proven effective, local gentamicin would be a highly cost-effective strategy to reduce complications and disability from open tibial fractures that could impact care in both high- and low-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The promise of nanoparticle (NP) anticancer drugs remain largely unfulfilled due to a low tumor delivery, in which only 5-10% of these agents in the plasma are actually distributed into solid tumors. Thus, there is a strong need to discover methods that can capitalize on the promise of NP anticancer drugs by significantly and safely enhancing tumor delivery, especially in pancreatic cancer (PaCa) that has major inherent barriers to tumor delivery that are associated with high resistance and low response. Our proposal will evaluate if induction minibeam radiation therapy (MRT), in contrast to conventional broad beam radiation therapy (BRT), increases tumor perfusion, and the tumor delivery and efficacy of NPs in PaCa tumor models, as the induction MRT + NP regimen would be an ideal fit for the pre-surgical neoadjuvant treatment of PaCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer disease (AD), the leading cause of dementia, is defined by the buildup of amyloid plaques in the brain made of Aβ protein and neurofibrillary tangles made of tau protein, but many people have high levels of amyloid plaque and no symptoms of dementia; furthermore, clinical trials of medications that showed removal of plaques mostly have not improved dementia symptoms. This proposal tests whether different people have different molecular types of Aβ in their brains, what they might look like under powerful microscopes, and whether different people’s neurons are differently affected by the most toxic forms of Aβ. This work has the potential to improve the design of new drugs for AD, improve clinical trials for existing AD investigative drugs, and identify new targets for future AD drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Adolescence is commonly a time of sub-optimal control of Type 1 diabetes (T1D), with a spike in mean HbA1c levels during the age range between 11-15 years; this deterioration in control is in part due to a rise in insulin resistance and the presence of key psychosocial issues, including family dynamics, peer influence and diabetes distress. We propose a comprehensive two-year study of pubertal children, using state-of-the-art techniques to follow these physiologic processes and explore psychosocial factors, while testing a promising intervention, the Control-IQ version of the artificial pancreas (AP). We hypothesize that the AP will respond to the underlying challenges and blunt the rise in HbA1c, thereby reducing long-term risks of sub-optimal T1D control among adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Episodic memory is a unique type of memory that enables us to mentally travel back in time to re-experience specific episodes that occurred in our lives. During memory encoding, continuous experience is segmented into episodes each encoding a sequence of temporally organized events; however, little is known about the neural circuits that perform computations to segment experience and encode sequential events. Revealing how the hippocampal circuits perform these computations will provide key insights into understanding episodic memory both in health and in pathological conditions such as dementia and Alzheimer’s disease where patients’ life quality is profoundly disrupted due to impaired episodic memory.

PHR: PD/PI Kennard Brunson Abstract Toward urinary catheterization with long-term resistance to bacterial colonization Problem: Catheter Associated Urinary Tract Infections (CAUTI) are common infections in hospitals and health care facilities especially for the disabled and the elderly and infirm with longer catheter indwelling times. To fight CAUTIs, WynnVision LLC has developed “WynnGard-1” silicone, which introduces a robust surface component that reduces bacterial colonization. With no depletion of a leached agent, patented WynnGard-1 silicone has the potential for long term antimicrobial effectiveness. R&D under this Phase IIB proposal will answer FDA concerns and de- risk the technology to make low-cost WynnGard-1 silicone attractive for commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer (PDAC) continues to have an extremely poor prognosis, with the 5-year survival rate of those diagnosed less than 5 percent. A broader understanding of PDAC initiation and the earliest events of disease progression is needed for the development of better early detection methods and new therapies. Our preliminary results suggest specific cells of the adult pancreas may contain a cell of origin for PDAC; the proposed research will utilize a genetically engineered mouse model to interrogate the capacity of these cells to initiate precancerous lesions and cancer, helping us to gain new insights into human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans (AAs) have rates of diabetes mellitus (DM) twice that of Whites and are disproportionately affected by leading risk factors for DM – obesity and low-income. A critical strategy in the battle against DM is the Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP), an evidence-based intervention that significantly delays or prevents Type 2 diabetes through the promotion of diet change, exercise and modest weight loss. However, weight loss from the DPP among AAs is about half that of White participants, and suboptimal AA attendance is a critical contributor. We propose to conduct a study that will address social determinants (SD) that challenge DPP attendance with underserved African Americans from a safety net hospital. We will examine DPP attendance and weight loss with participants randomized to 3 groups: standard DPP, a culturally-tailored DPP to address acceptability, and a culturally-tailored DPP enhanced to address socioeconomic-related barriers to DPP participation. This novel study is the first to tailor the DPP to address SD cultural and socioeconomic barriers that limit DPP attendance and reduce its effectiveness on outcomes. The proposed multidimensional, SD tailored DPP has great potential to be a feasible and scalable model to reduce DM risks among urban, African Americans and ultimately reduce DM disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid and reliable signaling from the cochlea to the brain depends on close interactions between neurons and glia, specialized cells that keep the neurons healthy and directly influence their function. By studying how these critical functional units form during development, we will identify new ways to repair the damaged cochlea, with additional relevance to glioblastoma, inherited hearing loss, and hearing loss that is acquired with noise or age.
