IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The androgen receptor (AR) is a hormone-binding protein that promotes prostate cancer development. One form continues to do so even after patients have been treated to remove the hormone. This project will determine the structural basis for these cancer-causing actions of this protein and pave the way for developing new and more effective treatments, by determining the structures of the complexes it forms with other proteins to increase expression of disease-causing genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study examines whether and how expanded access to affordable housing through rental assistance programs can improve type 2 diabetes self-management and control, ultimately reducing existing socioeconomic and racial disparities in diabetes outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Program is directly relevant to child health and development in training the next generation of scientists who will generate the advances essential for improving the quality of life and survival rates of children and adolescents with gastrointestinal, liver and nutrition-related disorders. Further, this training program represents an investment in the future of public health in general, as the multidisciplinary, intensive and innovative training provided by this Program will educate the leaders, teachers, and professional role models who will determine the direction and contributions of American medicine domestically and throughout the world, particularly as relates to pediatric gastroenterology, hepatology and nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The best predictor of obesity is having a mother with obesity, but the biological mechanisms that underlie this relationship are unknown. Using urinary and stool samples in addition to data from dyads stratified by maternal pre-pregnancy body mass index category, we will determine which biochemical pathways contribute to the development of childhood obesity. Further, we will be able to determine if those pathways differ according to maternal pre-pregnancy BMI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which includes conditions such as emphysema, is the fourth leading cause of death in the United States. New treatment/management options emerged recently (June 2018) when the FDA approved endobronchial valves (EBV) as a Breakthrough Device for the treatment of severe COPD. The goal of this proposal is to develop more robust, and quantitative criteria to identify patients that are likely to respond to EBV implantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We recently identified a novel structure in the airway lining of mice and humans. The cells in these mounded structures, which we have named hillocks for their shape, resist severe injury and act as stem cells that repair the lining of the airway. We propose to study the regulation and function of hillocks to understand how to promote airway repair and understand the role of hillocks in disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered two new sperm incubation methods based on the regulation of intracellular calcium and metabolic pathways; these methods improve sperm functional parameters which increase the percentage eggs that can be fertilized in vitro and also improve early embryo development and pregnancy rates. From the basic science perspective, this proposal is aimed to understand at the molecular level how intracellular calcium and metabolism interact to enhance sperm function. From the applied point of view, accomplishment of these goals will provide tools for improving current Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) methods including in vitro fertilization and early embryo development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This training program will develop young scientists and physician-scientists interested in working transplantation, at the interface between basic science and clinical application, as outstanding independent investigators with a broad understanding of the basic and translational sciences that form the foundation of this field. The Harvard Medical School environment encompasses all aspects of transplantation, from the most basic laboratory investigations to clinical applications in the operating room, and therefore provides a unique opportunity for training in this area. To accomplish this important goal, we have assembled an exceptional faculty team with diverse and complementary research interests, a successful record of collaboration, and a commitment to the training of young investigators.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Transplantation Biology

PHR: Overall Program -  Narrative (Genetics and Biology of Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma)    Pancreatic  cancer  will  be  the  second  leading  cause  of  cancer death  in 15  years and  remains  incurable.    This  program project aims to identify therapeutic intervention points through various state- of- the- art technologies and  animal modeling. The goal remains to gain sufficient understanding of PDAC genetics and biology to inform the  implementation of effective therapeutic combinations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project 1 -  Project Narrative  Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest cancer types in the United States with no effective therapy developed  to date. During our previous funding cycles, this research project in close collaboration with our P01 team has  elaborated the function of KRAS, the central driver for pancreatic cancer, and identified essential roles of the  crosstalk between tumor cells and their environment for the support of cancer- relevant growth. In this next cycle,  this project will continue to work with our Projects and Cores in a highly integrated fashion to perform in- depth  studies on the role of the tumor immune microenvironment in the regulation of KRAS- dependence and response  to immunotherapies, with a goal of rapidly translating our basic discoveries into clinical trials that will eventually  benefit pancreatic cancer patients suffering from this dreadful disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE & PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT A thorough characterization of a patient’s tumor upfront provides better outcomes, i.e., better insight affords higher survival rates. In contrast and almost anachronistically, PET imaging (the most sensitive and quantitative imaging method) is “monochromatic” as it can only assess one parameter at the time, lacking depth of information. However, the new paradigm of multicolor PET enables quantitative PET acquisitions of up to four different radiotracers at the same time, allowing us to visualize multiple targets with PET simultaneously, providing in depth mutiplexed information without increase in dose, time and cost as exemplified by interrogating the tumor microenvironment and immunotherapies for clinically relevant signatures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hair cells of the inner ear are responsible for detection of sound and motion. Loss of hair cells is a major cause of hearing and balance disorders. The results of hair cell loss are permanent as the adult mammalian organ of Corti - a mosaic of nonsensory supporting cells and sensory hair cells - does not have the capacity to regenerate hair cells, and currently, there is no treatment capable of arresting or reversing this hearing loss. In this proposal, we determine the role of epigenetic factors in the regeneration of hair cells. The results could lead to new treatments for these debilitating conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project 2- Narrative During the previous funding cycle, our work established general principles for metabolic reprogramming in PDAC, revealing therapeutic insights that show benefit in the clinic and dramatic effects in preclinical models. In this next cycle, we will address the role of mitochondria and various concurrent gene mutations in influencing cancer cell metabolism and its interplay with the tumor microenvironment. Understanding these key roles will enable us to most effectively exploit metabolic vulnerabilities of PDAC and lead to effective therapeutic development for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project 3 -  Narrative    The current treatment options for pancreatic cancer are not able to significantly impact the clinical outcome of  our patients, so new strategies to unravel the biology of pancreatic cancer and identify new therapeutic modalities  are urgently needed. We discovered a new vulnerability in pancreatic cancer cells that can be exploited to control  cancer progression, consisting of a unique type I collagen variant and a?3b?1 integrin signaling axis specific to  cancer cells. This new target can be combined with therapies designed to unleash the anti- tumor immune  response and suppress the altered metabolism of cancer cells in PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The electrical activity of local networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in the brain is important for regulating many aspects of behavior, including learning and memory storage. Mutations in HCN1 ion channels, which are strongly expressed in cortical neurons in the brain, have recently been implicated in both epilepsy and schizophrenia. To provide insight into the physiological function of HCN1 and its malfunction in disease, we will examine how normal and mutated HCN1 channels regulate the cellular, synaptic and behavioral contributions of a major class of inhibitory neurons that is of known importance for normal and abnormal brain function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fertility requires many levels of interaction between males and females – at the level of gametes and their fates in the reproductive tract and at neural/behavioral levels – and their ultimate success varies dramatically with the genotype of the male and female involved. This variation affects the likelihood of a particular male siring offspring with a given female, due to interactions between male and female components that impact the handling of sperm within the female, and the regulation of genes in her brain. Our proposed studies with a tractable and sensitive model system will uncover the extent and mechanisms by which genetic variation can alter reproductive outcomes, and how these can be predicted analytically for given pairs of interacting animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The majority of deaf children experience a period of limited exposure to language (spoken or signed), which has cascading effects on many aspects of cognition. The goal of the current project is to understand how children build a vocabulary in sign language, and whether and how this differs for deaf children who have limited exposure to a sign language. These data will be made publicly available to researchers and practitioners interested in sign language vocabulary development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death worldwide among people living with HIV/AIDS, and drug-resistant TB HIV is increasing in South Africa. Medication adherence and retention in care are critical components of the care continuum and predict TB cure and survival. This proposal seeks to understand local barriers and determinants for adherence and retention in South Africa, implement an innovative community-based intervention, and evaluate the effect of the intervention on clinical outcomes and patient barriers to adherence and retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional tissues and organs are generated during embryonic development by the movements and behaviors of cells. The work we propose will greatly enhance our understanding of how individual cell behaviors are coordinated to help generate complex tissue structure. Because the basic cell biological mechanisms are highly conserved from flies to humans, this work will shed light on how improper regulation of these processes results in disease states such as birth defects and cancer and may enable new therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative This project directly addresses the family planning goals of Healthy People 2020. It does so by investigating the impact of increased access to contraception provided by the Colorado Family Planning Initiative on reducing fertility, especially of young women, and on women's and men's later economic outcomes and human capital accumulation. Its results will contribute to establishing evidence-based policies to promote health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a serious, potentially life-threatening disorder affecting the blood vessels of the lung, which can lead to heart failure. Its causes are complex and not well understood. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is a related inherited abnormality of the blood vessels that can lead to serious bleeding, including strokes, and can also cause PH. This study will characterize the genetic changes that predispose to PH and HHT, and test new therapeutic approaches to correct these defects. The long term goals are to better understand what causes pulmonary vascular disease and who is most at risk, in order to improve diagnosis, identify new therapies and work towards disease prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to dissect the roles of tissue-resident CD4 helper T cells in the development of protective mucosal immunity following influenza infection or immunization with a “universal” influenza vaccine candidate, Nanovax. In addition, this application is designed to use genetic approaches to test whether selective promotion of tissue-resident helper T cell responses will simultaneously boost mucosal memory B cell and T cell responses following influenza infection or after immunization with Nanovax.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The fields of reactive sulfur species (including hydrogen sulfide, sulfane sulfurs, hydrogen polysulfides, persulfides, etc.) have been rapidly growing in recent years. Understanding their fundamental chemistry and property is the prerequisite for understanding their physiological and clinical potentials. In this R35 application, we plan to establish a research program focusing on these sulfur species. We will study the chemistry and chemical biology of several representative species including hydrogen sulfide, persulfides, and polysulfides. Four distinct projects related to their generation, detection, reactions, and uses are proposed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The neurotransmitter dopamine plays critical roles in circuits that generate voluntary movement and process rewarding stimuli; because these circuits have large influence on behavior, affect, and cognition, dopamine signaling is targeted for the treatment of many neurological and psychiatric diseases, including Parkinson's Disease, schizophrenia, attention disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. We will use a powerful experimental model - a microscopic animal that uses dopamine to generate simple behaviors - to discover genes required for the proper regulation of dopamine release and to determine how dopamine causes lasting changes in neural circuits that control behavior. Understanding the molecular and circuit mechanisms required for dopamine signaling will advance understanding of diseases linked to dysfunction of dopamine signaling in the brain and will generate opportunities to develop new approaches for their treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human population history is of importance to public health because it determines the genetic variants that individuals and populations inherit, which in turn make some people more or less susceptible to disease. The exponential increase ancient DNA data—from 0 genomes a decade ago to more than 10000 today—creates extraordinary new opportunities, but methods for analysis have not caught up to the data. This grant will support the development of a complete toolkit for using ancient DNA for studying biology and history, and in addition to papers describing these methods and their application, will produce two major resources: publicly available software and a high quality reprocessed version of the world's ancient DNA data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interferons (IFNs) exhibit important antitumor effects in vitro and in vivo and play key roles in the immune surveillance against cancer. We have identified a novel signaling mechanism activated by the Type I IFN receptor, involving the kinase ULK1. This IFN-controlled signaling cascade is unrelated to the effects of ULK1 on autophagy and was previously unknown. The proposal will precisely define the role of ULK1 signals in the induction of the biological effects of IFNs in myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) and will identify upstream and downstream effectors of the pathway. Ultimately, the studies of this proposal can lead to the development of novel approaches for the treatment of MPNs and other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who experience hot flashes are at greater risk for hypertension and other cardiovascular disease. Neurovascular control mechanisms are likely to play an important role in this relationship. As such, these studies are designed to provide a major step forward in understanding the link between hot flashes and neurovascular dysfunction and, by extension, cardiovascular disease in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Patients with ulcerative colitis often develop folate deficiencies and require supplementation with folic acid. The cancer preventive properties of folic acid remain controversial and few studies have focused on its activity in the setting of inflammatory bowel disease. An in-depth analysis of the impact of folic acid supplementation (high dietary intake) on risk for colitis-associated colorectal cancer is essential to ensure its safety and inform guidelines for its use in patients with ulcerative colitis who are known to be at increased risk for colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to define the physiological role of a novel adipocyte-specific protein CLSTN3B in determining the lipid storing capacity of adipocytes and the detailed molecular mechanism underlying this function. The knowledge obtained from this research is relevant to public health because factors affecting the lipid storing capacity of adipocytes are closely associated with an individual’s susceptibility to developing metabolic complications as a result of extra-adipose lipid deposition under the condition of caloric overload. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIDDK’s mission of seeking fundamental knowledge about endocrine and metabolic diseases and using that knowledge to improve people’s health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The inductive and morphogenetic processes that establish the vertebrate body plan during gastrulation must be coordinated in space and time to ensure normal development. We are investigating the molecular mechanisms through which the key regulators of gastrulation, including Gpr125 adhesion G Protein- Coupled Receptor, Wnt/Planar Cell Polarity and Dachsous, interact to coordinate gastrulation movements with embryo patterning. We will also take an unbiased genetic approach to identify new essential regulators of gastrulation. As mutations in the components of these pathways cause miscarriages, birth defects and diseases, our studies can advance their understanding, diagnosis and facilitate development of therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder, a disease affecting endogenous reward pathways in the brain, has a significant economic and social impact both globally and within the United States. In this proposal, we investigate an epigenetic mechanism in the medial habenula of the endogenous reward pathway related to the reinstatement of drug-seeking behavior. The medial habenula is an understudied region of the reward pathway, and investigating the epigenetic mechanisms in this brain region will shed new light on reinstatement (relapse-like behavior) and potentially identify novel mechanisms to target therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of patients with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) who receive CD19-directed immunotherapy ultimately fail therapy, with down-regulation or loss of the CD19 target on B-ALL cells as a prominent cause of failure. To offer alternative treatment options to these patients, we have developed genetically-engineered human immune T cells targeting the B-cell activating factor receptor (BAFF-R) on B- ALL cells, and will conduct a first-in-human trial in patients who have failed prior CD19 therapy. To further improve patient outcomes, we are also developing bispecific T cells targeting both CD19 and BAFF-R to cut off tumor’s escape routes and prevent the re-emergence of malignant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed research will investigate the impact of THC on extracellular vesicle signaling in the brain and periphery. It is predicted that extracellular vesicles will contain differential profiles of cargo in response to varying THC exposures and in the presence of nicotine co-exposure. By providing fundamental insights into novel extracellular mechanisms with THC, findings from these studies may thereby identify biomarkers and targets for the development of efficacious therapeutics to treat dependence in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung diseases account for most of the leading causes of death in the United States and the rest of the world. Despite the need for further lung research targeted broadly at basic and clinical levels, there is a national shortage of clinically-directed scientists. This grant aims to fund a program to train postdoctoral scientists in both adult and pediatric research programs, to invest in the future of lung-related research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative: Anti-hemangiogenesis and anti-lymphangiogenesis based therapies can be used as a platform to develop drugs, that can be used to prevent or regress the growth of blood and lymphatic vessels, which are involved in the treatment of Limbal Stem Cell transplantation, cancer, organ transplants and many other disorders. The goal of this project is to elucidate how Limbal Stem Cell Deficiency injury affects corneal HA and LA in VEGFR1, R2 or R3 knockout background in order to develop molecular strategies for treating pathologic corneal disorders with dysregulated HA and LA. Through these observations, we hypothesize that a dynamic balance of multiple anti-angiogenic and anti-lymphangiogenic factors as well as inflammatory cells modulates corneal avascularity, and these factors might be regulated by vascular endothelial cell receptor VEGFR1 or R2 and lymphatic endothelial cell receptor VEGFR2 or R3.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Many communities near military and industrial sites have drinking water with high PFAS concentrations, yet the potential health risks associated with these exposures are not well understood. This study will contribute to the understanding of the impact of perinatal PFAS exposure on immune function in early life, specifically, antibody transfer through placenta and milk and immune response to vaccination after birth and the underlying mechanisms. Study findings will not only help address community concerns at Pittsboro, NC where drinking water were heavily contaminated with PFAS, they will have widespread implications on our ability to understand potential effects of elevated PFAS levels on health and inform policy and clinical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The potent survival effects of the GFL family of growth factors have led to their development as therapeutic agents for the treatment of diseases and injuries of the nervous system. Likewise, small molecule inhibitors of p75 are currently being developed for the treatment of neurodegenerative disorders. Therefore, and understanding of the mechanisms of action of the GFLs and p75 will aid in the further development and refinement of treatment regimens based on the use of GFLs and p75 inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A vast amount of biology occurs at interfaces formed by cellular membranes. However, due to the complex and dynamic composition of cellular membranes as well as their inherent capacity to change shape, it has been difficult to study how these interfaces regulate cellular processes. We will use a battery of complementary, biophysical approaches combined with cellular imaging and computational models to manipulate and understand conserved signaling nodes operating at membranes and orchestrated by PLC- isozymes to draw general conclusions applicable to diverse cellular processes occurring at biological membranes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Since mitochondria are essential organelles that provide energy to cell and coordinate general metabolism, inherited or acquired defects in mitochondrial functions cause severe diseases often affecting the brain and causing premature death (mitochondrial encephalopathies). The overall mission of this proposal is to improve our understanding of mitochondrial encephalopathies by identifying and harnessing new mechanisms, such as cellular stress responses, that can be used to control the pathological events that occur in affected cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Venous thromboembolism is a major public health crisis. It annually affects ~1 million people and is responsible for >100,000 annual deaths in the US. Patients may develop recurrent disease and suffer debilitating long-term morbidity. Its economic impact is estimated to be as high as $69 billion per year in the US. Available anticoagulants are associated with a significant risk of bleeding which limits their clinical use. The goal is to develop safer anticoagulants by inhibiting human FXIIIa to effectively prevent/treat the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of this study is to define the long-term impact of coronary artery bypass graft surgery with venous grafts or all-arterial grafts on health-related quality of life and symptom burden among men and women and patients with diabetes and without. The results of this study will build the evidence about the risks and benefits of coronary artery bypass graft surgery, thus influencing future treatment recommendations and clinical practice guidelines. This will lay the foundation for shared decision-making tools to communicate risks and benefits to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the genetic basis of common diseases, such as cancers, heart disease, or even response to vaccinations, is essential to realize the broad benefits of personalized medicine. Despite rapid progress in genomic technologies, there are many gaps in how different types of genomic and phenotype data are integrated and analyzed to gain knowledge. The goals of this Maximizing Investigators Research Award are to develop novel statistical and computational methods to integrate different types of data, provide useful software tools to the scientific community, and apply new methods to existing data sets to better understand the genetic basis of human diseases and traits and predict disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the maintenance and transmission of Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), a potentially devastating foodborne pathogen. The focus on how STEC infect humans is aligned with NIAID’s E. coli priority area. Characterizing local STEC transmission systems will facilitate the development of targeted disease control interventions, with the ultimate goal of mitigating the burden of STEC in our population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 2021 09, Hite, Naloxone Parachute: Novel Wearable Dual Sensor Regional Oximeter to Detect Opioid-Induced Hypoxia and Enable Emergent Naloxone Rescue NARRATIVE: We are developing a wearable Opioid Overdose (OOD) Diagnostic device, that will decrease the time from OOD to recognition by bystanders, and therefore decrease time to resuscitation (and possible naloxone administration), with a goal to reduce the fatality rate of OOD in the ambulatory setting. A discreet biosensor device that detects life-threatening OOD with on-device logic and alarms locally, without wireless connectivity needed, is a fundamental improvement in patient safety because it removes all risk of connectivity (e.g. wearable device to mobile-device of User, and then to cloud for data analysis and response, introduces many opportunities for error), and enables patients to be rescued in a variety of circumstances where wireless connection may not be present to transmit the acute event (basement, car, etc). The addition of an adjunct (not required for device function) wireless alert, to people who have been specifically selected by the device User, adds an additional opportunity for intervention in OOD, giving agency to loved ones to act in case of an emergency (they may be nearby, or can call 911) - expanding the opportunities for intervention improves the likelihood of preventing fatal OOD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The first goal of this proposal is to define mechanisms of unisexual reproduction of the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus and how this reproductive mode controls population structure and diversity, production of infectious spores, and pathogenesis. The second goal is to elucidate how the RNAi pathway, which we discovered is activated during sexual reproduction, silences transposons and repetitive genes, and the consequences of RNAi loss in hypermutator strains and outbreak species with regard to genome stability, emergence of drug resistance, and pathogenicity. The Cryptococcus pathogenic species complex encompasses ~10 eukaryotic species that have a significant impact on global public health and afflict both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients causing life-threatening infections of the lungs and brain (pneumonia, meningoencephalitis); together these species are responsible for >220,000 infections each year, and more than 181,000 deaths worldwide resulting in >15% of all HIV/AIDS-associated deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms that control calcium entry through store-operated calcium channels (SOCs), a unique type of ion channel present in nearly every cell in the body. Mutations that inhibit SOCs lead to multiple disorders in humans, most notably a lethal combined immunodeficiency syndrome that underscores the essential role of store-operated calcium entry for immunity and survival. The proposed studies will contribute to a fundamental understanding of the intricate pathways that regulate these channels and processes they control, and may also reveal new targets for drug development, with the goal of enhancing function in individuals with compromised immunity, or inhibiting immunity to treat autoimmune disease or prevent organ transplant rejection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Increased survival rates of medically fragile infants lead to an increased number of children with functional impairments later in life. Early detection of motor delays or impairments provides the opportunity for early treatment which improves health outcomes. This study will use state of the art sensors combined with machine learning approaches to develop objective, accurate, easy-to-use tools for the early scoring of deficits and lays the foundation for the early prediction of physical disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian genome is arranged around large, nuclear compartments, and this genome organization provides an important layer of gene regulation. In tauopathies, nuclear speckles, which are membraneless compartments enriched in splicing factors, are perturbed, leading to defects in splicing. This work will identify chromatin in proximity to nuclear speckles in mature neurons as well as neurons with tau aggregates, which will improve understanding of gene expression and splicing defects that occur in tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel approaches are needed to characterize the tumor immune microenvironment (TIME) to identify novel biology and determine the TIME features that relate to clinical outcomes. Multiplex immunofluorescence (mIF) combined with automated image analysis is a widely used technique which allows for the assessment and visualization of the TIME. In this research, we will develop and test novel statistical methods to analyze mIF data that incorporates the spatial heterogeneity of the TIME, in addition to abundance measures of immune cells, whereby producing freely available software for the research community. The novel methods will be applied to the study of epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC), the deadliest gynecologic malignancy in the U.S., using existing mIF data from ~2,500 diverse EOC patients. An ovarian-specific immunoscore predictive of survival will be developed which can be used in patient stratification efforts to optimize therapeutic efficacy and ultimately, reduce cancer mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain after surgery that lasts more than 3 months is termed chronic postsurgical pain (CPSP) and occurs in up to 50% of patients, contributing to an epidemic of chronic pain that has a greater annual societal cost than that of cancer, heart disease, and diabetes combined. It is currently unclear how much of a role genetic variation has on the development of CPSP, and which genetic mutations are significant. The goal of this proposal is to identify genetic factors that predispose patients to develop CPSP and influence the response to pain therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Of the nearly 1 million people in the United States with multiple sclerosis (MS), 80% experience chronic fatigue and two-thirds describe fatigue as their most troubling symptom. While Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) for fatigue reduces the impact of fatigue on daily activities in people with MS, it is not widely accessed in the private sector. The proposed project seeks to identify the active ingredients of CBT for MS fatigue in order to optimize it for efficacy and efficiency to improve access to an evidence-based intervention and reduce the impact of fatigue on daily functioning in people living with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the recent WHO and CDC endorsement of the shorter, all-oral BPaLM treatment regimen for drug resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB), simple, rapid molecular diagnostics for pre-treatment drug susceptibility testing are crucial for ensuring this regimen is used appropriately and new resistance to these drugs is prevented. The objective of this project is to develop and evaluate the performance of a novel, culture-free, single amplification sequencing solution for the detection of DR-TB for all legacy and new/repurposed drugs with known molecular targets (specifically isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, amikacin, moxifloxacin, bedaquiline, clofazimine, linezolid, and delamanid). The technical and clinical knowledge gained from this project will translate directly into our goal of achieving an automated “sample-to-answer” sequencing system that can be deployed closer to the point of care than current sequencing diagnostics, and with significantly lower costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are pervasive and enduring environmental contaminants; and yet, despite the fact that they have been shown to interfere with human hormone systems and potentially cause cancer, there have been no significant, large-scale studies of their possible relationship to breast cancer. The goals of this project are to determine: a) whether exposure to these chemicals is associated with risk of developing breast cancer; and b) what the biologic effects of exposures to these chemicals are in normal human breast cells, in the blood of healthy women, and in women with breast cancer. This proposed research project will advance our understanding of the role of environmental chemicals in the development of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is a lethal brain cancer with no effective treatment available due to its high heterogeneity and ineffective immune cell composition, which still remains uncharacterized especially during radiation and chemotherapy treatment. We will use advanced technologies in single cell analysis to determine the composition, activation and localization of the immune cells of GBM in patient samples and in mouse models that recapitulate features of human GBM before, during and after treating the animals with the same standard of care that patients receive. This research will uncover new information on how tumor cells and immune cells react to radiation and chemotherapy and interact with each other, which we will leverage to design new treatment modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative We will monitor five gastroenteritis viruses both in children hospitalised with diarrhoea, and in wastewater from 11 treatment plants in nine provinces of South Africa. We will characterise the strain diversity of adenovirus, norovirus and rotavirus, which cause the most severe disease. We will determine which norovirus strains children are exposed to between birth and 2 years of age as well as the functionality of their antibody response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We propose that the development of liver disease associated with diet-induced obesity (i.e., non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, NAFLD) may be enhanced by vinyl chloride exposure, even below levels that are overtly hepatotoxic. We have demonstrated that VC increases the diet-stimulated inflammatory response in the liver via causing ER stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. The project will focus on this underappreciated risk- modifier and the detailed organelle-related mechanisms of liver injury caused by the interaction of VC and diet in experimental NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activation of the integrated stress response (ISR), a conserved signaling network that restores protein homeostasis by regulating protein synthesis, is emerging as a main causative mechanism underlying the memory deficits in a wide range of cognitive disorders. By using a novel human-based mouse model and a multidisciplinary approach that combines mouse genetics, molecular biology, electrophysiology, pharmacology, chemical biology and behavioral studies, we aim to define the precise molecular, cellular, and circuit mechanisms by which activation of the ISR leads to cognitive dysfunction. By providing new fundamental insights into the mechanisms by which inhibition of the ISR reverses cognitive dysfunction our studies could lead to the development of new treatments for cognitive disorders resulting from perturbation of protein homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kidney transplantation remains limited by a critical shortage of donor organs and suboptimal graft longevity due to alloimmune injury. Targeted delivery of gene therapies to improve function and longevity of donor kidneys has become feasible through the use of ex vivo machine perfusion platforms. This approach has significant potential to improve long-term outcomes in solid organ transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruptive mutations in the gene CHD8 (Chromodomain Helicase DNA-binding protein 8) are risk factors for autism spectrum disorder (ASD), a complex chronic neurodevelopmental disorder associated with life-long morbidity and increased mortality. Converging lines of research implicate dysfunctional basal ganglia circuits, particularly the dopaminergic system, in the core symptoms of ASD, and preliminary data indicates that CHD8 is a potential regulator of these circuits. The studies proposed in this application will integrate state-of-the-art single nuclear transcriptomics and cell type specific functional genomics, with electrophysiologic, optogenetic and behavioral probing of animal models of CHD8 haploinsufficiency to close a critical knowledge gap in the role of CHD8 in dopaminergic circuitry, thus providing insight into the biological underpinnings of ASD biology to inform future translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence suggests that dysregulation of the habenula, a region of the human brain that acts as a key node of reward circuitry governing motivated behavior and mood, is associated with both drug addiction and psychiatric disorders. In this application, we will generate a molecular neuroanatomical map of human habenula at single cell and spatial resolution and define genetic changes in this region across depression and opioid use disorder. These data will be used to better understand the molecular correlates of substance use and comorbid neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Toxoplasma gondii is an important human pathogen that causes life long infection in millions of people. To achieve efficient transmission to the next host, T. gondii must maintain a balance between replication and development into dormant forms that evade host immunity. We are studying central mechanisms that regulate the transition from proliferative tachyzoite to latent bradyzoite state of the parasite responsible for currently incurable chronic toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Podocytopathies are glomerular diseases that harm the kidney filter and are the culprit in many kidney diseases, such as minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and diabetic nephropathy. Proper understanding of how podocytes work, and how they regulate their actin cytoskeleton in health, disease and recovery, will allow us to develop better therapies for these diseases. In this proposal, we will apply a set of novel imaging approaches, including super- resolution microscopy, a newly developed membrane-extraction electron microscopy technique, and a novel method of visualizing primary podocytes in culture, to investigate some fundamental questions regarding the podocyte actin cytoskeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons receive hundreds or thousands of synaptic inputs on their dendritic trees; each input can change the voltage slightly, and all of the voltage changes are added up and amplified in complex ways to determine if the neuron will generate an output. Observing this process of electrical integration is difficult because dendrites are small. In this project we will test the ability of advanced microscopy techniques and new fluorescent voltage sensors to reveal this process in action in the intact brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metrics by which induced tissue damage during histotripsy – a non-invasive, ultrasound based, mechanical tis- sue ablation modality – can be monitored in situ during treatment do not currently exist. This project seeks to develop such metrics, as well as strategies for monitoring them in situ, by measuring the acoustic cavitation emission (ACE) signals emitted by the histotripsy-generated cavitation events during therapy, and correlating features of these ACE signals with material properties and damage induced to targeted gel phantoms and tissues in ex vivo and in vivo settings. Developing metrics to assess induced tissue damage, and to monitor them in situ, are vital for ensuring histotripsy treatment efficacy and for securing future FDA approval for histotripsy’s clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a common neurodegenerative disorder affecting more than a million patients in the USA alone, and currently there are no treatments that can halt or slow down the disease progression. The nuclear receptor Nurr1 is essential not only for development and maintenance but also for protection of midbrain dopamine neurons from inflammatory insults, rendering it a promising drug target for PD. Based on our recent data identifying synthetic and native ligands that can interact with the ligand binding domain of Nurr1, leading to its activation, we will systematically investigate how these ligands regulate Nurr1’s crosstalk with genetic and environmental risk factors of PD (e.g., -synuclein and neurotoxin) and whether they can translate into future therapeutic development for neuroprotective and disease-modifying treatment of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The recent surge in misuse of prescription opioids as pain killers and the easy accessibility to illegal opioids, such as heroine and fentanyl, have contributed to the current epidemic of opioid overdoses. Better treatments of opioid use disorder (OUD) are urgently needed to produce long-term recovery and avoid relapse of drug use in vulnerable individuals. However, our knowledge of how opioids affects different brain systems during disease progression is limited. Here, we will use single cell genomics to define how different cell types in the brain respond to opioid use during different stages of disease progression in a rodent model of addiction.

PHR: Project Narrative The ASPIRE project aims to improve patient safety for individuals using high-risk immunosuppressive medications. The proposed research will contribute novel information about emerging patient safety errors, rigorously evaluate a registry-based healthcare quality measurement program, and create the first toolkit to address ambulatory patient safety for immune-mediated diseases.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Numerous research projects utilize large electronic health record datasets containing standardized codes, without tools to assess if the codes are used consistent with their intended use. We have termed this consistent use of the codes as representational semantic integrity. Because violations of representational semantic integrity will propagate errors in subsequent large scale data analyses of patient records, the proposed project will develop and validate advanced statistical and machine learning methods to assess and improve representational semantic integrity in large clinical databases.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving health data quality by assessing and enhancing semantic integrity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Rhode Island proposes creating the URI ESTEEMED program to provide academic enrichment, develop research skills, and support a dynamic scholar community to encourage individuals from diverse backgrounds to pursue further studies and careers in bioengineering and related fields. The URI ESTEEMED program will nurture freshman and sophomore students from underrepresented backgrounds through a multi-year training program in which they gain invaluable experiences and skills enabling them to participate in mentored research and self-identify as researchers and bioengineers. With this comprehensive support strategy, URI ESTEEMED will develop a cohort of diverse students who possess the technical and soft skills necessary to excel in advanced research programs and ultimately pursue Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D. degrees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Crohn’s disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which affects nearly 1 million Americans. Several classes of immune suppressive therapy are approved for the treatment of CD but patients will often fail several classes of therapy before finding an effective medication. The proposed research will advance our understanding of transcriptional, genomic, and clinical predictors of anti-IL-12/23 therapy response allowing for improved selection of first-line therapy, which in turn may reduce costs associated with unnecessary biologic exposure and disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancers commonly exhibit dysfunctional redox resulting in elevated reactive oxygen species which can damage cellular DNA, especially the telomeres. Cancer cells must maintain their telomeres to survive and proliferate, and many achieve this by upregulating the alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) pathway, which relies on homology directed repair to restore telomeres. ALT is typically associated with aggressive cancers and poor prognosis. This proposal will advance our understanding of how oxidative damage in the telomeres regulates ALT activity and modulates telomere structures involved in ALT. Ultimately, this knowledge will be useful for developing new strategies that deplete telomeres to halt dividing malignant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Patients who survive the acute phase of intracerebral hemorrhage have the potential to recover but also face a high risk of complications such as recurrent stroke. The risk of ischemic stroke is especially high in those with atrial fibrillation. The use of anticoagulant therapy to prevent further prevent brain injury in this vulnerable patient population has the potential to prevent recurrent stroke, reduce disability, and improve survival. As a result, this work is directly relevant to NINDS's mission of reducing the burden of stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Epilepsy is a serious chronic neurologic condition that affects over 50 million people worldwide, and the most common form of focal epilepsy, temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), is frequently resistant to medical treatment resulting in significant neurologic and psychiatric morbidity. Recent research has shown that genetic mutations that arise after conception (somatic variants) may disrupt normal cellular function in the brain and cause neuropsychiatric disease. This proposal will examine the hypothesis that somatic mutations cause TLE and it will aim to identify the cell-types and gene expression changes that contribute to the development of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing evidence that maternal health and behaviors in pregnancy, such as pre-pregnancy obesity, excessive gestational weight gain, poor diet, smoking, and adverse pregnancy outcomes, are linked to fetal programming for obesity and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in the offspring. Yet, there is a surprising lack of research on the role of prenatal sedentary behavior, physical activity, and sleep (conceptualized together as 24-hour behavior) on offspring obesity risk and CVD risk; this is an unfortunate research gap since there is strong physiological rationale that these behaviors in pregnancy could influence offspring health and are modifiable intervention targets in pregnancy. This multi-site observational cohort study will leverage state-of- the-art, 24-hour behavior assessment in each trimester of pregnancy, collected as part of the ongoing Pregnancy 24/7 cohort study and add additional assessments of offspring growth, adiposity, and CVD risk through 24 months to inform future primordial prevention interventions to decrease the risk of offspring obesity and CVD across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Higher brain functions such as learning, memory and cognition requires for brain cells to undergo plastic changes in the connectivity, i.e. synaptic plasticity, and impairments in this plasticity are thought to underlie cognitive impairment in various pathological conditions. Here, we will elucidate the mechanisms that mediate the decision between two opposing forms of synaptic plasticity, long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD). These mechanisms are relevant for understanding normal neuronal information processing as well as its impairments in conditions including Angelman Syndrome, schizophrenia, and intellectual disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The role of macrophages in hepatobiliary development Narrative In the proposed work, we will employ macrophage-deficient zebrafish and transgenic reporter strains combined with high-resolution confocal imaging and novel image analysis methods to determine the importance of macrophages for liver development. We will determine the requirement for macrophages for biliary tree branching morphogenesis and hepatocyte polarization, and the role of TNFα and TGFβ signaling in attracting macrophages and mediating their effects. The proposed work will further elucidate our understanding of developmental defects of biliary tree formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Although vocal hyperfunction is linked to the most prevalent types of voice disorders, effective prevention and clinical management of these disorders continue to be hampered by limited knowledge of underlying etiological and pathophysiological mechanisms. To address this need, this Clinical Research Center brings together a multidisciplinary team of experienced investigators to pursue a comprehensive program of research focused on hyperfunctional voice disorders. Achieving the goals of this research program will lead to improved prevention, differential diagnosis, and more focused and efficient treatment of these highly prevalent conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance Unlike other retroviruses, lentiviruses including HIV-1 infect both activated/dividing CD4+ T cells and terminally differentiated/nondividing myeloid cells (e.g. macrophages and microglia) and also rapidly evolve through their robust genetic mutagenesis capability during the course of their pathogenesis. In this renewal, we aim to reveal noble mechanistic and structural strategies that lentiviruses employ for their cell tropism and rapid evolution/escape. Understanding of these unique viral strategies will ultimately assist the development of novel antiviral concepts and tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Long-term affective withdrawal symptoms following opioid  dependence confer vulnerability for relapse and persistent drug use in patients. Cannabinoid-based  therapies are commonly sought to treat these symptoms acutely, however the mechanisms by which  these therapies work, how cannabinoid signaling is altered with opioid dependence, and the efficacies  of these drugs in mitigating relapse with long-term withdrawal is unknown. The goal of the proposed  studies is to identify changes in cannabinoid signaling in reward circuits and determine the effect  cannabinoids have on opioid motivation and drug taking during long-term withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Dysfunction of the specialized liver endothelial cells that line blood vessels could lead to loss of hepatocytes and scarring setting the stage for the progression of advanced liver disease, which is incurable except with a liver transplant, that is an expensive and challenging procedure. We have found previously unknown key factors, namely the transcription factors Erg, Fli1, and c-Maf, capable of specifying naïve mouse or human endothelial cells into functioning specialized liver sinusoidal blood vessels; that will enable approaches to uncover the signals that drive liver regeneration without causing scarring. We have proposed studies to decipher the underlying mechanisms by which the endothelial cells by vascularizing stellate, Kupffer cells and hepatocytes conduct their crosstalk, thereby setting the stage for designing strategies for a more effective and scar-free hepatic regeneration to achieve efficacious treatment for liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Vocal hyperfunction (VH) is linked to the most prevalent types of voice disorders, but effective prevention and clinical management of these conditions continue to be hampered by limited knowledge of the etiological and pathophysiological mechanisms associated with VH. This project will use data from ambulatory voice monitoring as well as other sources to elucidate several factors that are assumed to play important roles in causing and maintaining hyperfunctional voice disorders. Achieving the goals of this research program will lead to improved prevention, differential diagnosis, and more focused and efficient treatment of these very prevalent conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) remains an urgent public health problem due to a lack of established biomarkers for early diagnosis and treatment to delay disease progression. While it is known that metabolic changes that affect disease progression occur early in the course of clinical disease, the cause or consequence of these metabolic changes are not well understood. To develop novel diagnostic biomarkers and identify treatment target(s) for ALS, I will focus this study on the metabolic changes in ALS by examining lipid mediators, body weight and composition, energy expenditures and other factors in groups of participants diagnosed with ALS, pre-ALS, or primary lateral sclerosis.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Public Health Relevance The deadly COVID-19 pandemic is underscored by the high morbidity and mortality rates seen in certain vulnerable populations, including patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) and obesity. Despite this well-known association, our understanding of how and why this occurs is lacking leading to an absence of specific therapies. In this proposal, we aim to test the mechanisms by which COVID-19 leads to adverse outcomes in diabetes mellitus and obesity with the goal of developing new therapies for patients with COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to determine the underlying physical and neurophysiological mechanisms associated with vocal hyperfunction, with the goal of identifying triggering mechanisms and differentiating cause from reaction in these disorders. The proposed modeling framework consists of numerical and experimental components that will provide unique insights into the underlying biomechanical, aero-acoustic, and auditory-motor control mechanisms. In addition, subject-specific model representations will provide access to additional measures and insights from the available data that will help to elucidate the etiology and pathophysiology of vocal hyperfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Vocal hyperfunction (VH) is the most commonly treated class of voice disorders by speech-language pathologists and voice therapy is the primary curative treatment. Patients and clinicians report that generalizing improved voicing into daily life is the most significant barrier to successful therapy. We will test if extending biofeedback into the patient’s daily life using ambulatory voice monitoring will significantly improve generalization during therapy and if individual patient factors, like how easily they can modify their voice and engagement during therapy, moderate the effects of the biofeedback.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Inhibitory neurotransmission controls the activity and synchrony of excitatory neurons, and impaired inhibition contributes to the pathomechanism of neurological disorders such as epilepsy. The current experiments will determine whether specific types of inhibitory neurons are more effective at suppressing epileptic activity in the neuronal circuit without disrupting information encoding and may identify strategies to prevent seizures without adverse effects on cognitive function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers are molecular machines responsible for organizing the packaging of DNA in our genomes. PHR: This diversity supplement will help develop sampling algorithms at the interface of statistical mechanics and artificial intelligence to probe mechanisms for rare event processes, such as drug unbinding and conformational change in drug targets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The overarching goal of this R25 proposal is to renew and expand the Michigan Integrative Well-Being and Inequality (MIWI) Training Program, a state-of-the-art program designed to enhance the methodological skills of interdisciplinary early-career scientists conducting integrative health research. Biological, psychological, social, and environmental aspects of health are often siloed in research, clinical care, and scientific training, reflecting a piecemeal approach to health that fails to meet the needs of persons with complex conditions. This hybrid training program builds on our successful track-record mentoring junior scientists and leverages extensive institutional resources and a national network of expert consultants to provide focused methodology training in integrative health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Polyketides are used more in human medicine than any other class of secondary metabolites, and comprise roughly 20% of top-selling small-molecule drugs. This project advances catalytic methods for the de novo chemical synthesis of polyketides based on hydrogen auto-transfer processes that enable direct stereo- and site-selective conversion of lower alcohols to higher alcohols. Polyketide natural products that possess anti-cancer and anti- bacterial properties are targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent legalization of cannabis in a growing number of States across the U.S. has led to a rapid increase in availability and use of cannabis and cannabis products, in a wide range of inhaled and edible forms that are potent and inexpensive, and this in turn has led to an exponential surge in emergency department (ED) visits for acute cannabinoid intoxication (ACI). This project aims to further advance Anebulo Pharmaceutical’s clinical development of an emergency treatment for ACI: ANEB-001, a CB1 antagonist shown to rapidly reverse the key symptoms of ACI after single oral doses in a Phase 2 THC challenge study in healthy subjects. Ultimately, providing ANEB-001 as an intravenous antidote for ACI and potentially cannabis hyperemesis syndrome (CHS) in the ED could address this rapidly growing unmet need, particularly for children and vulnerable patients at greatest risk of potentially life- threating adverse events, while also reducing the burden on the US healthcare system.

PHR: BICX104 is a 3-month naltrexone implantable pellet for the treatment of Methamphetamine Use Disorder, alone, or in conjunction with bupropion tablets. An estimated 2 million people suffer from Methamphetamine Use Disorder and there was a 43% increase from 2015-2019. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Looking at cardiovascular health for people living with HIV is vital given the growing number of middle- and older-aged adults living with HIV and the complex effects of HIV on cardiovascular health directly, and indirectly through HIV's impact on inflammation. Given the importance of sleep health for a range of health behaviors, including medication adherence, and the well-established link between poor sleep and increased risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD), the proposed study seeks to measure sleep, HIV health, inflammation, and cardiovascular health across a 12-month period in a sample of 240 racially-diverse sexual minority men living with HIV aged 45-64, to test pathways linking sleep to CVD risk through inflammation, and critically, through HIV health. Additionally, findings regarding the effect of daily minority stress experiences on subsequent sleep and next-day medication adherence will also provide insight into how poorer health outcomes emerge and persist in marginalized communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed transformable Nano-Theranostics shows great promise to improve imaging sensitivity/specificity and drug delivery efficiency to HNSCC and are expected to be highly useful in precision image-guided treatment for effective detection and elimination of early localized HNSCC lesions. For larger HNSCC that require surgical resection, it can be used as a theranostic agent for (i) delineation of tumor margin for image-guided surgery, (ii) intra-operative phototherapy to treat any residual diseases at the surgical margin and adjacent sites that are accessible to illumination intra-operatively, and (iii) systemic treatment of lesions that are not accessible to illumination if using full dose anti-cancer drug within the transformable nano-theranostics. This project will significantly lower the mortality among patients with HNSCC and will have a tremendous impact on the quality of life of these patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: This proposal addresses a critical need for both our older and younger populations of veterans. Head trauma is a risk factor for both Alzheimer disease and Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy, a neurodegenerative disease caused by repetitive mild traumatic brain injury. Soldiers have always been at risk for head injury and this is particularly the case for OEF/OIF veterans, many of who have experienced explosive blast injury and participated in contact sports. There is a critical need to understand the mechanisms and risk factors underlying this injury to facilitate prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. The aging veteran population and high rate of head injury will lead to daunting costs and responsibilities for the VA if research aimed at translating mechanisms into biomarkers and treatments is not developed. Improved understanding of the role of cerebrovascular remodeling in the development of neurodegenerative disease may lead to new treatment options and directions for interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung cancer (LC) causes significant mortality and morbidity in the U.S. How to guide screenings for LC survivors is a critical and timely public health concern, as CT screening becomes the standard of care with increased LC survivors in the US population. From a public health perspective, our study has high impact because the completion of this study will provide a valuable decision tool for evaluating an individual’s risk of developing second primary lung cancer (SPLC) and a set of optimal screening strategies for SPLC among LC survivors, which will ultimately result in a substantial reduction of the LC mortality and, in turn, a substantial cost-savings for the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is designed to examine that the loss of mechanical perception encountered in aging might be, in-part, due to decreased communication to the nucleus. The premise that intra-cellular connectivity maintained by “Linker of Nucleoskeleton and Cytoskeleton” complexes may be the key aspect regulating the nuclear mechanotransduction is of paramount interest for potential therapeutic interventions and poised to lay the foundation for novel advances in treatment and prevention of musculoskeletal decline as seen in aging, obesity, bedrest and other musculoskeletal conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each day, respiratory tract surfaces are exposed to billions of potentially harmful particles whose accumulation is averted by mucus barriers that reduce particle deposition, and by white blood cells called macrophages that engulf and digest materials that get past mucus barriers. While critical for defense, dysfunction within these two systems can contribute to lung injury and to subsequent scarring of lung tissues as they heal. We have identified a critical link between mucus and macrophage functions that highlights their abilities to communicate during responses to lung injury, and our studies have the potential to significantly impact our cellular and molecular understanding of mucus and macrophage functions, while also identifying potential targets for prevention and treatment of acute lung injury and fibrosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Pharmacokinetic (PK) drug-drug interaction (DDI) studies are rarely performed in infants, which results in the extrapolation of adult dosing recommendations that account for the DDI potential to infants despite known age- induced physiological changes that can alter the DDI magnitude with age. By incorporating information about the DDI mechanism and physiological age-induced changes that affect the DDI magnitude, physiologically-based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) models can be used to predict PK DDIs in infants. This proposal will evaluate a systematic approach to PK DDI evaluation in infants using PBPK modeling and real-world data to accelerate the availability of age-appropriate drug dosing recommendations for infants in light of the DDI potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Prenatal alcohol and anxiety: an ontogenetic role for CRF Prenatal exposure to alcohol differential affects anxiety across the lifespan and increases ethanol consumption, yet the neurobiological underpinnings are not well understood. The corticotropin- releasing factor (CRF) system is heavily involved in regulating anxiety and ethanol intake through its actions in the medial central amygdala (CeM) and is disrupted by prenatal exposure to alcohol. This proposal will examine prenatal alcohol-induced adaptations in the CRF system within the CeM across ontogeny to determine how dynamic changes in this system contribute to fluctuations in anxiety-like behaviors and ethanol intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer has a unique metastatic pattern and stromal cells including cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) play a key role in the metastatic process. I aim to study the role of omental CAF Discoidin domain receptor 2 (DDR2) in cancer cell metastasis, especially through its regulation of arginase-1. This study will uncover novel mechanisms by which omental CAF DDR2 and arginase alter collagen remodeling and polyamine biosynthesis, and may support development of novel therapies for ovarian cancer patients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a leading cause of injury related death and disability in the United States for which there are no currently approved pharmacological treatments. A hallmark of TBI is vascular injury which greatly disrupts neuronal networks leading to deficits in brain function. This proposal explores the importance of the Cannabinoid 2 Receptor (CB2) as a druggable target for vascular protection following TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunosuppressive therapy is required to prevent organ rejection, however, dosing of immunosuppressive agents is complicated by patient-specific differences impacting the body’s absorption and elimination of these agents. The goal of this research proposal is to clinically validate an innovative precision medicine strategy for dosing the immunosuppressant tacrolimus in pediatric heart transplant, which will in turn lead to improvements in long-term transplant survival outcomes. The strategy and techniques used in this project can be extended to improve drug therapy across multiple pediatric diseases requiring chronic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Penn Training Program in Rheumatic Diseases will provide the infrastructure and outstanding opportunities required to develop the next generation of physicians and scientists prepared to address the need to continue to close our knowledge gaps about basic pathophysiology, diagnosis, epidemiology, outcomes, and treatment of rheumatic diseases in all their manifestations. The program’s goal is to provide a rich, multi-disciplinary, multi- modal training environment to support the success of developing trainees in becoming independent scientists dedicated research in Rheumatic Disease. This program builds upon many decades of excellent success by the Penn/CHOP Adult and Pediatric Rheumatology Divisions in training leading researchers in Rheumatology.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program/Rheumatic Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorders are major public health problems in most parts of the world including the United States. This request is for funding to allow young scientists to attend the 44th through 48th Annual Meeting of the Research Society on Alcoholism (RSA). The meeting outcome will greatly advance the treatment, prevention, and understanding of alcoholism in the U.S. and throughout the world, and it will also help to retain trainees and young investigators in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES This research project focuses on studying the role of bilingualism in cognitive reserve through three socio- demographically and linguistically diverse cohorts: Chinese Americans, Mexican Americans, and Indians. in this project, the University of California, San Francisco, the National Institute of Mental Health and Neuroscience, and the Health and Aging Brain-Health Disparities study joint effort to assemble one of the largest, multicultural, multilingual, and well-characterized cohort of 2,200 individuals to build a theoretical framework for bilingualism and cognitive reserve. The proposed work will enhance our understanding of the multidimensionality of bilingualism and offer valuable insights into the inter-relationships of bilingualism, social determinants of health, and cognitive reserve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The project described here studies a unique cellular pathway used by influenza virus mRNAs to be exported from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. This project will also examine the effect of a novel inhibitor of this process, which prevents viral replication without causing cell toxicity. Thus, these studies will reveal fundamental biology and may uncover a potential strategy for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal Cord Injury (SCI) represents a major health crisis that leaves hundreds of thousands of people worldwide paralyzed or otherwise unable to perform essential daily functions, including walking, reaching, grasping and urination. While the body does have some potential for regeneration and recovery after SCI, the factors governing this regenerative capacity remain poorly understood, but prior work has found that recovery can correlate with the formation of new blood vessels in the spinal cord. My proposed research will directly address the potential of a novel astrocyte subtype to aid in the formation of new blood vessels in the spinal cord after injury- opening novel therapeutic avenues aimed at providing a more hospitable intraspinal environment to bolster functional recovery after SCI.
