IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian clocks have a profound impact on human health as they play a central role in regulating daily physiology, and several studies indicate substantial correlation between circadian dysfunction (e.g. in shift work) and human diseases including cancers, heart disease, lung inflammation, diabetes, metabolic, vascular and mental disorders. This project's goal is to study new types of circadian rhythms in mice that are missing a key molecular component of the core clock machinery – a gene called Bmal1. Gaining new molecular insights into the circadian clockwork will guide future therapeutic interventions to alleviate the disorders associated with circadian disruption, which are highly prevalent in contemporary society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adenovirus (Ad) is a remarkably efficient virus at infecting and replicating in human cells. These properties made adenovirus-based vectors a highly attractive platform for developing novel therapeutics to combat genetic diseases and cancer. The successful completion of this project will significantly advance our understanding of fundamental factors that are critical for effective clinical translation of Ad-based vector systems as cancer therapeutics. Results of our work may also be broadly applicable to other oncolytic viral vector systems and other treatment modalities that aim at triggering potent tumor cytotoxicity to halt progression and/or promote immunity to localized and disseminated neoplastic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: ‐ ‐‐ This project addresses unmet needs in our understanding of primary membranous nephropathy (MN) mechanism of initiation and progression. Using a newly generated glomerulus on a chip system that mimics the renal filtration barrier in vitro, we gathered preliminary data hinting at a possible role of the C3a/C3aR  ‐ signaling in podocyte and glomerular endothelial injury. We will test our hypothesis in vitro and in vivo and the results generated by this project will be directly relevant to the better understanding of auto immune nephropathies and other proteinuric kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among veterans; the lack of effective therapy provides the impetus to search for alternative, anti-neoplastic, chemopreventive agents and treatment strategies. Grape seed procyanidin extract (GSE) is used to promote cardiovascular health, and milk thistle silymarin extract (MTE) is used to promote hepatobiliary health; both natural agents have independently been reported to exert anti-neoplastic effects against lung cancer. Based on our encouraging in vitro findings showing unequivocal synergistic anti-cancer effects exerted by the combinations of GSE and MTE, the purpose of this continuing renewal Merit Review proposal is to evaluate the in vivo anti-neoplastic properties of combinations of leucoselect phytosome and siliphos, which are standardized GSE and MTE complexed with soy phospholipid to enhanced bioavailability, in mouse models of lung cancer, to determine their pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics against lung cancer, identify suitable surrogate endpoint biomarkers and set the stage for clinical trials in the near future.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a well documented need to involve greater numbers of veterinarians in biomedical research. By virtue of their broad training, veterinarians possess a unique skill set that makes them well suited to productively engage in interdisciplinary biomedical research. The Cornell University Veterinary Investigator Program (VIP) is designed to provide rigorous, hypothesis-driven laboratory research experiences to early stage DVM students. By exposing veterinary students to the importance, impact, and appeal of basic and translational science, this Program will have long-term impacts on the next generation of veterinarians, with significant implications for biomedical research and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strong genetic evidences suggest that microglia may play a key role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). DAP12, as an adaptor protein involved in the cross-interaction of signal networks of surface immune receptors in microglia, has been indicated to be a central player in an AD-associated microglia specific module. Our study reveals that DAP12 differentially regulates microglia-dependent tau metabolism and microglia- mediated inflammation, providing us a comprehensive understanding the disease mechanism underlying the fundamental contribution of microglia to the development of AD.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Non-technical skills impact patient safety in surgery, but the gold-standard for assessing team performance primarily relies on the use of subjective assessments that require trained observers. Currently, no automated devices or sensing-based metrics exist for objectively quantifying and monitoring non-technical skills. A sensing- based system incorporating objective metrics will provide a novel assessment and feedback tool for measuring the effectiveness of team training and identifying behaviors that influence surgical team performance, which can ultimately lead to improved patient safety within the operative environment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Wearable sensors for modeling and assessing nontechnical skills in surgery

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative More than 9 in 10 individuals carrying a penicillin allergy label are not truly allergic, which has widespread consequences that include a higher risk of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Removal of inaccurate penicillin allergy labels (de-labeling) is a safe and recommended strategy to improve antibiotic prescribing. This project seeks to measure, understand, and improve equitable access to penicillin allergy de-labeling.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Equitable Access to Penicillin Allergy De-Labeling

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative  Impairments in cognitive performance of tasks known to require the intact functioning of the prefrontal cortex, such as impairments in cognitive flexibility, are associated with multiple psychiatric disorders that impart substantial public health burdens, including major depression and schizophrenia. Stress, in addition to impairing cognitive flexibility directly, is associated with an increased risk of major depression and schizophrenia and therefore may provide either a pathogenic or mediating link between the pathophysiological manifestation of these disorders and their associated cognitive deficits. A circuit-level understanding of the role of prefrontal neuronal subpopulations is therefore critical in identifying potential targets for pharmacotherapeutic or neuromodulatory interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the absence of clinical trial data, causal inference from observational multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR- TB) cohort data is needed in order to generate robust evidence to guide treatment and care. A lack of high quality, systematically collected data and a limited armamentarium of statistical methods applied and/or tailored to MDR-TB cohorts constitutes a major barrier to guaranteeing optimal treatment for MDR-TB patients throughout the United States and the world. Our group is uniquely positioned to conduct novel analyses on high quality data, in order generate robust evidence to answer urgent research questions prioritized by the World Health Organization, with the overall goal of informing optimal care and treatment for patients with MDR-TB globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral cavity cancer outcomes have not significantly improved over the past 30 years. Immunotherapy is a new type of cancer treatment that uses the body’s own immune cells, such as T cells, to attack cancer, but it only works in a small number of patients for reasons that we do not understand. In this proposal, we aim to improve oral cavity cancer outcomes by determining why T cells do not kill cancer cells and discovering new ways to increase the ability of T cells to attack cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanocytes produce the melanin pigments that provide organismal protection against ultraviolet irradiation, which can cause DNA damage. Understanding melanocyte biology is relevant to public health since loss of melanocytes can result in the depigmentation disease vitiligo, and unrestrained expansion of melanocytes can result in melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer. This proposal aims to determine the mechanisms through which melanocyte stem cell behavior is altered by ultraviolet irradiation, in order to ultimately manipulate this population in human patients for the improved treatment of vitiligo, and the prevention of melanoma.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Urease-positive organisms cause detrimental consequences among long-term catheterized individuals, including painful catheter encrustation, blockages, stone formation, all of which increase morbidity and mortality. This project aims to determine the mechanism of action of novel compounds that decrease bacterial urease activity and to conduct pre-clinical assessment of their therapeutic potential. This project will provide new insight into urease enzyme regulatory mechanisms and provide new targets for therapeutics that prevent catheter-associated urinary tract infection associated morbidity and mortality, without the use of antimicrobials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed collaborative research intervention will investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and associated benefits and harms of integrating fentanyl test strip education and distribution into existing opioid overdose education and naloxone distribution programs in rural and urban communities. Fentanyl test strip education and distribution is an emerging harm reduction strategy that is becoming an increasingly common practice in some parts of the United States, but research supporting the intervention is limited. We expect that the findings of this study will advance the existing scientific knowledge related to fentanyl test strip education and distribution and inform decisions by public health leaders and policy makers on whether to support the continuation and expansion of fentanyl test strip education and distribution in Ohio and nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Graduate Research Training Initiative for Student Enhancement at the University of South Dakota (G- RISE USD) will develop a biomedical doctoral training program that produces a highly qualified, diverse pool of biomedical scientists and prepares them for a variety of potential career paths. The program will seek to train students from diverse populations that reflect South Dakota and the surrounding region, emphasizing American Indians, Latinos, 1st generation college students, economically disadvantaged students, and students from rural backgrounds. These trainees will be prepared for careers in the public and private sector through professional development workshops and access to graduate level classes in the fields of business, law, communication, and education.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because vestibular disorders and hearing loss can triple one’s fall risk and have a profound effect on one’s independence and participation in activities of daily living. This project is relevant to the mission of the NIDCD because it is uncovering new knowledge to better the overall health of these individuals. By understanding the relationship between neurobiological differences and balance performance, we can be better positioned to improve balance and function in over 1/3 of adults in the United States who seek medical attention for vestibular disorders or hearing loss.

PHR: Project Narrative The primary goals of the proposed Research Program on Cognition and Neuromodulation Based Interventions (RP-CNBI) are to create a sustainable and robust infrastructure (Goal 1), provide thorough training to the next generation of ADRD researchers (Goal 2), and develop consensus statements and centralized analytic platforms (Goal 3). The combination of these resources will enhance methodologic rigor, training, and access to resources necessary for high-quality non-pharmacologic intervention research, collectively enhancing Milestones 8A-E.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance Little is known about how amyloid-beta and tau interact to disrupt neural systems function in the intact brain across behavioral states. By integrating and applying a diverse set of tools, including concomitant mini-microscope imaging of dynamic calcium activity and local field potential recording in freely behaving mouse models of early onset Alzheimer’s disease and late onset Alzheimer’s disease, together with a viral vector that enables calcium imaging in tau-laden brain cells, we will address this knowledge gap. These efforts will advance Alzheimer’s disease modeling, set the stage for further research both mechanistic and translational, and inform therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Severe asthma (SA) is complex, multifactorial and refractory to treatment by corticosteroids (CS). In recent years, some progress has been made in its treatment with the advent of biologics. Using state-of-the-art immunological and molecular multi-omics approaches the projects and cores working synergistically will establish new concepts in immune-epithelial interactions underlying asthma pathogenesis. It is anticipated that the effector pathways identified in SA in this study can be ultimately targeted to limit disease morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Severe asthma is a heterogeneous and complex disease with limited options for therapy that involves bidirectional interactions between immune cells in the airways and airway epithelial cells. Project 1 will study at single cell resolution cell types and their molecular networks in asthmatic airways to understand the underlying immune dysfunction in severe asthma. Mouse models of severe asthma will be used in parallel to study mechanisms. The results of the proposed work will identify novel mechanisms of disease pathogenesis and new opportunities for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The optimal host response to mucosal infection relies on the critical balance between pathogen killing (immunity) and limiting immunopathology (tolerance) in the host. Host disease tolerance is especially important in infections with macroparasites such as helminths that cause significant tissue damage, therefore investigating these host disease tolerance mechanisms may be applicable to the treatment of tissue injury and inflammation of significant public health impact. This proposal will investigate how the secreted protein RELMa contributes to host disease tolerance to helminths through regulation of alternatively activated macrophage subsets, macrophage-helminth interactions and macrophage-lung stromal cell interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Only recently has a screening and brief intervention in low-income primary care settings been shown to reduce patients' illicit drug use over 3-months. Good as this finding is, the next challenge is to sustain patients' drug use reductions over 12-months to coincide with routine annual primary care visits for rescreening. We propose adding mHealth tools to enhance and sustain drug use reductions in an effective SBI to reduce drug use and prevent addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) eventually die when their disease becomes resistant to conventional or even newer treatments. Some of these newer treatments involve drug combinations that include an inhibitor of BCL2 called venetoclax. We have identified novel venetoclax drug combinations with activity that exceed the combinations currently in clinical use, and our proposed studies will involve detailed examination of these promising drug combinations to better understand the markers and mechanisms of sensitivity and resistance, with the goal of delivering better outcomes to patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combatting the ever-growing health and economic costs associated with diabetes, it is necessary to obtain full knowledge of beta cell dysfunction occurs in the progression to diabetes. Precise gene expression programs within the beta cell are mediated by islet enriched transcription factors and recruited coregulators, whose dynamic interactions are predicted to be compromised in the pathophysiological conditions associated with diabetes. The studies herein aim to define the importance of the Nucleosome Remodeling and Deacetylase complex on modulating the activity of the Pancreas Duodenum Homeobox-1 transcription factor in physiological and pathophysiological conditions associated with Type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  This K01 application describes a research and mentoring strategy for Dr. Su Chin Heo to gain the necessary biological skill set to identify how spatio-temporal genome organization regulates gene expression in meniscus cells. How genome organization of cells within the knee meniscus change with development or degeneration is not well understood, and how biophysical cues impact this process has not been studied. To this end, the proposed work will elucidate changes in the spatio-temporal genome organization in meniscus cells with tissue development or degeneration, and in response to biophysical cues, using both healthy and degenerative cell sources for use as a safe and effective cell therapy for dense connective tissue repair and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified Clstn3 as a key determinant of multilocular lipid droplet morphology and function. We will define the mechanisms of Clstn3 action and its contributions to metabolic physiology. These studies are expected to provide fundamental insight into pathways regulating lipid droplet function and may suggest opportunities for modulating lipid utilization in the setting of metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Serving as one of four disease teams of the Accelerating Medicines Partnership and Autoimmune Mediated Diseases (AMP-AIM) consortium, the Lupus Omics Cutaneous Kidney Investigative Team (LOCKIT) will enroll and follow an estimated 400 patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) from nine centers across the country. The initial focus of inquiry will be on the kidney and skin given the high prevalence, severity, and remarkable heterogeneity with which SLE manifests in these organs, and the considerable but poorly understood influences of race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status on disease phenotypes. With a high priority on identifying early kidney involvement and understanding what drives the range of skin rashes from acute to chronic, state-of the art and next generation analytics will be applied to interrogate tissues, blood, and urine from our informative populations, with the ultimate goal to identify novel targets for intervention.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because B cells/antibodies and T cells play vital roles across such a vast range of health conditions, from infection, to autoimmunity, to cancer, that the ability to de- code what they are doing would be an important step forward for diagnosing these conditions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New understanding in the mechanism of therapy response and resistance is urgently needed to improve the treatment efficacy of metastatic prostate cancer, which is the second leading cause of cancer death in American men. Completion of this proposal provides new molecular insights in how prostate cancer cells use hypoxia and HIF1 to confer treatment resistance. It will lead to new prognosis and treatment strategies by providing candidates for biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Newborn screening (NBS) is one of the most successful public health programs that provides cost-effective early diagnosis of treatable disorders while a major challenge for NBS of many treatable genetic disorders is the unavailability of a biomarker in dried blood spots (DBS). Given the facts that blood (in DBS) is a very complex mixture of proteins and that target proteins relevant to the diseases presented in this proposal are present at relatively low abundance, a technique called Immuno-SRM (Immunocapture coupled to selected-reaction- monitoring, or SRM) has been developed to quantify proteins in DBS. In this grant, our plan is to develop an Immuno-SRM method to quantify 19 peptides for NBS of 12 devastating but treatable genetic disorders using innovative method for covalent tagging of peptides so that several newborns can be analyzed simultaneously in one Immuno-SRM analysis and results easily decoded to link protein levels to each specific newborn.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Emerging areas of research via the mechanistic human disease modeling approach have led to the development of new hypotheses and technologies to collect massive omics data (e.g. metabolites and epigenetic makers) that present great challenges to the mediation analysis. Mediation analysis is essential to understand mechanistic causal pathways of environmental perturbations and socioeconomic stressors on human health and health inequalities. The existing statistical methodologies are inadequate and underpowered to address major methodological challenges and translational research needs from such high-dimensional data analyses. Substantially motivated by analytic needs from several NIH-funded projects, the primary goal of this project is to advance novel methodological research on high-dimensional statistical inference, which will deliver a set of novel statistical models and efficient algorithms to support translational research in the connection to evaluating, interpreting, and predicting impacts of exposures to environmental and nutritional risk factors as well as socioeconomic determinants to human health, developmental outcomes and health disparity. These new toolboxes provide answers to the most benefit of disease prevention, health equality and health practice as well supporting evidence to new policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public health relevance statement) Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) and X-linked protoporphyria (XLP) are two genetic diseases characterized by protoporphyrin IX (PPIX)-mediated phototoxicity and hepatotoxicity, and there is no cure. Targeting the transporter ABCG2, the current project will develop a novel strategy for the management of PPIX-mediated toxicities in EPP and XLP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular barrier breakdown is a hallmark of aberrant inflammation associated with trauma, infection, and cardiovascular diseases. There are currently no drugs that can effectively stop or prevent vascular leakage, owing to our incomplete understanding of its underlying mechanisms. We propose an in-depth investigation of the molecular and cellular reactions in the vascular wall during inflammation in hopes to identify new diagnostic or therapeutic targets for effective treatment of vascular inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The etiology of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is unknown and satisfactory treatments for AD are unavailable. We hypothesize that microglial MyD88 signaling plays a predominant role in exacerbating AD-like pathophysiology in AD mouse models during aging and that chronic, systemic inflammation exacerbates AD-like pathophysiology via synergistic activation of MyD88 signaling in peripheral and brain immune cells in AD mouse models during aging. The long term goals of this study are to determine the roles of microglial and peripheral MyD88 signaling in the AD pathogenesis, to elucidate the molecular mechanism underlying the increased AD risk associated with systemic inflammation and to develop new preventive and therapeutic strategies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There are large sex differences in neurodevelopmental disorders, thought to result in part from sex differences in the effects of associated genotypes. Using touchscreen cognitive testing in mice, we will explore whether sex differences in the effect of a genetic variant seen in neurodevelopmental disorders on cognition are the result of male-specific changes in function in neural circuits involved in representing rewards and choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease with no known cure and limited effective therapies. A major comorbidity of SLE and common cause of death is accelerated atherosclerosis. This proposal seeks to determine whether defects in T cell metabolism underpin mechanisms for SLE autoimmunity and resulting cardiovascular disease and test two potential targets to address this unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Unlike de novo gene mutations, which cannot be avoided, chemical exposures can be minimized or eliminated, particularly during critical periods of brain development. Our research will evaluate thousands of chemicals, including mixtures, and identify those with the greatest potential to impact neurodevelopmental processes. This new knowledge will enable us and others to evaluate real-world risks associated with these chemicals/mixtures, permit future generations to minimize exposure, and help to reduce the prevalence of avoidable neurodevelopmental disorders—those that are caused or exacerbated by chemical risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While ADHD typically onsets in early childhood, there are lengthy delays in the identification of the disorder frequently spanning many years putting the children at risks for developing adverse consequences. This calls for improved efforts in early identification of young children at risk for ADHD. In the K23 award, I aim to identify clinical indicators and neural biomarkers of the risk for ADHD that will foretell which preschool aged, pre- syndromatic children will develop ADHD by their early elementary school years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative It is unknown if the DASH eating pattern, a diet rich in fruits and vegetables, can improve glucose control and reduce glycemic variability in adults with type 2 diabetes. We will address this gap in the literature using a randomized clinical trial design. The results of this study will inform dietary recommendations in patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite strong consensus that early, specialized intervention for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) can have a dramatic impact on outcomes, the public health system’s capacity to provide such services is severely challenged by the rapid rise in ASD prevalence. The goal of this research is to increase timely and equitable access to ASD-specialized early intervention during the critical first three years of life by capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of the Part C Early Intervention (EI) system, which is publicly funded and available in all U.S. States. This project will train EI providers to use an evidence-based, inexpensive, parent-mediated intervention that can improve child and family outcomes as well as mitigate the substantial economic costs associated with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA helicases, translocases and single stranded DNA binding (SSB) proteins play fundamental roles in DNA metabolism in all organisms including humans. Mutations in a number of human DNA helicases are linked to several human diseases. Because of their pivotal roles in nucleic acid metabolism in all organisms, including bacteria, helicases are prime targets for drugs or antibiotics that may inhibit them specifically. Our basic studies of SSB and its interacting proteins in bacteria can potentially lead to new targets for the development of novel antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative    Our  mission  is  to  provide  a  biomedical  Ph.D.  training  program  that  is  truly  inclusive,  culturally  responsive,  increases  diversity,  enhances  student  scientific  skill  sets,  develops  student  career  and professional skill sets, provides new opportunities for the participants, and increases faculty  development  as  a  mentor.  The  primary  goal  of  the  UNT  G- RISE  program  is  to  increase  the  number of trainees from underrepresented groups who enter and complete a Ph.D. and enter into  the  biomedical  and  behavior  science  workforce.    To  align  with  this  goal,  the  objectives  of  this  training  program  are  to  1)  further  develop  an  inclusive,  diverse,  and  culturally  responsive  predoctoral  training  program;;  2)  provide  high- quality  scientific  training  for  Ph.D.  students  in  the  Biomedical Sciences;; 3) provide student participants with career and professional training;; and 4)  enhance the Ph.D. mentoring experience for both students and mentors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Liver diseases afflict millions of individuals in the United States, yet there are no effective treatments to curb the pathology and there remains a shortage of available livers for transplantation. However, a viable solution is the use of a model liver system that accurately mimics the biomechanical and biochemical functioning of in vivo liver tissue. This will be achieved through the development of a novel 3D printed bioscaffold for assembly of a liver organoid for in vivo tissue restoration and ex vivo drug screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) is the most common chronic liver disease, with prevalence growing in parallel with the obesity epidemic. NAFLD has no approved pharmacotherapy, due to incomplete understanding of its molecular mediators which is compounded by its unpredictable progression to liver fibrosis, the major determinant of morbidity/mortality of this disease. In this application, we study the potential role of hepatocyte-derived Adipsin, previously considered an adipose-specific secreted factor, to induce liver fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Proposed research is designed to determine the molecular mechanisms by which arsenic exposure alters the homeostatic function of neural cellular populations (neurons, astrocytes, and microglia) during different developmental stages and with aging. Furthermore, we will determine alterations in synaptic pruning and LXR regulated lipid homeostasis. These mechanism could trigger impaired neuronal development and biogenesis, dysregulated synaptic plasticity and chronic neuroinflammation, impacting over all cognition and predisposing the brain to neurodegeneration later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A continuing mystery in human biology is how the same genetic material can give to the more that 200 different types of cells found in the body. My proposal is focused on understanding how the genetic material in cardiac cells is organized in three-dimensions and revealing how that organization is maintained throughout the lifetime of a cell. These studies will help identify new therapeutic strategies for patients with disease that result from the failure to properly establish or maintain the correct organization in cardiac cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop and apply advanced statistical and computational methods to empower the integrative analysis of large scale whole genome sequencing studies (WGS) and biobanks. These methods will advance prevention and intervention strategies in common diseases, such as heart and lung diseases. We will improve the power of rare variant association studies through ensemble testing and the incorporation of cell- type specific functional annotations, and ensemble meta-analysis; developing distributed methods for analyses of large scale WGS studies and federated biobanks; and constructing polygenic risk scores using both common and rare variants, and studying the causal effects of biomarkers and omics markers on diseases and traits by using both common and rare variants in WGS studies and biobanks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Alcohol addiction is a neurological disease that affects millions of individuals in the U.S. and worldwide for which the efficacy of current pharmacological treatments remains limited. To improve such treatments, a better understanding of the long-lasting changes in neuronal communication that occur following chronic alcohol exposure is critical.  It has been theorized that the transition from casual to compulsive drinking is driven by poor decision-making, a phenomenon particularly strong during adolescence and whose influence diminishes with age. The initial loss of control over alcohol consumption may be caused by the weakening of the frontocortical-reflective system, and by the concomitant strengthening of the amygdala-impulsive system.  The objective of this project is to test the existence of a cellular correlate of this theory in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) by examining how nucleus accumbens medium spiny neurons compute competing cognitive and emotional information coming from the prefrontal and amygdala regions, respectively, and how binge alcohol drinking controls this phenomenon.  To explore this question, we will combine in vitro patch-clamp recordings, 2-photon laser scanning microscopy, and a novel double-optogenetics technique in naive and alcohol treated wild-type and transgenic mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Thrombopoietin (TPO), a plasma glycoprotein that stimulates platelet production, has been shown to be regulated at the transcriptional level and at the level of its plasma clearance. This project will utilize human derived cell lines and mouse genetics models to dissect the mechanisms of TPO regulation at the level of its intracellular trafficking/secretion and at the level of its intracellular degradation, two previously unrecognized mechanisms of TPO regulation. Knowledge gained from this proposal may lay the foundation for the development of novel strategies to therapeutically regulate the plasma TPO level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly all glioblastomas go through an accelerated growth phase initiated by the onset of necrosis, which proceeds quickly to death. Despite this, little is known about the mechanisms by which necrosis restructures the tumor microenvironment (TME) to drive this fatal expansion, in large part because an appropriate animal model has not been available. We are developing novel mouse models that allow us to induce necrosis within a high-grade glioma in order to directly visualize and analyze its effect on glioma dynamics and growth. In particular we focus on 1) glioma cell migration; 2) glioma stem cell (GSC) localization and accumulation; and 3) the influx of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs). An improved model that parallels the human disease will demonstrate how these TME elements impact tumor expansion and could potentially be antagonized by novel therapies.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recovery from hematopoietic injuries, which include significant bleeding, overwhelming infection, radiation exposure and myelosuppressive therapy, will benefit from strategies that modulate hematopoietic stem cell activation and return to quiescence. The proposed research contributes to human health by increasing the understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms responsible for the tight regulation of hematopoietic stem cell quiescence signaling within the bone marrow. Knowledge of the basic mechanisms that regulate hematopoietic stem cell quiescence within the bone marrow will aid in the identification of therapeutic targets that improve the regeneration response to hematologic injury, significantly improving overall patient outcomes from hematopoietic stresses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to understand and target cancer cell addictions to stress- tolerance pathways. We have identified that many different cancer cells employ translesion synthesis (TLS) to replicate in a continuous manner and subvert the replication stress response. Here, we will implement state-of-the-art assays to analyze how TLS alters DNA replication fork dynamics, replisome components, and identify cancers dependent on TLS in order to fully develop the anti-cancer potential of our lead small molecule inhibitors of TLS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection that predominantly affects immunosuppressed individuals such as patients with AIDS. A major problem in cryptococcosis is the accumulation of capsular polysaccharide in tissue, which cause local immunosuppression and interfere with the ability of the immune system to clear the infection. The goal of this proposed research program is to develop catalytic antibodies to degrade the capsular polysaccharide in the tissue of AIDS patients as a new therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative. In the United States, breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer among women and still accounts for over 40,000 deaths each year. The underlying goals of this proposal are to identify, at the molecular level, anti-neoplastic strategies that target breast cancer stem cells/tumor initiating cells and to take advantage of tumor cell selective metabolic processes to ultimately lessen disease related mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Animal studies have shown that cocaine produces long lasting changes in the connections between nerve cells (so-called “synapses”), suggesting that cocaine use disorder (CUD) may be a form of aberrant structural synaptic density. In pilot studies, we have collected preliminary data using 11C-UCB-J positron emission tomography (PET), suggesting, for the first time, that cocaine users have fewer such connections (i.e., lower synaptic density than healthy individuals. The current study proposes to replicate and extend these initial findings in a larger number of subjects using a more definitive longitudinal, within-subject design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Genomic profiling of solid tumor samples is now essential for the diagnosis and clinical management of many cancer types including lung adenocarcinoma, however current approaches for detecting the full spectrum of cancer mutations involve complicated testing methods and often fail due low specimen quantity or quality. In this proposal, we aim to optimize a rapid and robust whole genome sequencing method, ChromoSeq, that provides a genome-wide profile of all cancer mutation types from commonly available fixed biopsy material, and then validate its clinical performance for patients with lung adenocarcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We recently discovered two similar anti-cancer compounds with potent toxic activity against many types of human cancer cells. In this proposal, we will perform the requisite experiments to determine how the compounds cause death and if they are able to kill human cancers growing in mice. We expect that in the near future, the identified anti- cancer drugs will result in therapeutic agents that can be used alone or in combination with other FDA approved drugs for the treatment of human cancer and help reduce cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Wearable sensor systems present a unique opportunity for the continual monitoring of vital signs and health status of an individual, particularly in the case of cardiac health. In this project we describe a new rapid and reagent-free sensor system for the detection and quantification of a wide range of biomolecules. The project deliverables proposed will directly monitor heart failure markers using a wearable patch, offering a new peripheral biochemical monitoring system that will change how cardiac health is assessed in the United States and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Fungal asthma is oftentimes poorly controlled with frequent exacerbations and hospitalizations, and it can be fatal. The medications to treat or prevent these complications are limited and have side effects. The completion of this proposal will advance our knowledge about the pathogenesis of fungal asthma, and establish a foundation for the development of IFN therapy to treat asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although treatments for patients with metastatic melanoma, including inhibitors of PD-1, have had impressive activity in clinical trials, patients with brain metastases have largely been excluded from these trials. We propose to capitalize on resources generated at Yale in recent years to study brain metastasis to develop new therapeutic approaches. We will continue our studies of combinations of immune therapy and VEGF-targeting therapy, by validating exciting clinical trial results and conducting mechanistic studies in animal models as a basis for future clinical trials aimed at improving outcomes for patients with brain metastasis from melanoma or other tumor types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Although metastases are the main cause of colorectal cancer (CRC) deaths, and diet is considered the most important environmental factor for CRC development, we still cannot answer the simple questions, which dietary factors contribute to CRC metastasis and what is the mechanism. Answering these questions is important because, unlike genetic factors, diet can be modified, thereby having immense potential for reducing CRC mortality. In this proposal, we aim to address these fundamental questions by using preclinical models and data on CRC patients’ specimens to test our hypothesis that the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages containing glucose and fructose, accelerates CRC metastasis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Negative outcomes of behavior problems in early childhood are overrepresented in low-income and underrepresented minority families. We are evaluating the effect of a brief home-based intervention targeting parenting behavior on improvements in behavior and regulation in infants from high-risk families to prevent the need for later, more intensive treatment in childhood. In light of increasing needs and decreasing resources among the most vulnerable families, this research project carries potential for significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This experimental study will test the impacts of subsidized ridesharing on drunk driving, alcohol consumption, and mobility. This information is critical because alcohol-involved motor vehicle crashes are a major cause of death and injury, and preliminary studies provide compelling evidence that subsidized ridesharing may be a high-impact prevention strategy. Results of this study will provide important information to guide preventive interventions that use subsidized ridesharing to reduce alcohol-involved crashes—including identifying the individuals who will benefit most substantially and the locations where impacts will be greatest—while minimizing side-effects on alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite demonstrated clinical effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) for anxiety, there remains a gap in knowledge about the brain mechanisms by which MBSR works and the neurobiological mechanism for sex differences in MBSR response for the common condition of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD is an example of a condition with perturbations in these relevant emotion regulation and attentional neural circuits for whom MBSR has demonstrated efficacy. Building on prior data supporting our hypotheses about MBSR, GAD, and sex differences in fear and extinction neurocircuitry as well as novel whole brain functional connectivity analyses, we propose a rigorous neuroimaging study to examine how MBSR works, focusing on MBSR induced neural mechanisms that drive response to MBSR in patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), and the degree to which sex differences in MBSR response are explained by sex differences in these mechanisms, in line with moving mind body interventions for common problems such as GAD towards precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Narcolepsy with cataplexy is a chronic debilitating sleep-wake disorder affecting over 3 million people worldwide. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The degree to which female reproductive aging leads to macrostructural changes in brain morphology, brain connectivity, and ultimately cognitive functioning is severely understudied. By examining cognitively normal women undergoing ovarian hormone suppression for endometriosis, the present study will model a core aspect of reproductive aging, providing critical insights into how the depletion of ovarian hormones impacts the brain and cognition. This unique, genetically informed, cognitive neuroscience approach will advance our knowledge of the endocrine basis of cognition and facilitate a targeted approach to identifying individuals who may be particularly vulnerable to neural and cognitive effects of ovarian hormone depletion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The goal of our proposed research is to advance the knowledge regarding the role played by splicing alterations in neurological diseases with the objective of developing novel mRNA-targeted therapeutics. Our first aim is to use a computational approach to identify new neuron-specific poison exons for which mis-splicing is associated with neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases. We will then use patient-derived cellular models of frontotemporal dementia associated with MAPT mis-splicing as proof-of-principle to demonstrate the therapeutic potential of a novel class of splicing modulator compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects more than 35 million Americans and can progress to complete renal failure and the need for dialysis or transplantation. The kidney is innervated by sensory nerves and sympathetic nerves that are affected by CKD and can in turn alter renal function and CKD progression. This application tests whether nerve activity is altered in various CKD models, whether denervation alters hypertension, renal function, and CKD progression, and whether inflammation mediates increases in nerve activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Neuromodulation modalities, such as repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) can induce long-term plastic changes and selectively alter brain network function which in turn may improve symptoms in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, despite the wide application of rTMS in humans, the mechanisms underlying rTMS-induced plasticity in healthy aging and AD remain uncertain. The proposed study examines the ability of rTMS to induce plasticity and modulate brain network function in preclinical and prodromal AD in the context of the aging brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Shigella flexneri and related species are major sources of human diarrheal disease, affecting more than 100,000,000 people each year. This bacterium infects and grows within human intestinal epithelial cells, but many steps in this process are poorly understood. By characterizing the mechanisms of nutrient sensing and nutrient acquisition in the host cells, we will gain important knowledge about adaptation of bacteria to the host environment and potential means for interrupting the disease process.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The focus of this research proposal is to delineate the contribution of cells of the innate immune system (macrophages & monocytes) in the sequence of events that occur in the pubertal rodent testis after exposure to the Sertoli cell toxicant, mono-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (MEHP). Phthalates are a class of compounds used in medical and consumer products and, as a result, are found ubiquitously in the environment. The work of this research proposal is relevant to human health as it is anticipated to provide mechanistic insights that will be valuable for predicting and preventing human reproductive health risks to environmental toxicants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to develop improved sequence based machine learning models to build gene network models to more accurately predict the impact of enhancer perturbation by CRISPR or genetic variation. We will develop methods to train and validate these models by detecting altered TF activity from high time resolution chromatin accessibility, TF ChIP-seq, and H3K27ac data in a stem cell differentiation system and in large consortium datasets (e.g. ENCODE). This project will significantly contribute to our understanding of regulatory element function and how sequence variation impacts disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative More than 16 million older Americans undergo anesthesia and surgery each year. Up to 40% of these patients develop postoperative delirium, a syndrome of waxing and waning changes in levels of alertness and attention, and which is associated with long term cognitive decline and an increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. In this project, we seek to better understand how early Alzheimer’s disease-type changes predispose patients to show abnormal responses to anesthetic drugs, and the relationship between abnormal brain responses to anesthetic drugs and the risk of postoperative delirium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Major depression is a debilitating disorder affecting millions of people worldwide with limited success in treatment or remission. Despite a wealth of neurobiological studies over the last few decades, our understanding of the cellular and molecular processes associated with major depression is rudimentary, precluding the development of effective treatments. In this application, we are proposing an innovative line of research to examine the unique ability of mature microRNAs to translocate into nucleus with the help of exclusive nuclear signals and to determine their transcriptional and posttranscriptional roles in regulating their own expression and the expression of nuclear coding and non-coding genes that can be used as novel ‘‘molecular tools’’ to understand the etiopathogenesis of depressive behavior with a high potential to generate new molecular-based therapies to treat this severe mental disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric Crohn's Disease (CD) patient populations with severe disease subtypes suffer a loss of structural integrity of the small bowel and/or are non-responsive to treatment, which can negatively impact growth and development in these children. Identification of biomarkers aside from genomics, such as metabolic shifts which may occur in the bowel prior to development of severe disease, hold the power to separate at-risk pediatric populations and help physicians intervene earlier with personalized treatment. In this proposal, we will use a novel computational approach to characterize shifts in metabolism that occur across pediatric CD subtypes leveraging existing data archives with validation within a large, diverse cohort of over 400 patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative This project will develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based approach to freeze the beating heart in CT images within a 60-millisecond time window (1/20 of a heart beat), eliminate the motion blurring of coronary arteries in these images, and facilitate analysis of plaque buildup in these arteries, which is the main cause of heart attacks. Our methods will not require patients to hold their breath during the CT exam, and eliminate the need to use beta-blocker drugs to slow patients’ heart rates. Our AI-empowered computational framework will offer major benefits to patients who have the high and irregular heart rates that commonly occur in older adults many of whom experience atrial fibrillation, and also greatly improve image quality of legacy CT scanners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) produces extraordinary clinical responses in more than 25 types of tumor, but only a small number of patients benefit from this therapy. Our data support a provocative model that G Pro- tein-Coupled Receptor 84 (GPR84) pathway can be pharmacologically activated to shape macrophages to- ward the anti-tumorigenic phenotype to overcome ICB therapy resistance. Results will inform the development of promising treatments to reshape immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment through manipulation of met- abolic signaling, and thereby restore responsiveness to PD-1 blockade for bladder cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malformation of cerebellar structures during development is a hallmark of rare neurological ciliopathies like Joubert Syndrome and related disorders. Here, I propose to investigate a novel role for formin family actin polymerizer, FMNL2 as a regulator of microtubule dynamics, which upon disruption leads to ciliopathy-like phenotypes in mice. This proposal will investigate the role of FMNL2 in cerebellar development and provide novel insight into the mechanisms behind actin and microtubule interactions in ciliary signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE- OVERALL The Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (ADRC) at New York University Langone Health has facilitated pioneering research to define transitions from normal aging to the subjective cognitive decline (SCD), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and early dementia stages of AD; as well as AD biomarker development. We now propose to continue this long-standing successful research direction with a focus on understanding disease heterogeneity and delineating biomarkers and their role in these transitions, with the long-term goal of helping to develop novel interventions that will delay or prevent cognitive decline, to help achieve the NAPA goal of a cure by 2025.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the mechanisms of immune evasion in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), with a particular focus on the integrin αVβ6 – SOX4 pathway. We will therapeutically target this pathway with an antibody targeting integrin αVβ6 and investigate the mechanisms by which this pathway inhibits T cell-mediated tumor immunity. The clinical relevance of this pathway will be investigated by multi-color immunofluorescence analysis of human triple-negative breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative One major reason for the current obesity epidemic and its associated lack of effective treatment is due to incomplete understanding of neuronal control of body weight. Using a combination of viral tracing and intersectional mouse genetics, the current proposal aims to dissect the role of distinct AgRP neuron projections that mediate the massive obesity development produced by chronic AgRP neuron activation. The results will identify brain circuit mechanisms for obesity and therefore form a foundation for effective treatments against obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Head and neck cancer is one of the major causes of cancer related death in the US and worldwide and exhibits a high degree of interpersonal and intratumoral heterogeneity, making it difficult to treat. Our grant application proposes to develop a novel personalized immunotherapy approach using membrane vesicles prepared from patients’ own surgically excised tumor tissue, modifying them by protein transfer to express immunostimulatory molecules and administering them to patients along with immune checkpoint inhibitor to boost the immune response against cancer cells. The proposed approach does not require establishment of cell lines, identification of tumor antigens or in vitro manipulation of immune cells, thus making it applicable to wide number of patients in a cost-effective manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: As the population ages, more and more patients are cared for in intensive care units. However, there is a growing gap between the rapidly expanding need for critical care services and both the workforce needed to take care of critically ill patients and the researchers needed to discover new insights to improve outcomes in the intensive care unit. This institutional training grant is aimed at bridging this gap by providing research training for individuals who will pursue careers related to critical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Increasing evidence suggests that astrocytes play a critical role in regulating synaptic plasticity and circuit remodeling, but their role in addiction-related cellular and behavioral adaptations remains underexplored. The current application aims to understand astrocyte-mediated remodeling of cocaine-generated synapses and neuronal populations that drive cocaine seeking. The expected results will provide new insights into novel mechanisms underlying drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal is relevant to public health in the way in which it designed to, in the long-term, potentially improve the way in which urinary diversion surgery is done. If we are successful in generating autologous bladder urothelial stem cells, we will expand the opportunities for cell-based therapy approaches to disorders of the urothelium, such as radiation cystitis or interstitial cystitis, and improve upon the engineering of bladder or urothelial substitutes that can be potentially used in patients with severe hemorrhagic cystitis, end-stage painful bladder syndrome, urinary tract trauma, or congenital urinary tract abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glucocorticoid-induced ocular hypertension and glaucoma are the most common ocular complications of prolonged glucocorticoid use, which may lead to irreversible blindness. This project is relevant to public health because it focuses on how the distal aqueous humor outflow pathway tissues contribute to this disease. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NEI’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge with respect to blinding eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project uses Reinforcer Pathology, an Experimental Medicine approach that identifies novel determinants of cocaine valuation at multiple levels of analysis (behavioral, neural, and computational), to mechanistically test a new conceptual framework for understanding cocaine use disorder. Existing treatments for cocaine use disorder are not optimally robust and are further limited by an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms of cocaine use disorder - a gap that this project aims to address. Results from these studies will positively impact public health because Reinforcer Pathology suggests innovative interventions that will decrease consumption and valuation of cocaine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Although costly and invasive, hydrostatic pressure measurements are required for the diagnosis and management of a wide variety of clinical diseases. An ultrasound contrast agent (UCA) based technique termed subharmonic aided pressure estimation (SHAPE) has shown promise in several clinical trials, but the sensitivity of the technique is currently limited due to polydisperse nature of commercial UCA. Thus, we propose to develop a monodisperse, clinically translatable, SHAPE-specific UCA to improve overall sensitivity and to reconcile theoretical modeling work with empirical data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to lead to a treatment of infections on surgical meshes following hernia repair. Such a tool would provide a noninvasive treatment option that does not currently exist reducing the number of surgeries and complications associated with hernia repair. In addition, the research will lead to improved mesh visualization by ultrasound even when no infection occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child malnutrition has numerous devastating consequences, including impaired synthesis of bile acids (BAs), which help absorb dietary nutrients and regulate metabolism. The goal of this proposal is to understand how malnutrition suppresses BA synthesis. Results from these studies will help us develop new therapies to restore BA levels, improve outcomes of therapeutic feeding to treat malnutrition, and increase survival among children suffering from malnutrition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive deficits are the main cause of disability in schizophrenia. Here we will study how specific patterns of rhythmic electrical activity in the brain contribute to aspects of cognition that are impaired in schizophrenia. This will aid in the development of new treatments for cognitive deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE By integrating epidemiology, epigenetics, and clinical sciences, we create new opportunity to assess cell-type specificity in the molecular control of inflammation and pediatric type 2 diabetes. This study applies specialized training in single-cell gene expression and bioinformatics to investigate single-cell molecular signatures that are found in youth with type 2 diabetes compared to healthy youth. Findings from this project will identify new markers of diabetes pathogenesis in childhood, a period in the life course whose aggressive deterioration of beta cells warrants targeted investigation to inform translational applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have recently identified the function of the adeno-associated virus (AAV) membrane-associated accessory protein (MAAP) as a novel viral egress factor that both promotes enhanced AAV secretion into the media during AAV production and increases the production of exosomes from MAAP-expressing cells. In this proposal, we aim to define the define the molecular mechanisms by which MAAP enhances AAV secretion and exosome production, and further engineer novel MAAP proteins to improve up on its endogenous functionalities. These studies not only have far reaching implications for AAV vectors by improving production processes and yield, but also, expand the exosome delivery technology platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This UO1 brings together a unique team of investigators in von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) mutant malignancies (e.g. clear cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (ccRCC)) to address key unanswered questions with high clinical impact. Despite the recent progress achieved by UO1 investigators and others, there remains an urgent unmet need for the development of novel combination therapeutic strategies and tissue-based biomarkers with which to optimize the clinical use of HIF2α inhibitors. The established pre-clinical and clinical research programs for the study of VHL/RCC at the NCI will continue to be a cornerstone of this renewal proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) deficient subtype of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is (1) caused either by inherited genetic or sporadic epigenetic silencing of succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) genes; (2) characterized by variable biology that ranges from indolent growth to rapidly progressive, fatal disease; and (3) associated with limited treatment options. This proposed U01 project will (1) combine our existing National Succinate Dehydrogenase-deficient GIST Translational Research and Clinical Trial Consortium with unique NIH Clinical Center resources to evaluate the efficacy of a new combinatorial treatment strategy for SDH-deficient GIST patients; (2) create a centralized biobank of well-annotated SDH-deficient GISTs; (3) develop a network of research laboratories with novel complementary preclinical models of SDH-deficient GIST biology; and (4) develop new molecular tools to predict prognosis of SDH-deficient GIST. We anticipate that these aims will test the first efficacious combination therapy for SDH-deficient GIST, create a novel resource for researchers to improve our understanding of SDH-deficient GIST heterogeneity and biology, and molecularly define risk of disease progression/metastasis that can be used to immediately improve SDH-deficient GIST patient care and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic suppurative respiratory tract disease is typically characterized by persistent and recurrent ear, sinus and bronchial infections and eventually bronchiectasis. Genetic causes include primary ciliary dyskinesia associated with abnormal airway clearance and inborn errors of immunity which can have very similar clinical presentations. The purpose of this application is to evaluate a stepwise process for identifying, diagnosing and managing these genetic diseases which can lead to increased possibilities for precision treatments and improved clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Carbapenem-resistant organisms (CRO) are a major threat to public health worldwide, with organisms that render resistance to carbapenems through the production of degradative carbapenemase enzymes being associated with high mortality rates, as the treatment options available for them are limited. This Phase I SBIR proposal represents the first step in the development of a test – an antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) panel/plate with DETECT components integrated into the wells – that would be the first AST system compatible test capable of detecting carbapenemase production and classifying the enzymes present, alongside antimicrobial susceptibility. The all-in-one test would streamline existing clinical workflows, expedite care delivery to patients, and offer cost mitigation opportunities for healthcare centers by accelerating infection control de-escalation measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal is centered on the hypothesis that alcohol-induced hepatocyte injury induces biosynthesis of a group of atypical sphingolipids that promote protection and/or recovery from injury. A novel subunit of the serine palmitoyl transferase complex, Sptlc3, produces atypical sphingolipids, and we have found that its expression induces markers of autophagy which we hypothesize protect from ethanol-induced mitochondrial damage. We seek to pinpoint molecular mechanisms regulated by Sptlc3 and atypical sphingolipids, while testing the effect of Sptlc3 induction on pathways with therapeutic potential for alcoholic liver disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump adequately to supply the body with sufficient oxygen to meet its needs, and heart failure is a leading cause of death in the United States, the veteran population included. Of the 50,000 individuals diagnosed with heart failure each year, 70% of these patients have heart failure due to a previous heart attack (myocardial infarction; MI). The main objective of this grant is to use a mouse MI model to understand how one of the white blood cell types, the neutrophil, influences scar formation by regulating the wound healing response, particularly the inflammatory and reparative components.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Viral infections have more severe chronic consequences in individuals exposed to cigarette smoke (CS) than those who are not. We show that excessive accumulation of MAVS aggregates in mice exposed to CS and influenza virus (Flu) contributes to increased lung pathology. This grant will determine the mechanism of CS- induced dysregulation of mitochondrial antiviral signaling (MAVS) during Flu and the role of PINK1 kinase in correcting this dysregulation. We will characterize the pathways leading to excessive MAVS signaling and the mechanisms by which PINK1 limits MAVS aggregation. The downstream effects of PINK1-MAVS interactions and the effects on pathological pulmonary outcomes will be studied. We will explore the therapeutic potential of PINK1 augmentation using genetic and pharmacological approaches. Lastly, we will study the MAVS aggregation pathway in patients with smoking exposure and viral infections. A clear understanding of MAVS- PINK1 interactions can provide a new target to limit Flu-mediated pathology in CS-related lung diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The apolipoprotein E gene (APOE) is the strongest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). This study aims to elucidate the effects of APOE RNA expression in AD. We have observed that not all APOE mRNA extend to their full length to produce the apoE protein. This anomaly may be caused by the presence of APOE's ε2/ε3/ε4 allele variants that alter RNA transcription through epigenetic mechanisms. We hypothesize that APOE full- length mRNA is the only functional RNA for producing apoE protein and that ε2/ε3/ε4 can differentially modulate production of functional APOE mRNA to modify AD risk. Our short-term goals are to establish an association between the expressions of APOE RNAs, ε2/ε3/ε4 alleles, and AD risk; decipher the molecular mechanisms that regulate APOE RNAs production. Our long-term goal is to understand the role of APOE expression in AD and to apply this knowledge to develop strategies for AD prevention and/or intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease in adulthood originates in part from early life environmental exposures acting through critical windows of developmental susceptibility. Fundamental mechanistic nephrotoxicity information coupled with population-based risk assessment strategies are key to future interventions designed to prevent or treat later life chronic kidney disease. Together, the consortium will advance our understanding of the role of human- relevant metal mixtures in maladaptive kidney function using vertebrate and kidney organoid models and use experimental evidence to establish a population relevant whole-mixture risk assessment strategy applicable to diverse global populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing evidence that men who have sex with men (MSM) experience dual epidemics of HIV and intimate partner violence (IPV), yet understanding of the synergies between these two epidemics is underdeveloped. The proposed 24 month cohort study examines associations between the experience and perpetration of IPV and bio-markers of engagement in clinical HIV care among a large diverse sample of men living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to identify genetic variants associated with risk for alcohol withdrawal syndrome (AWS) and response to benzodiazepine treatment in alcohol use disorders (AUD), including sex-specific genetic effects in a large sample of subjects with AUD. Discovery of genetic variants promoting development of AWS will provide tools for the identification of at-risk patients, and selection of treatment options based on an understanding of inter-individual differences in sensitivity to this central component of AUD. This line of research may also contribute to the development of new AUD treatment approaches aimed to restore physiological dysfunctions associated with those genetic variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Over 90% of breast cancer-related deaths are due to the metastatic relapse of tumors in distant vital organs such as lung and bone. Our proposed studies will provide novel insights into the poorly understood question of how a traditional cancer treatment approach, chemotherapy, triggers the wound healing responses in the lung microenvironment and subsequently fosters the metastatic relapse of breast cancer in the lung. The results from the proposed research will facilitate the development of novel strategies to prevent post-therapy metastases in breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will establish basic cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying activity- dependent growth factor signaling at synapses. These pathways are evolutionarily conserved modulators of synapse structure and function, and pathway disruption is linked to devastating human brain disorders. By establishing how these pathways direct synapse function, this research will build an essential foundation for effective clinical approaches to treating neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative The average age of veterans is increasing and therefore understanding the underlying etiology of age associated disease vulnerability, as well as establishing new prevention and therapeutic strategies is of significant importance. Aging is associated with an increased susceptibility to a number of diseases including osteoporosis with its associated increased risk of fracture. Our studies aim to address improving bone health and healing by nutritional prevention strategies as well as proactive therapeutic interventions to manipulate the microbiome. We will use a comprehensive series of innovative methodologies to investigate the novel concept that the microbiome is integral to dietary Pi sensing and can alter disease pathology associated with sustained high Pi consumption including chronic inflammation and bone health. The studies proposed herein could open numerous new avenues to identify novel strategies to influence veterans' health as they age.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with medical complexity (CMC) are uniquely vulnerable to adverse drug events and dependent upon their under-supported family to carry out complex medication management and coordination across a network of caregivers. To improve CMC medication safety, this project will develop and test a mobile health platform, MedS@HOME, which is designed by stakeholders to support safe medication management across the child’s caregiving network. This technology has the potential to improve medication safety and chronic care outcomes across the wide range of populations that require care from caregiving networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Diabetes currently afflicts 170 million people worldwide and nearly 26 million Americans (more than 8 percent of the population) and its complications have broad and devastating effects on the health and quality of life of these patients. A particularly significant and dangerous complication of diabetes is non-healing ulcerated wounds in the lower leg, which are the leading cause of amputations in the USA. In this application, we propose to study associated cell dysfunctions and improve healing by creating novel native engineered constructs capable of enhancing cell integration and evaluating their ability to improve healing in a diabetic mouse model.
