IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In the blood microcirculation, endothelial cells play a key role in relaxing smooth muscle cells to produce vasodilation and increase blood flow to organs as they need, e.g. to brain or skeletal muscle during physical activity. At a catastrophic social and financial expense to societies around the world, this process is reduced with aging and the onset of neurodegenerative diseases through poorly understood mechanisms. The current research project investigates novel and controllable mechanisms to improve the function of blood vessels in the brain, thus promoting a healthier brain function to sustain the lifespan and quality of life in older humans susceptible to developing dementia such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of urologic chronic pelvic pain syndrome (UCPPS) in the United States is high, ranging from 14- 25% of men and women. The pathology of UCPPS is multifactorial and existing therapies are both limited and unsatisfactory, underscoring the need for preclinical models that are reflective of disease complexity to advance our mechanistic understanding and identify new treatment strategies. To achieve these goals, we propose to systematically phenotype a dual-insult, preclinical model with high relevance to the clinical condition in order to examine promising targetable units that individually or in combination alter the peripheral nervous system and lead to UCPPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roughly 10% of the mammalian corticospinal tract terminates ipsilaterally and is known to be involved in motor recovery from unilateral hemispheric injury; however, its detailed anatomy and function are unknown. The guiding hypothesis of this project is that the ipsilateral corticospinal tract is involved in the coordination of bilateral motor behavior. This project uses a novel method combining single nucleus sequencing and monosynaptic viral tracing to map the connectivity of the iCST at single-neuron resolution, a molecular barcode-based approach to reconstruct its projection structure in detail, retrograde tracing and tissue clearance to map its topography, and chemogenetic tools to investigate its function in behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm birth (PTB) rates are disproportionately higher among Black women than their White peers. Accurate measurement of women’s chronic stress exposures unique to each race/ethnicity could help illuminate the unclear mechanisms underlying the Black-White disparities in PTB. This project develops machine learning algorithms to compute women’s complex chronic stress exposures and then identify women at high PTB risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a complex degenerative joint disease that arises after injury and is characterized by pain, cartilage degradation, synovial inflammation and fibrosis, and formation of ectopic bone growths called osteophytes. PTOA is a chronic, debilitating condition that affects millions worldwide, yet there are currently no disease-modifying treatments. The overarching objective of this proposal is to comprehensively characterize cells and processes responsible for PTOA progression and to provide insights for the development of effective PTOA treatments that will meaningfully and tangibly improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence demonstrates that the risks of red blood cell transfusions outweigh benefits in many patients who are hospitalized in the pediatric ICU with increased risk of organ dysfunction, infection, delirium, and death. Guidelines have been developed to restrict transfusion in patients who are unlikely to benefit; however, these guidelines have not been consistently adopted into clinical practice. This pilot study will examine use of targeted efforts to improve implementation of the guidelines and will inform a future study that evaluates the impact of restrictive transfusion practices and implementation of the transfusion guidelines, with a goal of reducing unnecessary transfusions and improving patient outcomes in critically ill children.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Transfusion Recommendations Implemented in the PICU (TRIP)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Robust evaluation of vaccine safety is central to public confidence in COVID-19 vaccination, a critical tool to combat the pandemic. In this proposal, we will develop new approaches to detect serious adverse events that can happen after vaccination, and we will apply these new approaches to existing data from a large health care system to evaluate COVID-19 vaccine safety. Our study will produce rigorous evidence about the safety of COVID-19 vaccines for policymakers, clinicians, and the public.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to repetitive head impacts in contact sports such as football is a rising public health concern due to the connection with brain disease later in life and changes in the brain after a single season. This F31 Independent Predoctoral Fellowship Award will investigate the effectiveness of a novel evidence-based intervention program to reduce head impact exposure and negative clinical outcomes in youth football, while assessing the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention and utility of the strategy used to implement the intervention program. Formal training and experiential learning will prepare the applicant to become a productive and independent research scientist with cross-disciplinary skills in injury biomechanics and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recovery support services, alongside access to medications for opioid use disorder, are rapidly expanding in the wake of the opioid crisis, yet rigorous research on recovery support services continues to lag behind. The proposed activities will initiate the Studies To Advance Recovery Support (STARS) Network, a thematic, stakeholder-focused research network that will capitalize on an established research consortium to generate trainings, tools, and platforms targeted to the implementation and study of peer recovery support services for individuals treated with medications for opioid use disorder. The STARS Network is relevant to public health because it will provide a critical foundation for high-priority research on peer recovery support services that could inform the expansion of peer recovery support services and advance recovery among individuals with opioid use disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity disproportionately impacts sexual minority women. This K23 seeks to improve obesity treatments for this at-risk and underserved group by tailoring and optimizing an evidence-based online behavioral weight loss program to enhance weight loss in sexual minority women. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Million Veteran Program (MVP) constitutes the largest and most comprehensive biobank in the world, including multi-ancestry genetic data from more than 650,000 Veterans and dense electronic health records that fully captures the clinical characteristics of each participant. MVP provides a unique opportunity to perform large- scale genetic analyses and further our understanding of Precision Psychiatry across multiple traits and diseases. Here, we propose to leverage MVP data, integrate them with brain molecular profiling data, and perform a comprehensive analysis to investigate the functional roles of variants associated with serious mental illness that affect a great proportion of our Veterans. In addition to the tremendous burden of suffering and economic costs, these diseases increase the mortality rate among Veterans. Thus, this study is aimed at addressing the need for understanding the pathophysiology, identifying key drivers, and testing novel approaches to genetically informed customized treatment or prevention tailored to the individual characteristics of each patient.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interruption of the blood supply to the brain causes induces the detachment of contacts between neurons with the subsequent impairment of transmission of information. This process is initially reversible, but after variables period of time becomes irreversible and leads to the development of permanent neurological deficits. In this application we will study the mechanism whereby the different compartment of the synapse detach from each other during an ischemic stroke. We will then use this knowledge to develop a therapeutic strategy to induce the re-attachment of those components before the development of permanent functional deficits. We postulate that this will improve the functional outcome following an acute ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Syncope, or transient loss of consciousness, is a common reason for visit to the Emergency Department and often leads to extensive testing and hospitalization. Using objective risk scores to determine which patients with syncope will actually benefit from these interventions, and which can be safely discharged home with minimal testing, is critical to providing sensible medical care. Our study will evaluate the validity of two syncope risk-stratification tools and investigate their impact on healthcare utilization and patient safety, thus improving the quality of care for the 1-2 million patients who experience syncope every year in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This T32 proposal will establish the first transdisciplinary postdoctoral training program focusing on transdiagnostic, neurodevelopmental mechanisms of psychopathology, with an expanded focus on lifespan and environmental context. All postdoctoral fellows will have two co- mentors: (1) A co-mentor with expertise in neurodevelopmental and/or environmental mechanisms of psychopathology; and (2) a co-mentor in one of the following areas: (a) prevention, intervention, or implementation, (b) computational psychiatry and data science, or (c) the intersection of mental health and pediatric health. The transdisciplinary mentorship and didactic training will launch the next generation of neurodevelopmental clinical science researchers poised to accelerate the pace of clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles, especially the exosomes, have been recognized as a novel and highly effective means of cell-cell communication. Recent studies have implicated exosomes in many pathophysiological processes such as cardiovascular development, host-pathogen interaction, neuronal degeneration, and cancer. Studying the molecular basis of exosomal trafficking, and how exosome biogenesis is regulated by oncogenic signaling will not only provide the fundamental understanding of exosome trafficking, but also open new venues for therapeutic targeting of exosomes in cancer diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol is the most commonly used and abused drug in the United States. Chronic alcohol abuse results in neuronal degeneration and functional deficits in sensory-motor, memory, psychological, and cognitive functions. In this proposal, we hypothesize that the neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration, and cognitive deficits resulting from alcohol-induced oxidative damage can be repaired by activating the antioxidant signaling Nrf2 (nuclear factor E2-related factor 2) pathway using a small Nrf2 activator III peptide (briefly called as Nrf2 peptide). We will validate the effect of Nrf2 peptide with Nrf2 KO (Nrf2-/-) mice. We will use a cohort of behavioral tests that include cognitive and sensory-motor functions, and psychological stress to validate the effect of Nrf2 peptide in functional recovery in AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Experiments described in this proposal examine how synaptic activity and calcium signaling regulate long-distance molecular motor transport for delivery and removal of synaptic glutamate receptors. This is important because delivery and removal of receptor affect synaptic transmission, learning and memory. The ultimate goal of this project is to help human health by stimulating the development of pharmaceuticals that can modulate molecular motor transport thereby affecting cognition and neurodegeneration, but also potentially diabetes and cancer.

PHR: Evidence suggests that activators of the metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) receptor mGlu1 subtype in the brain have exciting potential as novel treatments for positive symptoms and cognitive disturbances in patients suffering from schizophrenia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: High grade serous cancers arise in the fallopian tube and exhibit a high proclivity to metastasize to the ovary as their primary metastatic site and omentum as a secondary site. Our team developed novel imaging mass spectrometry workflows to interrogate 3D organ culture systems co-cultured with fallopian tube derived tumor models to study the chemical crosstalk that occurs during metastasis. Overall, these data provide important new tools to uncover the signaling that occurs between organs and cells as it relates to the ovarian microenvironment in high grade serous metastasis.

PHR: Cilia are cellular extensions that play essential motile and signaling roles in human development and biology. This study will investigate the mechanisms by which the dynein motors that power ciliary motility are assembled and controlled. It will also study the role of peptide amidation in cilia formation, and how cilia-derived bioactive amidated products participate in cell-cell communication.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission because will shed light on the processes of human growth and development with the potential to improve health. More specifically, the work proposed is expected to define the mechanisms responsible to increase risk of prediabetes in offspring generated with widely used fertility treatments. These studies are expected to have an important impact because of the translational value to the fields of developmental reprogramming, diabetes, obesity and for patients affected with infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline RUNX1-mutations in familial platelet disorder (FPD), establishing a pre-leukemic state in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells, cause a life-long risk of developing leukemia in at least 40% of individuals at the median age of 33 years. Since the clinical symptoms and bone marrowcytokine profiling of FPD patients indicate increased inflammation, this proposal seeks to understand the cross-talk of RUNX1-mutations with inflammatory cytokines and its role in altering the functions of bone marrow niche and hematopoiesis. The results will determine novel therapeutic targets and offer premise of improved treatment options and preventive care for familial platelet disorder patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There is a potential link between the incidence of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most important demyelinating disease in human, and combat service as several vaccinations (anthrax, hepatitis B), viral infections, CNS toxins, and air pollutants may increase the risk of having MS among veterans. Here, we want to test if selective targeting of activated status of one component of the innate immune system (TLR2) by wild type TLR2- interacting domain of MyD88 (wtTIDM) peptide promotes the maturation of oligodendroglial progenitor cells and stimulate remyelination in animal models of demyelination. This study will enhance the possibility of developing an intranasal agent to stimulate remyelination in patients with multiple sclerosis and other demyelinating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Non-adherence to medications and treatment recommendations due to costs is an important driver of the socioeconomic status (SES) gradient in health outcomes among adults with Type 2 diabetes.1 Value Based Insurance Design (VBID) strategies that lower out-of-pocket costs for both diabetes medications and disease management visits may improve treatment compliance and health outcomes among adults with low SES; however, little is known about the effects of VBID in this population. Understanding the short and long-term health, disability and healthcare costs impacts of VBID among low SES adults with diabetes and how these effects vary across patient subgroups will be key for informing health insurance benefit design and efforts to improve health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance We propose to investigate the ability of individuals with treatment-resistant major depressive disorder (TR- MDD) to increase and sustain activity of the amygdala during positive memory recall, and relate this ability to outcomes that are clinically relevant for those with the disorder. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a disease highly prevalent in patients with obesity and diabetes, that can increase the risk of heart disease. In some patients, NASH leads to liver failure or cancer. Women of reproductive age have lower rates of NASH. However, this protection is lost after menopause when NASH rates equal or exceed those for men. There is evidence that estrogen, in combination with growth hormone (GH), work together at the level of the liver to protect both men and women against NASH. Studies are proposed that will use unique mouse models with diet-induced NASH to better understand the basic mechanisms by which estrogen and GH prevent or slow NASH progression. This information can be used to unveil novel targets to develop drugs that can treat NASH.

Because current treatment options are often of limited efficacy with high recurrence rates that elicit undesirable side effects, new medical treatments and identification of their targeting mechanisms are needed for endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural studies of influenza hemagglutinin in complex with broadly neutralizing antibodies and designed inhibitors have established sites of vulnerability that are highly conserved across hemagglutinin subtypes. Here, we will develop and use novel high-throughput screening assays that permit the robust interrogation of the vulnerable and highly conserved site located within the hemagglutinin stem region of influenza A and B. Recurring recognition motifs and conserved pockets observed in our collection of HA crystal structures will provide a platform and strong foundation for the optimization of small molecule leads as therapeutic candidates to prevent influenza virus infection and pandemic threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Glycogen metabolism is impaired in >20 individual rare genetic diseases with several diseases being caused by the accumulation of insoluble glycogen in liver, muscle, heart, and/or brain tissue. This proposal studies the molecular mechanisms underlying the prevention of pathogenic insoluble glycogen. We (1) provide a better grasp of vital cellular processes that maintain water-solubility of glycogen to function as a central metabolite for energy storage and utilization and (2) lay the foundation for new therapeutic approaches for several rare diseases with insoluble glycogen accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Upstream Open Reading frames (uORFs) are important cis-regulatory elements that control mRNA translation and decay. Although the human genome encodes thousands of uORFs, only a small number have been experimentally tested and many questions remain regarding their function and regulation. We propose to use novel high- throughput approaches to determine the functions of human uORFs, evaluate their importance in cellular stress responses, and investigate their potential regulation by RNA Binding Proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Characterization of Renal Allograft Fibrosis and Prediction of Outcome Using a Quantitative MRI Approach Project Narrative Caused by a variety of etiologies, acute and chronic renal allograft injury often results in the development of interstitial fibrosis/tubular atrophy (IFTA), is a significant cause of allograft failure and poor outcomes; the reference standard for which is tissue biopsy, which is limited due to sampling error and risk of complications. In this proposal, we will develop a short, non-contrast multiparametric MRI (mpMRI) protocol, consisting of advanced relaxometry (T1 mapping and T1) and advanced diffusion weighted imaging (IVIM-DWI) to accurately detect and stage allograft fibrosis, taking into account confounding Banff variables of inflammation and tested against biopsy. We will also assess the added value of urinary biomarkers of IFTA and if successful, this study will benefit a large population of patients with renal allograft fibrosis in the United States, enabling early diagnosis, optimized treatment planning, prognostication and longitudinal disease monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal Alcohol Exposure (PAE) is the leading cause of neurodevelopmental disability in the US. However, the emerging practice of simultaneous alcohol and cannabinoid (SAC) use among young adults of child-bearing age makes it imperitive to investigate the additional risk for adverse infant outcomes due to such prenatal poly-substance use. The goals of this proposal are consistent with the priorities of the Collaborative Research on Addiction at NIH (CRAN) initiative, which are to, “address poly- or multiple substance use, abuse, and addiction” and to “elucidate the common, specific, and interacting causes and consequences of substance exposure”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adults face a striking levels of depression, anxiety, and loneliness, and though social factors—such as peer support—are likely pivotal to the mental health trajectories of young adults, existing work is limited in its ability to precisely quantify these long-term effects. This project will apply a unique combination of social network analysis, experience sampling, and neuroimaging in a large, longitudinal sample (two university cohorts) to examine (i) the formation of social communities among young adults, (ii) the effects of subjective, biological, and community-level indices of social connectedness on students’ mental health over their four-year college arc, and (iii) the role of relationships in sustaining well being during an acute, large-scale stressor—the COVID-19 pandemic. This work will sharpen basic science understanding of social factors in mental health, and pave the way for precise, novel interventions to bolster social connectedness and well being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal aims to understand how secretory and membrane proteins are properly synthesized and folded in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The ER-resident sensor molecules monitor and adjust the protein folding capacity of the ER according to demand. We previously discovered that one of the sensor molecules, IRE1, forms a direct complex with the protein translocation machinery in the ER. In this proposal, we will mechanistically understand how both IRE1 and protein translocation machinery work together to maintain ER homeostasis, which is fundamentally important for producing functional molecules, including antibodies, hormones, and transport proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite advances in HIV-1 therapeutics, there is a need for anti-retrovirals that prevent resistance and that can be formulated as long-acting drugs. Nearly all current drugs are targeted to viral proteins. This application seeks to delineate a new host-virus protein-protein interaction interface as a drug target and to develop novel, first-in-class, dual-acting drugs which can target both virus- host protein-protein and viral protein-viral RNA interactions. These drugs that potently inhibit HIV- 1 replication may not induce drug resistance due to the fact that host factor is essential for viral replication and the escape mutants are likely to be replication defective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In this project we are developing new ways to understand the mechanisms by which cells interpret, and in cancer misinterpret, the host of stimuli from outside and inside the cell that determine behavior. We are building molecules that can report, through light emission, the behavior of multiple key elements of the cellular “decision making circuits”, and in parallel developing new mathematical tools to interpret the output of these molecules, and to integrate this data into overall models that reveal information flow in the circuitry. We are also developing the ability to control one circuit component while watching the activity of another, enabling us to dissect out causal relationships within cellular circuits.
